			<title>Finding Small Business Fraud with James Ratley</title>
			<itunes:title>Finding Small Business Fraud with James Ratley</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 30 Oct 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[22b1ec83-50da-4afd-ac44-ef849104d385]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/244]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">There are a shocking amount of businesses that ultimately fail because of fraud. Many managers and business owners are unaware of their losses because they do not have the systems in place to look for fraud and it may not be their primary concern.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is James Ratley. Jim graduated from the University of Texas at Dallas with a bachelor’s degree in Business Administration. In 1971, he joined the Dallas Police Department as a police officer. He was on numerous task forces with a concentration on major fraud cases. He joined a major forensic accounting practice and was in charge of fraud investigations.</p> <p dir="ltr">In 1988, he was named the Program Director of The Association of Certified Fraud Examiners and in 2006, became the President. In 2011, he became the CEO and he retired in 2018 after 30 years there. James has been an adjunct professor, published author, and named by Accounting Today as one of the top influencers multiple times.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:14] - James shares his background and the way his career panned out over 30 years.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:35] - When the ACFE was established, there was no information or education around it at all.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:09] - The average organization loses 5% of their revenue to fraud. Out of every ten people hired, statistically, six of them will steal from you.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:46] - Fraud can be prevented and strategies to reduce fraud are typically inexpensive.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:40] - It’s important for business owners not to be afraid to call it fraud.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:25] - Fraud perpetrators believe they deserve what they’ve taken.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:26] - It’s important for businesses to have strong management and leadership. Training is crucial.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:18] - James discusses the most common types of fraud and how even the seemingly minor things could be detrimental.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[18:24] - Fraud perpetrators are really good at hiding what they are doing and making the business owners believe it could never be them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:15] - Another strategy is to separate tasks out and be strict about them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:37] - Surprise cash counts is another good strategy.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:13] - There are no small frauds, only frauds that have not had time to reach maturity.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:44] - You impact rationalization through education.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[29:16] - James lists some of the red flags that could indicate something more going on.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[31:31] - There should be policies and regulations that purchasing officers are held to.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:30] - Auditors must be completely independent.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[40:10] - Some business owners will deny the problem is happening because it is hard to deal with and accept that someone they trust could be stealing.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[44:35] - Many small organizations go out of business due to operating at a loss. Most of the time this is because of fraud.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[47:25] - Never judge someone by the standards you have for yourself.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[51:12] - Something to remember is that most fraudsters will steal in even numbers.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[53:11] - In most cases that James has worked, the manager had seen all the signs, but never thought anything about it.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.acfe.com/about-the-acfe/staff/bio-james-ratley">ACFE Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Truth and Lies with Mark Bowden</title>
			<itunes:title>Truth and Lies with Mark Bowden</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 23 Oct 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ad979416-9e98-43a6-a132-c990603da6a5]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/243]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Now that so much of our communications are digital, such as texts, emails, and chats, we miss out on the tone and facial expressions to help us understand the intent and content in communication. It’s important to know ourselves well enough to know what areas we’ll be more easily influenced and are susceptible to being deceived. The greater our desire for something to be true, the easier it is for us to be scammed.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Mark Bowden. Mark is a world-renowned body language expert, keynote speaker, and best-selling author. He is the founder of the communication training company, TruthPlane. Mark is also a member of The Behavior Panel on YouTube.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:08] - Mark shares his background and what motivated him to specialize in human behavior.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[2:34] - There are parts of the brain that are activated when we first meet someone new.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:56] - Think about how many people you see on a regular day. Some you will notice and some you will not.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:03] - There are certain parts of the brain that can overwrite natural instinct.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:02] - Mark demonstrates how body language changes when there is perceived risk.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:50] - Body language signals can be perceived inaccurately. People can also change their body language to send different signals.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:15] - So many signals that our brains rely on in communication disappear when we cannot see the person we’re talking to.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[19:16] - Mark gives an example of how the human brain perceives the bait of a scam.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:48] - The first step in critical thinking is to suspend judgment.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:58] - “You can only con a greedy man.” Think about what you want so much that if it were offered, you lose your sense of judgment.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:33] - If anyone ever tells you that something seems like it isn’t true, suspend judgment and look into it.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:32] - It’s a risky world. There are people who have dedicated their lives to deceiving others.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[35:13] - Part of critical thinking is asking other people whom you trust about what they think.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:56] - Sometimes we will set people up to see how they will respond.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[43:11] - It is best to have an open mind and be willing to see things for what they are over what you want them to be.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://truthplane.com/home/people/mark-bowden/">TruthPlane Website</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@MarkBowden1">Mark Bowden on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/@TheBehaviorPanel">The Behavior Panel on YouTube</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

There are people who have dedicated their lives to deceiving others.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[35:13] - Part of critical thinking is asking other people whom you trust about what they think.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:56] - Sometimes we will set people up to see how they will respond.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[43:11] - It is best to have an open mind and be willing to see things for what they are over what you want them to be.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>The Update That Broke America with Gabe Dimeglio</title>
			<itunes:title>The Update That Broke America with Gabe Dimeglio</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 16 Oct 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0308078a-2779-4263-8cd9-6600999af9c0]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/242]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Many industries are reliant on software and if the software becomes corrupt or an update fails, it may require hands-on support. Do you have your infrastructure set for repair and recovery?</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Gabe Dimeglio. Gabe is a 20-year veteran of information technology and security for private and public sector organizations. He is a results-driven leader, specializing in security services and solutions for mission-critical, complex enterprise platforms. His expertise includes strategic consulting services, risk analysis/risk mitigation, and compliance.</p> <p dir="ltr">Mr. Dimeglio serves as Vice President & Executive Advisor, Security, Office of the CTO at Rimini Street. He is responsible for oversight of the GSS organization that provides tailored consulting and advisory security services to prospects and clients, in collaboration with Rimini Street sales, client engagement, and retention functions.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:18] - Gabe shares his background and what he does in his roles at Rimini Street.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[2:38] - Anyone can be a victim of a scam. That includes Gabe.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:03] - Scams are very sophisticated and techniques have come a long way in the last decade.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:23] - Gabe describes what happened with the update that shut down much of the United States’ systems and infrastructure.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:30] - To complicate things, the platform could not be restarted with this update in effect.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:42] - Updates are sideloaded continuously and are processed by this kernel driver. The thought process is interesting because it has happened before.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[12:37] - This was the biggest problem caused by Crowdstrike.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:47] - One mistake out of 10,000 updates is a low error rate, but there is a lot of reputation damage done in this event.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:50] - In the case of Crowdstrike, turning off auto-update was not an option.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[18:43] - Any time software, programs, or data are introduced, you’re also introducing risk.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:04] - Part of the solution to fixing this massive problem was hands-on support on every box.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:13] - One problem is that there are some industries where technology is very outdated.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:23] - People are selling their solutions and the solutions are cloud-managed. This is scary due to frequent cloud breaches.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[31:10] - There are still businesses that have no security professionals or teams managing client data and safety.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:53] - The skills gap is crushing most businesses.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[35:03] - Security has come a long way, even if there are still areas of lack.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[37:01] - For the last couple of years, security has been something that there is a budget for in most businesses.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[40:49] - Don’t ever let anyone convince you to shortcut anything.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.riministreet.com/blog/author/gdimeglio/">Rimini Street Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>A Lesson in Crisis Management with Jeremiah Grossman</title>
			<itunes:title>A Lesson in Crisis Management with Jeremiah Grossman</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 09 Oct 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2d876e9f-5c8b-4adf-a274-9b0c2150e9d5]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/241]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">It’s not always easy to determine the value of digital assets. The potential of overestimating or undervaluing your data can make it difficult to establish how much protection you need for a cyber intrusion. </p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Jeremiah Grossman. Jeremiah has spent over 25 years as an InfoSec professional and hacker. He is the Managing Director of Grossman Ventures. He is an industry creator and founder of White Hat Security and Bit Discovery. He has his black belt in Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and is an avid car collector.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:53] - Jeremiah shares his background and what he does as the managing director of new venture capital, Grossman Venture.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:55] - When he was 24, Jeremiah’s business was victimized by a data breach.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:30] - This experience taught him that if you treat your customers with integrity and have their best interests in mind, they will keep doing business with you.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:43] - These things happen to countless businesses. It is important to keep customers and clients informed.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:27] - Cybercrime is one of the only crimes where the victim doesn’t always know they’re a victim.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:30] - When it comes to solving these problems, we have to narrow in on the problems that are worth solving and then work for a solution.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:53] - Doing an asset evaluation is a good starting point. There is no algorithm to determine the value of digital assets.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[19:18] - What role does AI play in this and what should people be wary of?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:31] - How do we raise the cost on the adversary?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:12] - There are ways to bait adversaries as well which is an inexpensive solution.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:17] - These days, adversaries are nowhere physically near the data. They access it all through digital means.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:28] - Jeremiah is optimistic about AI and in his perspective, AI is a tool that will help us determine solutions.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:07] - Currently, cyber insurance has become compulsory.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:48] - Jeremiah explains how things work in venture capital and the problems that are common.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:11] - There are many things that we can do better in this space.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[35:46] - Jeremiah shares advice for small and medium-sized businesses.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.jeremiahgrossman.com/">Jeremiah Grossman’s Website</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/jeremiahg">Jeremiah on Twitter</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Pig Butchering Is Getting Worse with Erin West</title>
			<itunes:title>Pig Butchering Is Getting Worse with Erin West</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 02 Oct 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ab0802a1-93a1-4141-b1f7-c4aa74b0503a]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/240]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Pig butchering is worse than just manipulating someone and taking their money. It leaves them with emotional anguish. Once their finances have been drained, they lose their financial security and they no longer trust people. Today’s guest is Erin West. Erin has been with the County of Santa Clara for 26 years and is a Deputy District Attorney. She specializes in cryptocurrency investigations and prosecutions. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:46] - Erin shares her background and what her role is as a Deputy District Attorney in Santa Clara County.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:20] - Five years ago, Erin found herself working on prosecutions regarding SIM swapping and cryptocurrency hacks.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:35] - The emotional impact of “just a financial crime,” is staggering.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:38] - You never know who around you is a victim of some of these crimes.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:18] - Erin describes the experience of being convinced to click a link herself. </li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:32] - Scammers will think about different things that would trigger someone into clicking a link.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:40] - Pig butchering involves building trust with a victim and showing them a false plush lifestyle.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:08] - A red flag is a text or social media message you may receive that seems misdirected or to a wrong number.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[19:21] - It feels like the right thing to do when we feel the need to respond to the scammer with a “you’ve got the wrong number,” but that’s how they start a conversation.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:29] - In many cases, scammers bulk text a massive amount of phone numbers. But some people are specifically targeted on social media.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[24:23] - Covid really accelerated this type of scam due to loneliness.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:40] - A misconception is that these scams target the elderly. 			<title>Protecting Parents with Terri Proctor</title>
			<itunes:title>Protecting Parents with Terri Proctor</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 25 Sep 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3989d21a-ef88-484f-926e-b7d12f0c4d1d]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/239]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Sometimes people only share their stories after they’ve gone through a challenging time. But it’s also important to learn from those in the middle of a scam to learn how people are manipulated and how vulnerable our loved ones can really be.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Terri Proctor. Terri’s elderly mother has been scammed by romance scammers over the last three years. In trying to get help from different recommended services, she realized that no one was really interested in helping. She started the non-profit Stop Elderly Scams to educate and bring awareness to the community. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:53] - Terri shares her background and how she was thrown into her situation. Her experience led her to founding a non-profit.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[2:28] - Over the course of a year, Terri’s mother lost about $100,000 to a romance scammer.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:30] - Terri’s mother was not treated like a victim. She was treated as a willing participant.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:01] - There were many reasons why Terri’s mother was vulnerable to manipulation, including loneliness.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:23] - It is sad to see the comments online about victims of scams.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:23] - The shame and embarrassment a lot of victims feel causes them to not talk about the problem or seek help.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:57] - In the beginning, Terri admits that she had a lot of anger and frustration that was also focused on her mother. It is better to listen and try to reason.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:54] - Terri’s mother was stopped by a store manager from buying more gift cards. The manager has expressed concern that she is not the only one.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:51] - Part of the vulnerability of Terri’s mother is loneliness.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[18:47] - Other types of scams tend to target the elderly. It is hard to keep up.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[24:08] - How can we help our loved ones without taking away their independence?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:21] - People should feel free to talk about these issues. Terri shares how her non-profit is helping educate and make a difference.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:46] - It is challenging to find the balance in helping loved ones and making sure they have their autonomy.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[29:59] - When you think you’ve learned about one thing or one scam, another problem pops up.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://stopelderlyscams.com/">Stop Elderly Scams Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Technology Regulation is Outdated with Bruce Schneier</title>
			<itunes:title>Technology Regulation is Outdated with Bruce Schneier</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 18 Sep 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[aef2c61a-c491-4272-bb59-95382426ea10]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/238]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Regulators have to invest a considerable amount of time in keeping legislation and policy up to date regarding technology and AI, but it’s not easy. We need floor debates, not for sound bytes or for political gain, but to move policy forward.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Bruce Schneier. Bruce is an internationally renowned security technologist called The Security Guru by The Economist. He is the author of over a dozen books including his latest, A Hacker’s Mind. He has testified before Congress, is a frequent guest on television and radio, has served on several government committees, and is regularly quoted in the press. He is a fellow at the Berkman-Klein Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University, a lecturer in Public Policy at Harvard Kennedy School, a board member of the Electronic Frontier Foundation and AccessNow, and an advisory board member of EPIC and VerifiedVoting.org.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:40] - Bruce shares what he teaches at Harvard and the current interest in policy.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:27] - The notion that tech can’t be regulated has been very harmful.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:00] - Typically, the United States doesn’t regulate much in tech. Most regulation has come from Europe.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:52] - AI is a power magnification tool. Will the uses empower the already powerful or democratize power?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:16] - Bruce describes loopholes and how AI as a power magnification tool can mean something different in different situations.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[12:06] - It will be interesting to watch AI begin to do human cognitive tasks because they will do them differently.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:58] - Bruce explains how AI collaboration can be a real benefit.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:17] - Like every text writer, AI is going to become a collaborative tool. What does this mean for writing legislation?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:18] - AI can write more complex and detailed laws than humans can.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:27] - AI regulation will be skewed towards corporations. Bruce explains how public AI could work.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:46] - Will AI help the defender or the attacker more?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:19] - AI can be good against legacy, but we need some sort of infrastructure.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[29:27] - There’s going to be a need for proof of humanity.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:29] - It is hard to know what people can do to help move regulation along. Ultimately, it is a political issue.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.schneier.com/">Schneier on Security</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Threat Emulation with Andrew Costis</title>
			<itunes:title>Threat Emulation with Andrew Costis</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 11 Sep 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3e9ffdfd-20fc-4290-8dc7-af7c68c6640b]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/237]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Security risks are dynamic. Projects, employees, change, tools, and configurations are modified. Many companies utilize PEN testers on an annual basis, but as quickly as systems are revised, you may need to implement threat emulation for regular monitoring. </p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Andrew Costis. Andrew is the Chapter Lead of the Adversary Research Team at Attack IQ. He has over 22 years of professional industry experience and previously worked in the Threat Analysis Unit Team at Firmware, Carbon Black, and Logrhythm Labs, performing security research, reverse engineering malware, and tracking and discovering new campaigns and threats. Andrew has delivered various talks at DefCon, Adversary Village, Black Hat, B Side, Cyber Risk Alliance, Security Weekly, IT Pro, Bright Talk, SE Magazine, and others.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:14] - Andrew shares his background and what he currently does in his career at Attack IQ.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:49] - At the time of this recording, there has been a major global security panic.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:06] - There are many programs that we use on a regular basis that we don’t always consider the security of.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:09] - Historically, companies would pay for an external pen test. Andrew describes the purpose of this and how they usually went.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:33] - Pen tests and threat emulation do not need to be limited to just once a year.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:45] - Andrew’s team is in the business of testing post-breached systems. But they preach prevention.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:55] - Attackers are lazy in the sense that they will reuse the same strategies over and over again.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:13] - Many programs we use may be caught in the crosshairs of attacks and vulnerabilities in other companies.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:41] - Andrew discusses the frequency of really critical CVEs.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[19:01] - What do attackers go after when they’ve breached a system?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:04] - The priority for attackers is to get in quickly and make the victim’s data unavailable.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:24] - A lot of people are under the impression of vulnerability testers. “Fire and forget it” is not a beneficial mindset.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[24:56] - If we run every test, the amount of data will be overwhelming.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:03] - In his experience, there has been client testing that has been overwhelmingly easy to breach.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[29:07] - There are also organizations that have done a fantastic job. However, vulnerabilities will still be found.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:18] - The red team is not going to be able to cover your entire organization.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:15] - Threat emulation and pen testing are technically the same thing. Andrew explains how she sees the difference.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[33:50] - How are vulnerabilities and tests prioritized?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:19] - Andrew describes the things his team works on and their objectives for customers and clients.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[38:34] - The outage at the time of this recording had a big impact. It gave a really good idea of what could happen if it were a real security breach.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[41:37] - There are a ton of free resources out there. The primary resource at Attack IQ is the free Attack IQ Academy.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.attackiq.com/author/acostis/">Andrew Costis at Attack IQ</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Ransomware: To Pay or Not To Pay? with Amitabh Sinha</title>
			<itunes:title>Ransomware: To Pay or Not To Pay? with Amitabh Sinha</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 04 Sep 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b01fa0d8-5ee8-49d0-a8ed-dd98d448b28e]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/236]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Ransomware may not be on your machines due to your negligence or mistakes. It could be there because of third-party software you are utilizing. Do you know what to do if this happens to you? </p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Amitabh Sinha. Amitabh has a PhD in Computer Science and more than 20 years of experience in enterprise software, end-user computing, mobile, and database software. He co-founded Workspot in 2012. He was the General Manager of Enterprise Desktop and Applications at Citrix Systems. In his five years at Citrix, he was the VP of Product Management for XenDesktop and VP of Engineering for the Advanced Solutions Group.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:03] - Amitabh shares his background and current role and contributions at Workspot.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:35] - The first sign of ransomware in an organization is widespread blue screens and Microsoft machines shutting down.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:40] - How does ransomware find its way to a device?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:59] - Ransomware in your organization is not necessarily your fault.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:37] - Amitabh describes how he has helped client organizations back up and running after having been infected with ransomware.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:11] - Typically, it is not recommended to pay the ransomware, but it may be a viable option for some organizations.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[15:59] - Most small companies are not prepared to prevent or handle ransomware.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:34] - In most large companies, not all PCs are up to date on security patches.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:41] - Cloud storage is much safer and can be accessed on other physical machines in the event that ransomware shuts down an organization.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[24:41] - For those who work from home, sometimes multiple machines makes things even more complicated.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:35] - What are you willing to pay to not have something happen? That’s how ransomware takes advantage of people.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[31:20] - For small companies, there is typically an architectural solution, but that isn’t always viable for large organizations.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[33:14] - Consider the critical functions of your organizations and what a plan could be if computers were not accessible.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:37] - These types of attacks are more and more frequent.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:44] - Amitabh is confident that AI will make preventing ransomware even more challenging.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[40:38] - Most people have accepted that a lot, if not all, their information has already been leaked on the internet. But businesses are particularly vulnerable.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[42:30] - A whole organization can be drastically impacted by just one machine being hit by ransomware.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/amitabhbsinha/">Amitabh Sinha on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "http://workspot.com">Workspot.com</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons with Carey Parker</title>
			<itunes:title>Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons with Carey Parker</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 28 Aug 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[f8ad85b2-a7fd-4e2a-b092-3913ebab8555]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/235]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">We all use technology. Things like internet browsers, search engines, instant messaging, and payment apps. But we aren’t always aware of the data being collected. This information can not only impact your privacy, but those around you as well.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Carey Parker. Carey is the author of <em><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/FIREWALLS-DONT-DRAGONS-STEP-STEP/dp/1484238516">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons</a></em>, a step-by-step guide to computer security and privacy for non-techies. He also hosts a podcast by the same name. He recently retired from a career in software engineering to focus on teaching others how to defend their digital devices and protect their personal data.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:53] - Carey shares his background and what provoked the motivation for a career shift.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:07] - If we all did the small things that protect privacy, we would all be stronger.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:20] - Even if you have already shared a lot of your information online, it is not hopeless and it’s not too late.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:32] - Your security and privacy overlap with other people’s.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:35] - We need to be protecting privacy for all of us, not just ourselves as individuals.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:17] - Carey explains why and how apps and companies collect data.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:48] - Foreign governments would love to get their hands on the data that is collected by countless companies and apps.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:53] - Data is valuable to software developers for honest reasons. Collecting data isn’t inherently bad.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:16] - When determining what connection to use, you are trading off who you trust - your ISP, the public wifi connection, or a VPN.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:10] - Carey shares some easy things you can change right now to protect your privacy.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:25] - Companies love to get your email address and your phone number. These become unique identifiers.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:05] - Search engines collect data as well. This is important to remember.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:05] - Payment apps are another obvious type of website that collects data. Which ones should you avoid?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:32] - There is value in social media. Make sure the things you post are not public by default.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:19] - Metadata and location tools are used on any social media image.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:37] - Messaging apps collect data and share it. There is a gold standard app though that Carey suggests.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:31] - Email is trickier because it is open standard. It wasn’t designed with encryption in mind.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[38:55] - Carey discusses automated AI systems like Alexa.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[41:26] - When using AI tools, assume that the information is collected and could be public.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[42:35] - Car privacy is horrible and there is almost nothing you can do about it.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[46:18] - It is not true that you need to give up privacy for security. Carey discusses the differences.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://firewallsdontstopdragons.com/">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons Website</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://firewallsdontstopdragons.com/podcast/">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons Podcast</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/FIREWALLS-DONT-DRAGONS-STEP-STEP/dp/1484238516"> <em>Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons</em> by Carey Parker</a></li> </ul>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">We all use technology. Things like internet browsers, search engines, instant messaging, and payment apps. But we aren’t always aware of the data being collected. This information can not only impact your privacy, but those around you as well.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Carey Parker. Carey is the author of <em><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/FIREWALLS-DONT-DRAGONS-STEP-STEP/dp/1484238516">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons</a></em>, a step-by-step guide to computer security and privacy for non-techies. He also hosts a podcast by the same name. He recently retired from a career in software engineering to focus on teaching others how to defend their digital devices and protect their personal data.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:53] - Carey shares his background and what provoked the motivation for a career shift.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:07] - If we all did the small things that protect privacy, we would all be stronger.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:20] - Even if you have already shared a lot of your information online, it is not hopeless and it’s not too late.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:32] - Your security and privacy overlap with other people’s.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:35] - We need to be protecting privacy for all of us, not just ourselves as individuals.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:17] - Carey explains why and how apps and companies collect data.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:48] - Foreign governments would love to get their hands on the data that is collected by countless companies and apps.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:53] - Data is valuable to software developers for honest reasons. Collecting data isn’t inherently bad.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:16] - When determining what connection to use, you are trading off who you trust - your ISP, the public wifi connection, or a VPN.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:10] - Carey shares some easy things you can change right now to protect your privacy.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:25] - Companies love to get your email address and your phone number. These become unique identifiers.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:05] - Search engines collect data as well. This is important to remember.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:05] - Payment apps are another obvious type of website that collects data. Which ones should you avoid?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:32] - There is value in social media. Make sure the things you post are not public by default.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:19] - Metadata and location tools are used on any social media image.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:37] - Messaging apps collect data and share it. There is a gold standard app though that Carey suggests.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:31] - Email is trickier because it is open standard. It wasn’t designed with encryption in mind.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[38:55] - Carey discusses automated AI systems like Alexa.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[41:26] - When using AI tools, assume that the information is collected and could be public.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[42:35] - Car privacy is horrible and there is almost nothing you can do about it.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[46:18] - It is not true that you need to give up privacy for security. Carey discusses the differences.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://firewallsdontstopdragons.com/">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons Website</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://firewallsdontstopdragons.com/podcast/">Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons Podcast</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/FIREWALLS-DONT-DRAGONS-STEP-STEP/dp/1484238516"> <em>Firewalls Don’t Stop Dragons</em> by Carey Parker</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Stopping Robocalls with Aaron Foss</title>
			<itunes:title>Stopping Robocalls with Aaron Foss</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 21 Aug 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9bf190e9-2fcb-4f0f-89c5-8050c784b1ae]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/234]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Finding a solution to stop spam calls to you, your family, or your business isn’t easy. We may not win this war, but we don’t want the government making this decision for us. We can make it more manageable in the meantime.</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Aaron Foss. After winning the FTC Robocall Challenge in 2013, Aaron started Nomorobo. Since then, Nomorobo has stopped billions and billions of unwanted robocalls and spam texts from reaching our phones, and it was acquired by Applause group in August 2023. Aaron has been featured in The New York Times, Wired, CNN, CNBC, Fox News, and countless other media outlets. He has testified in front of Congress, not once, not twice, but three times.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:14] - Aaron shares his background as a serial entrepreneur in the intersection of technology and business.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[3:57] - At the beginning, Aaron didn’t even know what a robocall was.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:47] - Robocalls have this negative connotation. They can actually be good. But there are many that are unwanted.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:13] - There are different types of robocalls and there is a differentiation between spam and scam calls.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:08] - Aaron explains why spam emails are easier to block than robocalls.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[12:20] - There are some robocalls that are necessary and helpful for some people. That is one reason why not all robocalls can be blocked.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:40] - Not answering the phone is not a plausible solution.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[15:50] - Nomorobo is basically a series of bots talking to other bots.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:50] - Aaron describes caller ID and how spoofing a number is possible.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[19:42] - This is such a big problem because the barrier of entry is low.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:08] - It is amazing that we can call anyone in the world. But that also means that scammers can, too.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:53] - This is a complicated problem, and the future solution is a combination of government regulation, companies like Nomorobo, and AI.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:29] - We are never going to win the war, but we can keep it manageable.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[29:45] - What is the role of the carriers when it comes to robocalls?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[31:47] - Keeping scammers on the phone does not make the problem go away.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[33:52] - Some scams are seasonal and some are evergreen, like Medicare calls.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:26] - Aaron explains the different ways these scams can be done and the range of damage they can do.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:56] - At best, this is an annoyance. But there are people in our lives that are vulnerable and less protected.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[44:42] - Sometimes, Nomorobo users have to turn it off for specific reasons and specific calls they’re waiting for.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[47:56] - This problem is an example of “death by a thousand papercuts.”</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[49:30] - There are some red flags and things you might notice if you answer robocalls that could indicate that they are scams.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[50:46] - This seems like an easy problem to solve, but it is far more complicated than most people think.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[52:00] - Aaron describes what it was like to testify in front of Congress.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[56:43] - Listen and educate yourself. Talk to other people about these things.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.nomorobo.com/">Nomorobo Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Safety Can’t Be an Afterthought with Kris Burkhardt</title>
			<itunes:title>Safety Can’t Be an Afterthought with Kris Burkhardt</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 14 Aug 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[920f9c54-6464-41b9-b347-979947374a9a]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/233]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Most businesses rely on some type of software, either for scheduling, payment, banking, customer lists, or something else. It’s important to know where this information is stored and what would happen if that software was hacked or you weren’t able to access it. Today’s guest is Kris Burkhardt. As Accenture’s Chief Information Security Officer, Kris leads a team of over 800 security experts charged with protecting company client and customer data. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:49] - Kris describes his role at Accenture and what Accenture is known for in the security industry.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[2:26] - Part of their program is sending phishing tests and Kris has failed one before as well. It happens, especially when we are in a rush.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:39] - We are so highly connected that when something goes down, it impacts us in ways we never considered.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:10] - Many small businesses rely on software service providers because there is a lot of good about them. But what happens when they go down?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:56] - Defenders have to get it right all the time.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:13] - The last ten years have seen an immense amount of growth in how we store data. We have to stay ahead of change when it comes to security.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:59] - It is hard to understand how much we rely on technology.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:34] - Kris describes a time when the CEO of Accenture was used in a deep fake and the threat actor was very clever.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:17] - Kris believes that advances in technology will make it harder to pretend to be someone else.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:20] - Children are growing up in a technological world and are naturally more skeptical and cautious as a result.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:49] - Safety has always been an afterthought.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:15] - Kris shares what he thinks scams and deep fakes will look like in the near future.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:12] - Pay attention to things that don’t seem consistent.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:57] - People feel like there is a trade off when it comes to efficiency and security.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:37] - Having a plan ahead of time is absolutely beneficial in staying ahead of security problems.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[44:25] - As deep fakes become more and more of a problem, Kris suggests having code words with family members.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.accenture.com/us-en">Accenture Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

We have to stay ahead of change when it comes to security.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:59] - It is hard to understand how much we rely on technology.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:34] - Kris describes a time when the CEO of Accenture was used in a deep fake and the threat actor was very clever.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[21:17] - Kris believes that advances in technology will make it harder to pretend to be someone else.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[23:20] - Children are growing up in a technological world and are naturally more skeptical and cautious as a result.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:49] - Safety has always been an afterthought.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:15] - Kris shares what he thinks scams and deep fakes will look like in the near future.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:12] - Pay attention to things that don’t seem consistent.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[32:57] - People feel like there is a trade off when it comes to efficiency and security.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:37] - Having a plan ahead of time is absolutely beneficial in staying ahead of security problems.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[44:25] - As deep fakes become more and more of a problem, Kris suggests having code words with family members.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Child Safety Tips with Steve Lazarus</title>
			<itunes:title>Child Safety Tips with Steve Lazarus</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 07 Aug 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[46fe3e2c-53d8-43d5-a5a6-043c8bd802b7]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/232]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Is it right for parents to be the ones to have to put limits on their children’s screen time or to monitor the content they consume? Knowing the impact of social media and kids can influence the decisions that are made. Today’s guest is Steve Lazarus. Steve is a retired FBI agent, crime fiction author, and Instagram influencer specializing in personal and child safety topics.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[0:42] - Steve shares his background and his career history in the FBI and the military.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:02] - For a long time, Steve was anti-social media. However, since the publication of his book, he has garnered a significant social media following.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:50] - He started his Instagram with posts of things that he would never do as a retired FBI agent.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:08] - Steve describes the post that went super viral on TikTok and Instagram.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:00] - Parents need to know what their kids are looking at on the internet and control the amount of access they have online.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:40] - Sextortion is a very real and serious problem, especially for young boys.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[12:27] - Always report any case of sextortion or sexual content involving a minor. Law enforcement becomes involved immediately.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:09] - Steve lists some of the things to look for when children and teens that could be red flags.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:01] - The internet is on almost every device in your home. A child’s access is not limited to just a computer.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[17:59] - Covid did not help the increasing amount of time children spend online.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:52] - We’re asking kids to have good judgment without teaching them how.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:13] - The first question that needs to be asked by anyone, but especially a child is, “Do I know this person?”</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:07] - To deal with the digital world now, common sense is crucial and we can’t take everything at face value.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:56] - A relatively new issue is AI generated images that are very convincing and look so real.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Fraud: Not Going Away with Steve Lenderman</title>
			<itunes:title>Fraud: Not Going Away with Steve Lenderman</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 31 Jul 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[52d9dc84-4095-452f-9f9f-f95e72b84b38]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/231]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Synthetic IDs can be used to open fake accounts, but without a person to file the fraud claim, how should companies deal with this type of deceit? There is no crime where someone doesn’t need to pay for the loss. Either way, the loss is passed on to the consumers in some way or another. </p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Steve Lenderman. Steve is currently the Head of Fraud Solutions North America at Quantexa and has over 25 years of experience in financial crimes investigation. His previous roles include being the Senior Vice President of Fraud Prevention Investigations at Bank Mobile Technology, the Director of Strategic Fraud Prevention at ADP, and the Fraud Operations Lead for PayPal Business Loans. He is a certified fraud examiner and actively contributes to the anti-fraud community.</p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:07] - Steve shares his background and what his current role is at Quantexa.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:04] - For those who are interested in a career path in cybersecurity or fraud, Steve has some tips.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[6:07] - What is synthetic identity? Steve describes what it is and why we should be concerned about them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[8:59] - Although still mostly built around financial data, synthetic IDs have also morphed into other nefarious uses.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[10:56] - All fraud in general is underreported, but synthetic IDs are extremely underreported, so data is not accurate, although still very high.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[12:37] - Synthetic IDs can be used to open a credit card and then after several purchases, fraudsters leave the card open and unpaid.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[14:21] - Some think that synthetic IDs and fake accounts are victimless.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[18:59] - To understand how fraud works, Steve had to create synthetic IDs.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[22:15] - Over the years, it has gotten even easier to do, which is alarming.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:13] - Credit repair using a CPN is illegal fraud using synthetic IDs.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[26:40] - Synthetics are all built around data and the ease of collecting data in the last few years has increased the ease of creating them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:57] - Criminals have learned that they can use synthetic IDs in more ways and in more industries.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[31:04] - Small businesses are particularly easy targets for synthetic ID use.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[33:16] - It is possible for synthetic IDs to also be used to create a new business.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:53] - Technology has also made it possible for a deep fake to be created to match a synthetic ID.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:49] - A lot of synthetic IDs are created with unused credit.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905">subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://stevelenderman.com/">Steve Lenderman’s Website</a></li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation"><a href= "https://www.quantexa.com/">Quantexa Website</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Phishing Attack Awareness and Training with Josh Bartolomie</title>
			<itunes:title>Phishing Attack Awareness and Training with Josh Bartolomie</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 24 Jul 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[880390d6-31c8-43e2-83a4-147852ab9fc7]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/230]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Criminals do their own recon to study how vendors craft their emails and how they can structure them to match. Scammers know employees are busy and that they want to act promptly on requests, but they also understand it takes time to verify the validity of the email. How do we train employees to know what is real and what isn’t?</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Josh Bartolomie. After joining Cofense in 2018 as the Director of Research and Development, Josh currently serves as the Vice President of Global Threat Services. He has over 25 years of IT and cybersecurity experience. He designed, built, and managed security operations centers, incident response teams, security architecture, and compliance for global organizations. </p> <h3 dir="ltr">Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:08] - Josh shares his background and what he does in his current role at Cofense.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:06] - After all these years, email continues to be an easy way for scammers to target many people at one time and victimize a percentage of them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:52] - Wherever there are a lot of people, that is where attackers will go because that is a bigger pool of success for them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:08] - You used to be able to block emails with an unsubscribe button, but now we rely on those emails, too.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:50] - The goal is not to stop them altogether, because at this point it isn’t possible. The goal is to dissuade people from clicking links and trusting emails.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:47] - With AI and LM, crafting emails has never been easier for scammers.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:48] - Organizations get hit in different ways, but HR generally gets targeted a lot.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:54] - Intellectual property theft is also a part of email crafting.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:14] - Chris shares the story of an unfortunate experience.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:10] - Acknowledge that these things do happen and they can happen to you.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:33] - Always call the vendor. It’s an extra layer and extra work, but never trust an email that says something has changed when it comes to finances.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:54] - Organizations should have a strong reporting culture.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:55] - Employees can report emails that seem suspicious. The majority of them are spam emails, rather than scams, but they should be reported.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:02] - What constitutes a spam email? What is the difference?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:13] - Organizations tend to cut IT and cybersecurity when there are budget cuts.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:18] - This is changing every single day.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[41:46] - Scammers collect data and create profiles. They are very sophisticated in their strategies to target organizations.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p dir="ltr">Criminals do their own recon to study how vendors craft their emails and how they can structure them to match. Scammers know employees are busy and that they want to act promptly on requests, but they also understand it takes time to verify the validity of the email. How do we train employees to know what is real and what isn’t?</p> <p dir="ltr">Today’s guest is Josh Bartolomie. After joining Cofense in 2018 as the Director of Research and Development, Josh currently serves as the Vice President of Global Threat Services. He has over 25 years of IT and cybersecurity experience. He designed, built, and managed security operations centers, incident response teams, security architecture, and compliance for global organizations. </p> Show Notes: <ul> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[1:08] - Josh shares his background and what he does in his current role at Cofense.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[4:06] - After all these years, email continues to be an easy way for scammers to target many people at one time and victimize a percentage of them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[5:52] - Wherever there are a lot of people, that is where attackers will go because that is a bigger pool of success for them.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[7:08] - You used to be able to block emails with an unsubscribe button, but now we rely on those emails, too.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[9:50] - The goal is not to stop them altogether, because at this point it isn’t possible. The goal is to dissuade people from clicking links and trusting emails.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[11:47] - With AI and LM, crafting emails has never been easier for scammers.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[13:48] - Organizations get hit in different ways, but HR generally gets targeted a lot.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[16:54] - Intellectual property theft is also a part of email crafting.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[20:14] - Chris shares the story of an unfortunate experience.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[25:10] - Acknowledge that these things do happen and they can happen to you.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[27:33] - Always call the vendor. It’s an extra layer and extra work, but never trust an email that says something has changed when it comes to finances.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[28:54] - Organizations should have a strong reporting culture.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[30:55] - Employees can report emails that seem suspicious. The majority of them are spam emails, rather than scams, but they should be reported.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[34:02] - What constitutes a spam email? What is the difference?</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[36:13] - Organizations tend to cut IT and cybersecurity when there are budget cuts.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[39:18] - This is changing every single day.</li> <li dir="ltr" role="presentation">[41:46] - Scammers collect data and create profiles. They are very sophisticated in their strategies to target organizations.</li> </ul> <p dir="ltr">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Consumer Education for Fraud Protection with Doug Shadel</title>
			<itunes:title>Consumer Education for Fraud Protection with Doug Shadel</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 17 Jul 2024 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[14186f1a-ea93-4e28-8413-c74f71930e44]]></guid>
