		<item>
			<title>Stalkerware with Eva Galperin</title>
			<itunes:title>Stalkerware with Eva Galperin</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 16 Jun 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[fdadb385-8317-437d-80a8-15370e4dbdc1]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/68]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’ve ever had the feeling that someone is eavesdropping on your calls, reading your messages or emails, and even knows where you’ve been going, you just might be right. Abusers often utilize stalkerware to control and manipulate their targets. Being educated on what it is, how it got there, how to clean it off your devices, and where to go for help can make a world of difference.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Eva Galperin. Eva is the Director of Cybersecurity at The Electronic Frontier Foundation. She has worked in security and IT in Silicon Valley and earned degrees in Political Science and International Relations. She has applied the combination of her poli-sci and technical backgrounds to everything including organizing EFF’s TOR relay challenge to writing privacy and security training manuals. Those include Surveillance Self-Defense and The Digital First Aid Kit.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:21] - On her way to law school, Eva began working for Electronic Frontier Foundation and decided not to leave. She has worked in nearly every department.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:22] - Having worked in tech since a teen, Eva had a lot of experience with stalkerware. But she shares the reason why she was driven to research it further.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:02] - Through her own research and trials, Eva found that anti-virus apps did not protect against stalkerware.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:21] - Eva explains how abusers could react to stalkerware being removed from a device and leaves the decision up to the survivor on how and when to remove it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:30] - There are companies that are now paying more attention to stalkerware. Eva explains that this is a good thing, but also believes that it is because there has been an increase in the use of stalkerware.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:24] - The most recent report of stalkerware being detected by antivirus programs indicates a range of 60-95% as compared to only 10% a few years ago.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:33] - In cases of domestic abuse, an abuser has physical access to a device and can install stalkerware without the survivor even knowing.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:10] - Spouses and partners having access to each other’s devices and knowing passwords is very common in modern relationships.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:22] - Eva recommends stalkerware detection apps for Android and Apple.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:01] - Chris and Eva discuss Windows and Mac OS stalkerware.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:32] - What is the difference between account compromise and device compromise? Eva says the more common problem is account compromise.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:01] - Eva recommends different and long passwords for each account you have as well as having two factor authorization turned on. She explains how this works.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:09] - Eva’s advice for consumers is to meet them where they are. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:13] - You should go into your account settings and look for the page that lists devices and IP addresses that have logged into your account if you feel something is going on.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:32] - Personal trackers that are meant for people to keep track of their belongings are essentially a gift to stalkers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:11] - Regarding personal trackers, Eva shares that she has gotten some pushback on the abuse of these tools.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:32] - Software that allows you to do this without notifying the user so that they do not know that they are being watched is in and of itself abusive.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:01] - It is sad to see when people who have been abused feel that the only way they can take back power is to abuse as well.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:33] - Resetting to factory settings for most forms of device compromise is sufficient but you also need to change your account passwords and disable iCloud backups.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:51] - Eva loves open source for personal use, but as a general rule she doesn’t recommend it due to her security background.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:52] - If your cameras are compromised, covering the camera is a viable security measure. Covering microphones is trickier.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:43] - Chris and Eva discuss hackers hacking webcams, using blackmail photos, and sextortion emails.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:01] - Sometimes the extortion emails can confuse people severely enough to believe the scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:26] - Evan recommends the</span> <a href="https://nnedv.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">NNEDV</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and</span> <a href= "https://safeescape.org/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Operation Safe Escape</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">for those looking for support.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:17] - The U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline is 1-800-799-7233</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>If you’ve ever had the feeling that someone is eavesdropping on your calls, reading your messages or emails, and even knows where you’ve been going, you just might be right. Abusers often utilize stalkerware to control and manipulate their targets. Being educated on what it is, how it got there, how to clean it off your devices, and where to go for help can make a world of difference.</p> <p>Today’s guest is Eva Galperin. Eva is the Director of Cybersecurity at The Electronic Frontier Foundation. She has worked in security and IT in Silicon Valley and earned degrees in Political Science and International Relations. She has applied the combination of her poli-sci and technical backgrounds to everything including organizing EFF’s TOR relay challenge to writing privacy and security training manuals. Those include Surveillance Self-Defense and The Digital First Aid Kit.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li>[1:21] - On her way to law school, Eva began working for Electronic Frontier Foundation and decided not to leave. She has worked in nearly every department.</li> <li>[2:22] - Having worked in tech since a teen, Eva had a lot of experience with stalkerware. But she shares the reason why she was driven to research it further.</li> <li>[4:02] - Through her own research and trials, Eva found that anti-virus apps did not protect against stalkerware.</li> <li>[5:21] - Eva explains how abusers could react to stalkerware being removed from a device and leaves the decision up to the survivor on how and when to remove it.</li> <li>[6:30] - There are companies that are now paying more attention to stalkerware. Eva explains that this is a good thing, but also believes that it is because there has been an increase in the use of stalkerware.</li> <li>[7:24] - The most recent report of stalkerware being detected by antivirus programs indicates a range of 60-95% as compared to only 10% a few years ago.</li> <li>[8:33] - In cases of domestic abuse, an abuser has physical access to a device and can install stalkerware without the survivor even knowing.</li> <li>[10:10] - Spouses and partners having access to each other’s devices and knowing passwords is very common in modern relationships.</li> <li>[11:22] - Eva recommends stalkerware detection apps for Android and Apple.</li> <li>[13:01] - Chris and Eva discuss Windows and Mac OS stalkerware.</li> <li>[14:32] - What is the difference between account compromise and device compromise? Eva says the more common problem is account compromise.</li> <li>[16:01] - Eva recommends different and long passwords for each account you have as well as having two factor authorization turned on. She explains how this works.</li> <li>[18:09] - Eva’s advice for consumers is to meet them where they are. </li> <li>[19:13] - You should go into your account settings and look for the page that lists devices and IP addresses that have logged into your account if you feel something is going on.</li> <li>[21:32] - Personal trackers that are meant for people to keep track of their belongings are essentially a gift to stalkers.</li> <li>[23:11] - Regarding personal trackers, Eva shares that she has gotten some pushback on the abuse of these tools.</li> <li>[24:32] - Software that allows you to do this without notifying the user so that they do not know that they are being watched is in and of itself abusive.</li> <li>[26:01] - It is sad to see when people who have been abused feel that the only way they can take back power is to abuse as well.</li> <li>[27:33] - Resetting to factory settings for most forms of device compromise is sufficient but you also need to change your account passwords and disable iCloud backups.</li> <li>[28:51] - Eva loves open source for personal use, but as a general rule she doesn’t recommend it due to her security background.</li> <li>[29:52] - If your cameras are compromised, covering the camera is a viable security measure. Covering microphones is trickier.</li> <li>[30:43] - Chris and Eva discuss hackers hacking webcams, using blackmail photos, and sextortion emails.</li> <li>[33:01] - Sometimes the extortion emails can confuse people severely enough to believe the scam.</li> <li>[34:26] - Evan recommends the <a href="https://nnedv.org/">NNEDV</a> and <a href= "https://safeescape.org/">Operation Safe Escape</a> for those looking for support.</li> <li>[36:17] - The U.S. National Domestic Violence Hotline is 1-800-799-7233</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><em><a href="https://stopstalkerware.org/">Coalition Against Stalkerware - StopStalkerware.org</a></em></li> <li><a href="https://nnedv.org/">National Network to End Domestic Violence (NNEDV)</a></li> <li><a href="https://safeescape.org/">Operation Safe Escape</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.eff.org/">Electronic Frontier Foundation</a></li> <li>Email: <a href= "mailto:eva@eff.org">eva@eff.org</a></li> <li><a href= "https://twitter.com/evacide?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> Eva Galperin on Twitter</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

Roger is an author and international speaker. 			<title>People Hacking with Jenny Radcliffe</title>
			<itunes:title>People Hacking with Jenny Radcliffe</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 02 Jun 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ce292a8c-3e28-4b6b-be61-ebe3a0eebe28]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/66]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When you hear the word “hacker,” you envision someone breaking into a computer, but did you know that people can be hacked? The manipulation and persuasion of people can lead to someone gaining physical access to a location or even data being leaked. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Jenny Radcliffe. Jenny is the founder and director of Human Factor Security and is commonly known as the People Hacker. She’s a world-renowned social engineer hired to bypass security systems through a no-tech mixture of psychology, con-artistry, cunning, and guile. 			<title>Child Exploitation with Dr. Deaneè Johnson</title>
			<itunes:title>Child Exploitation with Dr. Deaneè Johnson</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 19 May 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[ca3d30d7-86de-4787-ba24-95ea0ca72c5f]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/64]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Child exploitation is an incredibly sensitive and difficult topic. It is vital to understand what resources are available to help the victims find healing.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Dr. Deaneè Johnson. Dr. Johnson has been a key player in advancing the victim services field at the federal, state, and local levels for over twenty years. As an OVC Fellow, she has assisted with collaborating with the DOJ to identify a range of child exploitation programs available nationwide, illuminating the best practices. She was most recently the chief program officer at the National Center for Victims of Crime before building her own consulting business Ascent Connection and Consulting Solutions. She also serves on the National Steering Committee for the Vision 21 Linking Systems of Care for Children and Youth, the Advisory Board for Preparedness Without Paranoia, and the Charles County Board of Education Safety in Maryland.</span></p> <p><em><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you know or suspect child exploitation, sexual abuse, or any other kind of child victimization, contact the National Child Abuse Hotline at 1-800-422-4453. If you are looking for more resources as a victim of past child abuse, call Victim Connect at (855) 484-2846.</span></em></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Show Notes:</span></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:39] - Dr. Johnson began her interest in this field of child exploitation in 1999 as a volunteer mentor. During her undergrad courses, she was focused on child abuse.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:27] - After Dr. Johnson received her degree in Criminal Justice, she started her Master’s in Counseling. She counseled adolescent youth that were victim of sexual abuse.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:15] - Through her experience in counseling, Dr. Johnson felt that something was stirred inside her and she no longer felt that counseling was the direction she should take.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:13] - Deaneè was given the opportunity to build a forensic interviewing program in a rural community in Texas. She got her masters and transferred her focus to forensic interviewing but still didn’t understand her drive.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:19] - She put all her energy and education towards the children who were victimized sexually.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:28] - Throughout her experiences, Deaneè had a memory pop up and realized that she did not have memories from her childhood other than images from photos. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Child exploitation is an incredibly sensitive and difficult topic. It is vital to understand what resources are available to help the victims find healing.</p> <p>Today’s guest is Dr. Deaneè Johnson. Dr. Johnson has been a key player in advancing the victim services field at the federal, state, and local levels for over twenty years. As an OVC Fellow, she has assisted with collaborating with the DOJ to identify a range of child exploitation programs available nationwide, illuminating the best practices. She was most recently the chief program officer at the National Center for Victims of Crime before building her own consulting business Ascent Connection and Consulting Solutions. She also serves on the National Steering Committee for the Vision 21 Linking Systems of Care for Children and Youth, the Advisory Board for Preparedness Without Paranoia, and the Charles County Board of Education Safety in Maryland.</p> <p><em>If you know or suspect child exploitation, sexual abuse, or any other kind of child victimization, contact the National Child Abuse Hotline at 1-800-422-4453. If you are looking for more resources as a victim of past child abuse, call Victim Connect at (855) 484-2846.</em></p> <p>Show Notes:</p> <ul> <li>[1:39] - Dr. Johnson began her interest in this field of child exploitation in 1999 as a volunteer mentor. During her undergrad courses, she was focused on child abuse.</li> <li>[2:27] - After Dr. Johnson received her degree in Criminal Justice, she started her Master’s in Counseling. He is the CEO and chairman of Accelerated Intelligence which is an Amazon marketing and advertising agency. He shares his passion for Amazon in his course Amazon Mastery and is also a featured mentor at the Founder Institute. Shaahin has been highlighted in many publications including Newsweek, The New York Times, Chicago Tribune, and The New York Post.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Show Notes:</span></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:10] - Shaahin began in physical products while he was 16 years old. Amazon will take any product back 99% of the time. You want to try to buy when you can from Amazon themselves for that return policy and register for your warranty immediately on high ticket items.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:57] - Sometimes Amazon will refund you your money for your return without even requiring you to send the product back.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:12] - Unfortunately there are a lot of savvy scammers that are onto scamming third party sellers. Shaahin flipped the issue into an opportunity.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:57] - There’s a high cost to low price. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:51] - The terms of service on Amazon says that you cannot do anything to solicit reviews for your products. This can be done through discount clubs.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:26] - The problem in these online marketplaces is that unless everyone follows every single rule, sellers will need to do what others are doing in order to build a business.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:11] - There’s so little incentive to leave organic reviews. 			<itunes:title>Deep Fakes with Lonnie Waugh</itunes:title>

			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/62]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">A “deep fake” typically refers to a video that has been edited to replace the person in the original video with someone else, commonly a public figure in a way that makes the video look entirely authentic. These are time consuming to make but can be very convincing.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Lonnie Waugh. Lonnie is a web developer, software engineer, and deep fake creator. He has been doing deep fake videos for years with a sense of humor traditionally using the OneDuality on Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[0:56] - Lonnie describes what a deep fake is and what he does for his YouTube channel to make things humorous.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:52] - To accomplish this in the past, it was very extensive, but now can be done from home with the right equipment and software.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:37] - The process to create something like this is very time consuming and Lonnie describes a frustration with rendering something and going back to edit.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:32] - Lonnie outlines what this process looks like for him and why he chooses political conferences for a lot of his videos.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:30] - In addition to finding all the movements needed for the face he’s using to replace the original, Lonnie also does some pre-processing. This isn’t necessary but he explains why he chooses to take the time to do it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:02] - The software used to do this is open source but not yet available for Mac.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:18] - Because Lonnie has been doing this for so long, he knows what to look for to determine if the content is real or a deep fake, but points out that if you don’t know what to look for, it is easy to be fooled.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:27] - Lonnie and Chris describe some of the little nuances and indicators that Lonnie can notice.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:49] - Lonnie shares that he cannot monetize his YouTube channel because of the copyrighted content he uses so it is not worth his time to go back and fix some of the most minor indicators of it being fake.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:12] - Lighting also makes things challenging and Lonnie shares an experience with a music video director not consulting a professional.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:28] - Lonnie has created content for music videos and hopes to eventually create for commercials.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:38] - Discussing the technical aspects of the process, Lonnie describes how many frames a creator should use and how the AI recognizes faces.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:47] - There are different modes that creators can use.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:23] - Because of copyrights, there are challenges to deep fakes when using obvious original videos.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:21] - Politicians are typically in the public domain but celebrities and actors who have enough legal backing could find each video one by one and take them down. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:57] - For those who are not celebrities or political figures, there’s likely not enough video content available for a deep fake to be made of them. Lonnie says it can be done with photos but thousands of photos would be needed.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:51] - The quality of the video used is important as well.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:47] - There is an app that can take photos and video and replace faces. To Lonnie they look good but are obviously not real. Some people may be fooled by them, though.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:45] - At the moment it is not likely of someone creating a deep fake of someone with malicious intent unless there’s a lot of professionally done video content of them in all different kinds of lighting.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:38] - Lonnie and Chris discuss the amount of work involved in creating a convincing deep fake of the average Joe.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:29] - There is software that will use a single photo to impose onto a video but they are not convincing and are typically used for entertainment.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:40] - In regards to romance scams, Chris shares that this could eventually be something used to create video content.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:08] - Lonnie explains how another YouTuber has used clips to startle people.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:09] - There is a lot of thought being put into this in the political world and will potentially be legislated in the future.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:33] - While the technology can be abused, Lonnie has not yet seen it used in a dangerous way and says that the abuse of it is pretty predictable right now.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:11] - Lonnie references a recent legal case that may have abused this type of technology.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/oneduality/?hl=en"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">OneDuality on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC-bXtw0kSNhsb0JNuZQWF1g"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> OneDuality on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.tiktok.com/@oneduality"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">OneDuality on TikTok</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCNYrK4tc5i1-eL8TXesH2pg"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Schmoyoho on YouTube</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Data Destruction with Paul Katzoff</title>
			<itunes:title>Data Destruction with Paul Katzoff</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 28 Apr 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9e40662a-e61e-4dea-b8b8-0bb1e84eee6a]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/61]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In the past, deleting a file was considered safe data destruction. But we know that it only clears the pointer to the file and not the data itself. Today there are many options when it comes to destroying data even though some harddrives seem almost indestructible. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Paul Katzoff. Paul is the CEO of WhiteCanyon Software where they specialize in data erasure for businesses both corporate and government. These customers need secure data destruction that meets HIPAA and other compliance standards for harddrive and mobile device erasure.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[0:54] - Paul gives a background of himself and what WhiteCanyon Software is all about, starting back in 1995.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:02] - Data is becoming more and more important every year and Paul gives examples of current compliance legislation and standards.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:03] - Chris shares a story from years ago regarding purchasing used copiers, scanners, and other devices that unknowingly stored data.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:20] - Paul describes the data exposure that happened with this issue in 2011 as healthcare providers did not know their scanned documents were stored.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:32] - Regarding criminal activity using data on harddrives, Pail explains that more and more people are becoming a little more knowledgeable and on board with data destruction if needed but it hasn’t always been that way.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:39] - Paul describes what data destruction has looked like over the years including old technology like floppy disks and tapes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:32] - Physical destruction only goes so far and software erasure is crucial now.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:11] - When you click “delete,” your file is not actually deleted.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:35] - Paul lists multiple erasure patterns and how it worked until about 2013 to erase any device out there.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:21] - There are some new requirements in data destruction that Paul explains and how they have had to adjust to make sure everything is erased.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:29] - WhiteCanyon Software has been working in data destruction for 23 years.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:14] - The current Covid-19 pandemic has complicated data as employees were then working from home and sometimes on a home computer.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:24] - Paul lists the concerns of accessing work networks on their home computers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:26] - WhiteCanyon offers a product that corporations can send to their employees to click a link to erase their computer and then provides a QR code.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:33] - Regarding mobile devices and phones, your data is stored on that device even with an encryption reset. Paul describes concerns with encryption keys.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:21] - WhiteCanyon provides a certificate that everything has been destroyed. A lot of third party companies that wipe data especially from mobile devices can’t actually promise it’s completely erased.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:29] - One of the huge issues with data is once it leaves your facility sitting on a device, it can pop up a decade later.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:20] - Chris points out that data erasure is a “hard sell” for IT to bring forward to their company. Paul explains that it is certainly a cost because it doesn’t earn a company any money.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:59] - Paul explains what needs to be done to properly erase data on a nonworking drive.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:08] - If you would like to physically destroy a harddrive, Paul explains what he recommends. If you’d like it destroyed for you, there is a cost.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:35] - What most consumers can do for shredding home computers is search for companies that process second-hand computers and they have shredders on site.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:15] - Because harddrives hold so much, data destruction can take a lot of time. But if it is an SSD, it is far quicker to completely erase.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:50] - Chris and Paul discuss new devices that now hold data, including refrigerators.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:02] - WhiteCanyon offers two free downloads with the coupon code “homefree” to wipe a home computer or device. They offer this because they know everyone has several old computers or devices holed away that could be useful elsewhere.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:39] - Paul points out that data recovery software is free online so if data is not properly destroyed, it can be recovered by whoever has your harddrive.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:30] - Although we still store data on devices, network storage is extremely popular which makes things easier regarding data destruction for some consumers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:04] - Paul strongly recommends pushing for harsher legislation for data protection and explains why this is crucial.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Paul describes the data exposure that happened with this issue in 2011 as healthcare providers did not know their scanned documents were stored.</li> <li>[5:32] - Regarding criminal activity using data on harddrives, Pail explains that more and more people are becoming a little more knowledgeable and on board with data destruction if needed but it hasn’t always been that way.</li> <li>[6:39] - Paul describes what data destruction has looked like over the years including old technology like floppy disks and tapes.</li> <li>[7:32] - Physical destruction only goes so far and software erasure is crucial now.</li> <li>[8:11] - When you click “delete,” your file is not actually deleted.</li> <li>[9:35] - Paul lists multiple erasure patterns and how it worked until about 2013 to erase any device out there.</li> <li>[10:21] - There are some new requirements in data destruction that Paul explains and how they have had to adjust to make sure everything is erased.</li> <li>[12:29] - WhiteCanyon Software has been working in data destruction for 23 years.</li> <li>[13:14] - The current Covid-19 pandemic has complicated data as employees were then working from home and sometimes on a home computer.</li> <li>[14:24] - Paul lists the concerns of accessing work networks on their home computers.</li> <li>[15:26] - WhiteCanyon offers a product that corporations can send to their employees to click a link to erase their computer and then provides a QR code.</li> <li>[16:33] - Regarding mobile devices and phones, your data is stored on that device even with an encryption reset. Paul describes concerns with encryption keys.</li> <li>[18:21] - WhiteCanyon provides a certificate that everything has been destroyed. A lot of third party companies that wipe data especially from mobile devices can’t actually promise it’s completely erased.</li> <li>[19:29] - One of the huge issues with data is once it leaves your facility sitting on a device, it can pop up a decade later.</li> <li>[20:20] - Chris points out that data erasure is a “hard sell” for IT to bring forward to their company. Paul explains that it is certainly a cost because it doesn’t earn a company any money.</li> <li>[21:59] - Paul explains what needs to be done to properly erase data on a nonworking drive.</li> <li>[23:08] - If you would like to physically destroy a harddrive, Paul explains what he recommends. If you’d like it destroyed for you, there is a cost.</li> <li>[24:35] - What most consumers can do for shredding home computers is search for companies that process second-hand computers and they have shredders on site.</li> <li>[26:15] - Because harddrives hold so much, data destruction can take a lot of time. But if it is an SSD, it is far quicker to completely erase.</li> <li>[27:50] - Chris and Paul discuss new devices that now hold data, including refrigerators.</li> <li>[29:02] - WhiteCanyon offers two free downloads with the coupon code “homefree” to wipe a home computer or device. They offer this because they know everyone has several old computers or devices holed away that could be useful elsewhere.</li> <li>[30:39] - Paul points out that data recovery software is free online so if data is not properly destroyed, it can be recovered by whoever has your harddrive.</li> <li>[31:30] - Although we still store data on devices, network storage is extremely popular which makes things easier regarding data destruction for some consumers.</li> <li>[32:04] - Paul strongly recommends pushing for harsher legislation for data protection and explains why this is crucial.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><em><a href= "https://www.whitecanyon.com/home-products/wipedrive">WipeDrive Home Edition Free with Coupon Code “HOMEFREE”</a></em></li> <li><a href="https://www.whitecanyon.com/">WhiteCanyon Home Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/paulkatzoff/">Paul Katzoff on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/paulkatzoff?lang=en">Paul Katzoff on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/WhiteCanyon">WhiteCanyon on Twitter</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Hacking with Alissa Valentina Knight</title>
			<itunes:title>Hacking with Alissa Valentina Knight</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 21 Apr 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[cf1ce3e1-aded-4c39-81a4-177577e2e700]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/60]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gifted hackers can access data from a government website, a hospital medical system, or even a car. Most are not aware when their personal information is stolen, sold, and used until it is too late. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Alissa Knight. Alissa is a recovering hacker of 20 years, a cyber security influencer, content creator, and the principal cyber security analyst at</span> <a href= "https://www.alissaknight.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alissa Knight and Associates</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. She is the author of the recently released book</span> <a href= "https://www.alissaknight.com/books"><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Hacking Connected Cars</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alissa has been quoted in articles by Brian Krebs and featured in numerous magazine articles including PC Magazine, Wired, and Forbes.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:01] - Alissa shares how she started hacking at the age of 13 and she got caught hacking a government network. They came to arrest her at school.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:27] - After this experience, Alissa later went on to own a few startups and sold them for millions of dollars.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:44] - Alissa explains her combat training when owning a defense contracting company. She then transitioned back into cyber security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:10] - Her company shifted from defense contracting to private sector cyber security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:06] - While living in Germany, Alissa got into hacking connected cars.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:07] - Although Alissa knows the risks of having connected technology, she is definitely a consumer of connected devices.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:55] - We are seeing a fundamental change in cybersecurity because now it isn’t just about information. It can literally be life or death.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:02] - Alissa loves cinematography and combines her knowledge of hacking and content creation.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:17] - Cybersecurity can be boring and uninteresting. Alissa states that she got tired of seeing the same white papers and changed it up to make it more interesting not just for her but for clients as well.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:22] - Alissa references a book called Blue Ocean Strategy and summarizes its content in relation to her business model and content.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:58] - “A lot of the content out there for security is told through the eyes of a blue team member. It’s told through the eyes of the defender. Very rarely do we see content being told through the eyes of the adversary.”</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:13] - Alissa describes what she wants people to see through her content.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:58] - In Alissa’s opinion, we need to relearn the concept of prevention.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:27] - Chris points out that many mistakes are made when people think they have an impenetrable system. They become complacent.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:20] - There are so many products out there right now that become very overwhelming and many don’t know what to choose or buy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:17] - Alissa breaks down the categories of mHealth and describes how she was able to hack into them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:59] - When testing these systems through hacking, Alissa was shocked at how much information she was able to access about patients.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:01] - Alissa explains the rule that CMS passed called FHIR.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:36] - Describing the systems that hospital systems use, Alissa points out some issues with lack of security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:48] - Alissa shares a personal story about being diagnosed with cancer and the experience of getting an email with her medical data available through a mobile app.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:21] - The average person is not digging deep to find where their information could have been published on the darkweb.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:54] - Alissa explains the differences between what some providers can and cannot do with data. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:41] - To explain a BOLA vulnerability, Alissa uses an easy to visualize analogy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:58] - Some of the problems in the APIs that Alissa is testing is insecure coding and programming. She lists how this can see patient health information in medical systems.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:13] - Simply changing an ID slightly once it has been authenticated is the number 1 vulnerability in APIs. Alissa says it's the easiest hack in the world.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:08] - Sharing a story about an experience with a pen tester, Chris demonstrates how important testing for vulnerabilities is.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[38:16] - We as consumers have to rely on manufacturers to make more secure cars and our healthcare providers to create more secure programs. It’s unfortunately out of our hands.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[39:54] - It is not an immediate thing to learn. Alissa points out the many tools and the importance of understanding them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[42:16] - Exploits and these penetration testing tools are important, but if they are in the wrong hands they can be used for different purposes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[43:32] - When the developer is responsible for data, it leads to many problems. Alissa describes what can happen.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[46:19] - Alissa explains what she predicts what she thinks will happen in the future.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[47:28] - “I think zero trust should have been the foundational elements of the building blocks from the beginning.”</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[49:37] - There is a lot of amazing technology coming from Tel Aviv which is a shift from the past.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCejZj1i5m_UlwPqu_7IqBwQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Alissa Knight on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.alissaknight.com/"><span style= LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/alissaknight"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alissa Knight on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.alissaknight.com/books"><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Hacking Connected Cats: Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures</span></em> <span style="font-weight: 400;">by Alissa Knight</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>How to Spot a Liar with Pamela Meyer</title>
			<itunes:title>How to Spot a Liar with Pamela Meyer</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 14 Apr 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[5a08c614-fcfb-4298-b19c-9bca2f4cfcbd]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/59]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Not all lies are scams, but everyone lies, even if it's only about someone’s birthday gift. Liars give out both verbal and nonverbal cues, but how do you know what they are? Listen to this episode to learn how to spot a lie.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Pamela Meyer. Pamela is certified fraud examiner, international speaker, entrepreneur, and the author of</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Liespotting-Proven-Techniques-Detect-Deception/dp/0312611730"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lie Spotting: Proven Techniques to Detect Deception</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">Her TEDtalk “How to Spot a Liar” is one of the 15 most popular TEDtalks of all time with over 30 million views. She has been featured on NPR, CNN, ABC, Forbes, The Washington Post, and The New York Post, and she writes regularly for The Huffington Post. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:03] - Pamela’s background is in business and for many years she was in media. She had developed some websites and sold them. She shared how a Harvard Business School reunion sparked her interest in deception.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:41] - When Pamela returned home from the reunion, she realized that there was a huge interest in the topic of deception but that the information on it was inaccessible.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:31] - Pamela shares the story that is also featured in her book</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Liespotting-Proven-Techniques-Detect-Deception/dp/0312611730"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Lie Spotting</span></em></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, about an assistant she had many years ago.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:56] - Just because it is taught in the CIA, doesn’t mean it can’t be learned by the public.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:23] - The myth of lie detection is that it is simple. It is actually quite complex.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:02] - Pamela shares another myth regarding lie detection through the eyes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:10] - When someone is lying, sometimes people will try to overcompensate their body language to appear truthful.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:20] - What’s important with lie detection is starting with baselining. One indicator doesn’t mean anything and Pamela describes why.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:02] - If you know someone very well and you notice that something is a little off, it could be an indicator for lying. Pamela explains that someone trained in detection will be able to note exactly what is off.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:52] - Professionals can usually determine a baseline for someone and detect lies within a half hour, 15 minutes, or even 5 minutes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:56] - If you are having a difficult conversation, what you’re looking for are energetic changes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:53] - Pamela begins sharing a good starting point called BASIC in learning detection which is a 5 step process. This is different from the advanced masterclass she offers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:03] - The first step is B for Baselining. A is for Ask open ended questions.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:07] - Be warm and be in an environment that is free from distraction. Sit in a non-threatening way and make the person feel comfortable.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:47] - Be authentic with building rapport with someone. Prepare for harder conversations ahead of time.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:39] - The biggest issue with cues to verbal and nonverbal deceit is what we call Cognitive Load. When you’re trying to think what to say, act composed, appear spontaneous, if you are lying you leak verbal and nonverbal cues.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:03] - Pamela shares some nonverbal cues that someone who is lying could adopt when in conversation with you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:37] - The verbal cues in a difficult conversation could be pushing the main point of conversation off to the end. Someone who is truthful will typically tell a story with a beginning, middle, and an end. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:29] - Pamela describes some verbal cues that could mean deception.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:40] - These methods are not weapons. They’re just techniques to help you get to the truth. Deception isn’t always indicative of something bad.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:22] - Everyone lies. Although the term “lying” has a negative connotation.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:01] - S in BASIC is “Study the clusters.” Look at the cues and study them. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Not all lies are scams, but everyone lies, even if it's only about someone’s birthday gift. Liars give out both verbal and nonverbal cues, but how do you know what they are? Listen to this episode to learn how to spot a lie.</p> <p>Today’s guest is Pamela Meyer. Pamela is certified fraud examiner, international speaker, entrepreneur, and the author of <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Liespotting-Proven-Techniques-Detect-Deception/dp/0312611730"> <em>Lie Spotting: Proven Techniques to Detect Deception</em></a><em>.</em> Her TEDtalk “How to Spot a Liar” is one of the 15 most popular TEDtalks of all time with over 30 million views. She has been featured on NPR, CNN, ABC, Forbes, The Washington Post, and The New York Post, and she writes regularly for The Huffington Post. </p> Show Notes: <ul> <li>[1:03] - Pamela’s background is in business and for many years she was in media. She had developed some websites and sold them. She shared how a Harvard Business School reunion sparked her interest in deception.</li> <li>[2:41] - When Pamela returned home from the reunion, she realized that there was a huge interest in the topic of deception but that the information on it was inaccessible.</li> <li>[3:31] - Pamela shares the story that is also featured in her book <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Liespotting-Proven-Techniques-Detect-Deception/dp/0312611730"> <em>Lie Spotting</em></a>, about an assistant she had many years ago.</li> <li>[4:56] - Just because it is taught in the CIA, doesn’t mean it can’t be learned by the public.</li> <li>[5:23] - The myth of lie detection is that it is simple. It is actually quite complex.</li> <li>[6:02] - Pamela shares another myth regarding lie detection through the eyes.</li> <li>[7:10] - When someone is lying, sometimes people will try to overcompensate their body language to appear truthful.</li> <li>[8:20] - What’s important with lie detection is starting with baselining. One indicator doesn’t mean anything and Pamela describes why.</li> <li>[10:02] - If you know someone very well and you notice that something is a little off, it could be an indicator for lying. Pamela explains that someone trained in detection will be able to note exactly what is off.</li> <li>[10:52] - Professionals can usually determine a baseline for someone and detect lies within a half hour, 15 minutes, or even 5 minutes.</li> <li>[11:56] - If you are having a difficult conversation, what you’re looking for are energetic changes.</li> <li>[12:53] - Pamela begins sharing a good starting point called BASIC in learning detection which is a 5 step process. This is different from the advanced masterclass she offers.</li> <li>[13:03] - The first step is B for Baselining. A is for Ask open ended questions.</li> <li>[14:07] - Be warm and be in an environment that is free from distraction. Sit in a non-threatening way and make the person feel comfortable.</li> <li>[15:47] - Be authentic with building rapport with someone. Prepare for harder conversations ahead of time.</li> <li>[17:39] - The biggest issue with cues to verbal and nonverbal deceit is what we call Cognitive Load. When you’re trying to think what to say, act composed, appear spontaneous, if you are lying you leak verbal and nonverbal cues.</li> <li>[19:03] - Pamela shares some nonverbal cues that someone who is lying could adopt when in conversation with you.</li> <li>[20:37] - The verbal cues in a difficult conversation could be pushing the main point of conversation off to the end. Someone who is truthful will typically tell a story with a beginning, middle, and an end. </li> <li>[21:29] - Pamela describes some verbal cues that could mean deception.</li> <li>[22:40] - These methods are not weapons. They’re just techniques to help you get to the truth. Deception isn’t always indicative of something bad.</li> <li>[24:22] - Everyone lies. Although the term “lying” has a negative connotation.</li> <li>[25:01] - S in BASIC is “Study the clusters.” Look at the cues and study them. I is for “Intuiting the gaps.” Keep your instincts in mind and identify and fill in the holes.</li> <li>[26:37] - Pamela describes behavior gaps and emotion gaps. What is the person saying and are they flashing contradictory facial expressions or body movements?</li> <li>[28:10] - These indicators are not to point fingers and call the person a liar. They are to give you more information and give you guidance on the harder questions to ask.</li> <li>[28:32] - C is to confirm. After you’ve done everything prior, you need to now ask the questions that will confirm your thoughts of deceit. These questions often indicate that you have some information that you might not have.</li> <li>[30:18] - Pamela gives some examples of what a truthful person will say to answer these questions and what a deceitful person will say.</li> <li>[31:17] - You don’t always have to use these questions and in most cases you won’t need to. But Pamela has several that she keeps in her back pocket in the event that she needs more.</li> <li>[32:09] - A good interrogator or interviewer is prepared. If you are an artful interviewer, you will be prepared with tons of questions to determine that Cognitive Load.</li> <li>[33:13] - To answer the question of “can you teach me to lie?” Pamela says no because anyone who is really talented at interrogation will be able to detect deception.</li> <li>[34:07] - We all have biases and blindspots. So we are not completely immune to being conned or lied to.</li> <li>[34:57] - We are past polygraph tests these days. There is a lot of technology out there to detect deception. It can’t be used in all settings but it's available.</li> <li>[37:34] - There is a lot of technology that is effective and some that is not. Pamela gives some examples of studies that are going on currently.</li> <li>[39:08] - Chris and Pamela discuss the problem of cyberthreats and not knowing the baseline of someone. This also applies to AI algorithms. </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="http://liespotting.com/">Lie Spotting Home Page</a></li> <li><em><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Liespotting-Proven-Techniques-Detect-Deception/dp/0312611730"> Lie Spotting: Proven Techniques to Detect Deception by Pamela Meyer</a></em></li> <li><a href= "https://www.ted.com/speakers/pamela_meyer"> Pamela Meyer on TED.com</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/pamela_meyer">Pamela Meyer on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/pamelameyer/detail/recent-activity/posts/"> Pamela Meyer on LinkedIn</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Influencer Marketing with Neal Schaffer</title>
			<itunes:title>Influencer Marketing with Neal Schaffer</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 07 Apr 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[4057e235-5652-4f7a-b743-bf39e47d5865]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Not all social media influencers are equal. Just because someone has a ton of followers doesn’t mean they actually have any influence on their audience. It’s important that we learn to be critical thinkers that do research and not just believe what we hear and read. Whether you’re a business looking to use an influencer to promote your product, or you’re interested in becoming an influencer yourself, this is the episode for you.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Neal Schaffer. Neal is an authority on helping innovative businesses digitally transform their sales and marketing. He’s the founder of the digital marketing consultancy PDCA Social and currently serves as a fractional CMO to several companies. He teaches at Rutgers Business School and the Irish Management Institute and is fluent in Japanese and Mandarin Chinese. Neal is a popular keynote speaker internationally and has also authored four sales and marketing books including his latest,</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Age-Influence-Power-Influencers-Elevate/dp/1400216362/ref=as_li_ss_tl?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=&linkCode=sl1&tag=windminetwor-20&linkId=241999fadb26f6bc02547da69ae16ee6&language=en_US"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Age of Influence</span></em></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:34] - Neal shares his background and how he began working with social media influencers around 2017.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:29] - It is a huge industry with a lot of money being thrown at it and it is very easy to dupe people.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:55] - Neal shares the statistic that there’s more than a billion dollars in fraud in the industry.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:15] - There’s no real way to tell if someone’s followers and engagement are real or fake because you don’t have access to their account. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:03] - Influencers have to deliver. Neal explains how social media really works and what questions he asks when looking deeply at influencer profiles.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:30] - People have to be smart enough and to have a critical mind and analyze what they see. Don’t take anything at face value.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:37] - Neal compares looking into a social media influencer or someone who seems to be an influencer to shopping on Amazon.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:30] - The book</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Age-Influence-Power-Influencers-Elevate/dp/1400216362/ref=as_li_ss_tl?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=&linkCode=sl1&tag=windminetwor-20&linkId=241999fadb26f6bc02547da69ae16ee6&language=en_US"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Age of Influence</span></em></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">by Neal Schaffer answers a lot of questions for business owners looking to potentially hire an influencer.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:09] - Neal describes how influencer marketing works and what a lot of business owners assume it is like.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:21] - If you are going to reach out to someone to promote your product, ask them honestly if they’ve used your product. If they don’t care about your product, why would you want them to promote it? Reach out to the right people.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:39] - Chris shares “influencer fails.” If you treat an influencer like you are hiring them for a project with specific details and restrictions, the worse and less genuine the content is going to be.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:29] - Influencers can create better content that any business so restricting them is counterproductive.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:41] - When it is a cut and paste, people can see that. You would be introducing a foreign element into their community.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:51] - Neal and Chris discuss government involvement in influencer marketing and the potential future in regulations.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:52] - Neal shares that as a content creator himself, he has been approached by businesses who say they want to work with him but they do not want him to use the term “sponsored.”</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:47] - Disclosures are required but the post can still be genuine.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:31] - Neal suggests some ways to engage with and develop genuine relationships with influencers that will help in the long run.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:42] - Good influencers turn down the sponsorships and product promotions that don’t make sense for their own brand.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:49] - Becoming an influencer is a long haul. Becoming more influential as a side hustle is more realistic. You’re not going to become a millionaire overnight. Because it is a long haul, it needs to be something you are passionate about.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:14] - Because you are passionate about your niche, you draw people who are also passionate about it and over time you will influence them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:46] - As an influencer, keep a short list of brands that you would love to have sponsor you and work to keep your passion clear to draw the followers that will connect with you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:26] - There’s no shortcut to the process of becoming an influencer. It is hard work but with strategy it can happen.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:50] - There are going to be people that push back. Part of building fans is standing up for your niche. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:04] - Your profile is your space. If someone is invading your space with negative comments, it is totally okay to delete and block. Your community will likely support you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:48] - Neal tells a story about a game he plays on his phone and how it is similar to taking care of your community of followers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:26] - If you are a business owner, influencers are an excellent opportunity. If you are a consumer, treat influencers like Amazon product reviews. If you want to become an influencer, don’t do it for the money. Do it for the passion.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://nealschaffer.com/"><span style= "font-weight: <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Age of Influence</span></em> <span style="font-weight: 400;">by Neal Schaffer</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/nealschaffer"><span style= Your community will likely support you.</li> <li>[27:48] - Neal tells a story about a game he plays on his phone and how it is similar to taking care of your community of followers.</li> <li>[29:26] - If you are a business owner, influencers are an excellent opportunity. If you are a consumer, treat influencers like Amazon product reviews. If you want to become an influencer, don’t do it for the money. Do it for the passion.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="https://nealschaffer.com/">Neal Schaffer Home Page</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Age-Influence-Power-Influencers-Elevate/dp/1400216362/ref=as_li_ss_tl?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=&linkCode=sl1&tag=windminetwor-20&linkId=241999fadb26f6bc02547da69ae16ee6&language=en_US"> <em>The Age of Influence</em> by Neal Schaffer</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/nealschaffer">Neal Schaffer on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/nealschaffer/"> Neal Schaffer on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.instagram.com/nealschaffer/">Neal Schaffer on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/NealSchafferPage/">Neal Schaffer on Facebook</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Pet Scams with Brandi Hunter</title>
			<itunes:title>Pet Scams with Brandi Hunter</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 31 Mar 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[8ad7e926-7297-428e-83bc-d178b3b8d778]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/57]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pets are one way to get to someone’s heart and their wallet. Purchasing a dog is an investment that scammers can try to manipulate for their own advantage.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Brandi Hunter. Brandi has been in public relations and communications for over 15 years. The past five years she has been working for the American Kennel Club commonly known as the AKC. The AKC is over 135 years old and the largest pure-bred registry in the United States. The AKC is passionate about all breeds of dogs, their sports, and their safety. Brandi shares many different resources that are available and scams to watch out for.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[0:54] - Brandi shares some background on herself working in communications and the background of the AKC.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:48] - AKC’s mission is to protect all dogs and make sure they have the happiest and healthiest life possible.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:11] - The first thing you need to do before purchasing a pet, you need to assess your life and look at your lifestyle and household to make sure you can.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:45] - Brandi also recommends you take a moment to discover if rescuing is what you should do or if you should go through a breeder.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:07] - If going through a breeder, you need to make sure you are going through a reputable source. AKC has a marketplace that has a compliance program that Brandi describes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:02] - Brandi says to research breeds as well to make sure that their traits and typical behaviors make sense for your lifestyle.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:10] - Be careful if you are on a website for a breeder. Double check by calling the AKC to see if they are registered. Brandi says that it is easy for someone to copy and paste a logo or make a website a scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:12] - Chris shares his story in searching for a Mini Schnauzer.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:01] - Brandi explains how some breeds are not good for first time dog owners.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:02] - Chris and his wife found a breeder near a family member’s home. His family member trains service dogs and decided to have her go look at the dog and breeder, the breeder completely stopped communicating.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:35] - Responsible breeders want to meet you and make sure the dog is going to a good home.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:53] - In every case Brandi has ever seen with responsible breeders, the breeder will say to bring the dog back if it is not the right fit. This reduces surrender.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:57] - When Chris and his wife found the right breeder, he described the difference in experience. She was very communicative and cared about the dog.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:01] - Nobody that is intentionally breeding wants their dogs to end up in shelters. That’s not why you put the work in. Breeding is a lot of work.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:34] - A puppy mill is not a term the AKC uses because they do not encourage the practice. But it is when someone breeds irresponsibility in mass after receiving money.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:58] - Puppy mills and backyard breeders do not do health checks because they are only concerned about earning money.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:02] - Breeding this irresponsibly is unscrupulous and completely unhealthy for the parents and the puppies. When this happens you can usually tell based on looks and behavior.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:08] - A red flag will also be exorbitant prices and the breeder telling you that the puppy is exotic.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:02] - Another sign to watch out for is that the breeder doesn’t ask you any questions to make sure the dog is going to a good home. They only want to know that you can pay for it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:56] - When paying for a dog, Brandi says do not use Western Union or other methods of wiring money that you cannot trace. Use your credit card because you can report fraud.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:33] - Another red flag is that a scammer will ask for money right away. That is the first thing they will talk about.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:19] - Brandi lists some other red flags including refusal to provide papers and bad grammar on websites.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:47] - When contacting a phone number on a website, always call. Numbers that you can’t call but you can receive texts from is another red flag.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:59] - Brandi recommends to reverse look-up a photo to see if it is a stock photo used elsewhere or to copy and paste testimonials from their website into Google.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:40] - There will be no financial surprises with a reputable breeder. Brandi lists some ways scammers and irresponsible breeders will spring additional fees.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:34] - Responsible breeders will work with a contract. They will have a copy and you will have one.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:56] - Pricing a dog is at the discretion of the breeder, not the AKC. It is random and arbitrary so there will be no hidden costs that pop up.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:50] - Brandi describes a common lost dog scam. It tugs on the emotion of the pet owner.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:10] - You should always have your dog microchipped or have tags on your dog in the event they get lost. If someone calls and claims to have your dog, they need to send you a picture of the tags.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:47] - Pay attention to what they’re saying and to what they’re not saying. This is good advice for someone who claimed to find your dog or a breeder you are in contact with to purchase.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:09] - A legitimate person is only concerned with reuniting you with your dog. They should get the reward money only when the dog is returned, not before.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:33] - “Do your research. We know that puppies are an impulsive buying decision. The minute that warm little nose touches your cheek, it’s over for any straightforward thought you’re thinking. But the desire for the pet should never outweigh your logic.” - Brandi Hunter</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:41] - If a pet store or a shelter is doing it right, they are protecting the animal. Take the right path for you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:23] - There is a wealth of information on AKC’s website, including quizzes, articles, and videos to help plan.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "https://akc.tv/?utm_source=ncsmartlink&utm_medium=smartlink"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> AKCtv</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/AmericanKennelClub/"><span style= <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/americankennelclub/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">American Kennel Club on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href=
