		<item>
			<title>Deception Detection with Abby Ellin</title>
			<itunes:title>Deception Detection with Abby Ellin</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 24 Mar 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[aced03dc-ffa4-4051-a1ea-2d7d8cf1e973]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/56]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many assume that dating scams only take place online. A scenario where they create an emotional connection over a period of time and eventually start asking for money. Today, we talk with someone who was deceived in person and how to see the warning signs in real life.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Abby Ellin. Abby has been a freelance writer for 20 years. She has mostly written for The New York Times but has been published in countless other publications including Time and The London Daily Telegraph. Abby’s latest book</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Duped: Double Lives, False Identities, and the Con Man I Almost Married</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">was published in 2019 and is the topic of today’s discussion.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:14] - The reason Chris wanted Abby on the podcast was because Abby’s experience is different from the more common online dating scams.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:40] - Very briefly, Abby was engaged to a man who turned out to be a pathological liar. She felt something was off and left him within a year. But later she got a phone call.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:14] - It turned out that the man was using Abby’s name to write prescriptions for drugs. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:40] - Abby jumped into journalist mode and interviewed the people in the man’s life who he had also been deceiving.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:17] - Abby explains the true things that were not deceptions: he had been a doctor in the Navy and was from Jacksonville, Florida.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:42] - When he didn’t want Abby coming to Jacksonville with him it was because he was engaged to another woman who he lived with there. He would tell the other woman he was on a secret mission and would leave for long periods of time.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:25] - Nothing was verifiable which drove the journalist side of Abby nuts.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:14] - Abby initially met him during an interview. She was interviewing him as a doctor and when fact checking he shared that he was opening up a facility in Iraq and Afghanistan for kids with cancer. They kept in touch because of the story she could write.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:25] - Abby describes his pattern starting with marrying someone, leaving them, and moving to another marriage.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:07] - It wasn’t just “love fraud,” it was a real con. He was using names of people he had been with romantically as well as names of the people he worked with to get drugs for himself.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:58] - Abby was suspicious and left him after a year. She shares a story about a time he lied to her parents so convincingly and it made her concerned about other possible lies.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:17] - Some red flags Abby noticed were that he would always cancel plans last minute and unusual things would happen when she was out of town.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:15] - Chris and Abby discuss how people use the claim of being in the military as their adopted persona because we don’t tend to question that. But the man she was engaged to was in fact in the military.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:10] - He was a military doctor and you don’t ever expect someone in that kind of position to be a “bad egg.”</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:19] - Abby explains that he was caught for using drugs but he had gotten a hold of so much that she is also convinced that he was selling.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:40] - For online scams, the goal is to receive money and the manipulation is a means to an end. For some in person scams, sometimes the manipulation is part of the goal, too.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:51] - Because Abby had been suspicious and was not forthcoming about financial information, she did not lose any money. She says that if that had been his goal with her, she was a failed scam. But he did ask a few times about finances.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:47] - When asked about trust, Abby explains that we are programmed to trust and that society will not function without it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:53] - Those gut feelings, intuition, or what Abby calls the “Spidey-sense,” can be right. Listen to your gut.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:34] - Abby shares a story about a woman she just recently started seeing and how her gut feeling was actually wrong. She had been projecting her baggage to someone else’s scenario.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:03] - When you see a photo of someone on a dating app who is in a military uniform, it is a scam. People who are truly in the military won’t be using a photo like that for their profile.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:25] - There are some people who thrive on manipulating others. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Many assume that dating scams only take place online. A scenario where they create an emotional connection over a period of time and eventually start asking for money. Today, we talk with someone who was deceived in person and how to see the warning signs in real life.</p> <p>Today’s guest is Abby Ellin. Abby has been a freelance writer for 20 years. She has mostly written for The New York Times but has been published in countless other publications including Time and The London Daily Telegraph. Abby’s latest book <em>Duped: Double Lives, False Identities, and the Con Man I Almost Married</em> was published in 2019 and is the topic of today’s discussion.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li>[1:14] - The reason Chris wanted Abby on the podcast was because Abby’s experience is different from the more common online dating scams.</li> <li>[1:40] - Very briefly, Abby was engaged to a man who turned out to be a pathological liar. She felt something was off and left him within a year. But later she got a phone call.</li> <li>[2:14] - It turned out that the man was using Abby’s name to write prescriptions for drugs. </li> <li>[2:40] - Abby jumped into journalist mode and interviewed the people in the man’s life who he had also been deceiving.</li> <li>[4:17] - Abby explains the true things that were not deceptions: he had been a doctor in the Navy and was from Jacksonville, Florida.</li> <li>[4:42] - When he didn’t want Abby coming to Jacksonville with him it was because he was engaged to another woman who he lived with there. He would tell the other woman he was on a secret mission and would leave for long periods of time.</li> <li>[5:25] - Nothing was verifiable which drove the journalist side of Abby nuts.</li> <li>[6:14] - Abby initially met him during an interview. She was interviewing him as a doctor and when fact checking he shared that he was opening up a facility in Iraq and Afghanistan for kids with cancer. They kept in touch because of the story she could write.</li> <li>[7:25] - Abby describes his pattern starting with marrying someone, leaving them, and moving to another marriage.</li> <li>[8:07] - It wasn’t just “love fraud,” it was a real con. He was using names of people he had been with romantically as well as names of the people he worked with to get drugs for himself.</li> <li>[8:58] - Abby was suspicious and left him after a year. She shares a story about a time he lied to her parents so convincingly and it made her concerned about other possible lies.</li> <li>[10:17] - Some red flags Abby noticed were that he would always cancel plans last minute and unusual things would happen when she was out of town.</li> <li>[11:15] - Chris and Abby discuss how people use the claim of being in the military as their adopted persona because we don’t tend to question that. But the man she was engaged to was in fact in the military.</li> <li>[12:10] - He was a military doctor and you don’t ever expect someone in that kind of position to be a “bad egg.”</li> <li>[13:19] - Abby explains that he was caught for using drugs but he had gotten a hold of so much that she is also convinced that he was selling.</li> <li>[14:40] - For online scams, the goal is to receive money and the manipulation is a means to an end. For some in person scams, sometimes the manipulation is part of the goal, too.</li> <li>[15:51] - Because Abby had been suspicious and was not forthcoming about financial information, she did not lose any money. She says that if that had been his goal with her, she was a failed scam. But he did ask a few times about finances.</li> <li>[16:47] - When asked about trust, Abby explains that we are programmed to trust and that society will not function without it.</li> <li>[17:53] - Those gut feelings, intuition, or what Abby calls the “Spidey-sense,” can be right. Listen to your gut.</li> <li>[19:34] - Abby shares a story about a woman she just recently started seeing and how her gut feeling was actually wrong. She had been projecting her baggage to someone else’s scenario.</li> <li>[22:03] - When you see a photo of someone on a dating app who is in a military uniform, it is a scam. People who are truly in the military won’t be using a photo like that for their profile.</li> <li>[23:25] - There are some people who thrive on manipulating others. If the goal is to dupe someone for money, Abby thinks that scamming a freelance journalist was not the best plan for that goal.</li> <li>[24:58] - Abby shares that she called a scammer back one time just to see what would happen.</li> <li>[26:01] - Chris describes how sophisticated scams have gotten.</li> <li>[26:55] - The minute someone asks for money, that should be the end of the conversation.</li> <li>[28:01] - It is really hard to deal with an in-person situation like Abby was involved in because you have met them and you do have a relationship with them rather than an online dating scam where you don’t meet them in person.</li> <li>[28:58] - You need to know what someone’s baseline is. There is not a specific set of behaviors that indicate someone is lying. Everyone is different so take notice of things that are out of the ordinary for them.</li> <li>[29:44] - Abby discusses polygraph tests and how she needs to have hard evidence.</li> <li>[31:33] - In Abby’s situation, the man she was engaged to had duped his entire family.</li> <li>[33:02] - It became so much a problem for him, that lying became his default. </li> <li>[34:29] - Abby shares a story about another red flag about their living situation. She caught him in a lie and she is convinced he believed his own lies.</li> <li>[37:05] - Abby will be starting a podcast to share more details of her experience soon.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><em><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Duped-Double-Identities-Almost-Married/dp/1610398009"> Duped: Double Lives, False Identities, and the Con Man I Almost Married by Abby Ellin</a></em></li> <li><a href="https://www.abbyellin.com/">Abby Ellin Author and Journalist Home Page</a></li> <li><a href= "https://twitter.com/abbyellin?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> Abby Ellin on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/abbyellin/">Abby Ellin on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/abbyellinauthor/"> Abby Ellin on Facebook</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Ethical Hacking with Brian Self</title>
			<itunes:title>Ethical Hacking with Brian Self</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 17 Mar 2021 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[941c41a3-1a35-4fb2-8948-9d6fcd65b669]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/55]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ethical hacking may seem like an oxymoron, but having someone that you trust do a penetration test on your network may shock you. Our guest today has been helping people for 20 years to know when they’re vulnerable, and he shares his stories and insights to help you keep your information secure.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Brian Self. Brian is a certified Information Systems Security professional, ethical hacker, and professional speaker. He has the unique ability to take a complicated topic like network security and make it easy for a wide audience to understand. He has been in Information Security for over 15 years and in IT for over 20. He is a professional penetration tester doing offensive security, a compliance subject matter expert, an IT security architect, a security engineer, and a consultant in a variety of security domains.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:10] - Brian shares his background and how he got into the field of IT and security including the story that inspired him to get into ethical hacking.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:34] -In 15 minutes, a penetration tester taught Brian more about the system he was using than he ever knew was there. He was hooked from then on.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:37] - Brian defines some common hacking terminology in easy-to-understand verbiage.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:12] - In Brian’s experience, many people tell him that they don’t have anything of value that a hacker would want. He clarifies that everyone has something that can make them a target, including things you just don’t think of as a vulnerability.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:01] - In addition to white hat, gray hat, and black hat hackers, Brian explains the different teams of hackers called blue teams and red teams.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:43] - For penetration tests that Brian does, he doesn’t necessarily avoid getting caught.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:29] - Chris shares his experience with a penetration testing company and the surprise of what they found.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:52] - Brian confirms that Chris’s experience is very common. There are a lot of old systems in place that may have been secure when created but haven’t been updated.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:21] - Brian describes one of his very first pen tests and the ease of finding vulnerability.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:48] - For pen testers out there who are just starting, here’s a rule of thumb, never tell how you got in until you’re done. Brian explains why.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:58] - If you are approached by someone who claims to have found vulnerability, like a grey hat hacker, Brian advises to be very careful and to get a legal team involved.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:02] - Brian is motivated to help people understand security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:38] - Responsible disclosure is when a security researcher gives companies ample time to make changes to their vulnerability. Some security researchers disclose the information on social media.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:33] - Brian suggests starting with the basics first before hiring someone to do penetration testing. Are you patching? If not, patch first.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:04] - If you’re starting from scratch, you can plan for changes in security. Consider who needs access to certain data.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:21] - Chris describes the balance that needs to be found between automated systems and human error.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:01] - Brian started learning social engineering when he had to convince someone to send him to an event to learn more.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:10] - Brian highly recommends the</span> <a href="https://owasp.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">OWASP foundation</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">to continue learning about penetration testing and overall security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:14] - Chris admits that he has been nervous to attend conventions and explains his reasoning.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:15] - Chris references a</span> <a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/penetration-testing-and-ethical-hacking-with-ed-skoudis/"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">previous episode with Ed Skoudis</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">and an experience he had with the Holiday Hack Challenge.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:17] - Brian suggests taking classes, courses, and learning what you can. He says that if you take a course with Ed Skoudis, you are really learning.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:09] - In regards to risk, Brian keeps two main points - the likelihood and the impact.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:15] - Engage with the pen test team. Don’t wait to ask questions. Leverage them while you have their time and attention.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:55] - Make sure you have some proof from pen testers so you know how you fixed something without having to track down the pen testers later. You need a detailed report with priorities.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:13] - There are some companies that are now specializing in fixing risks. Brian is cautious of this because of an apparent conflict of interest.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:34] - It should be negotiated in your contract with a pen test to come back and retest.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[38:38] - Brian describes how he became burnt out with pen testing.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[40:00] - Many companies only hired pen test companies for compliance reasons. There are other companies who actually care about risk management. Brian explains that the types of testing he did varied due to the company’s reason.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[42:04] - What are the things that every security professional always tells people? Two-factor authorization is annoying but it is crucial.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[44:01] - Chris and Brian discuss SMS two-factor authorization. Brian explains that for most of us, it is enough. But for some, it isn’t.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[45:47] - Brian says that passwords need to be as complex as possible and at least 15 characters long.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[46:22] - Comparing two-factor authorization to a home break-in, Brian illustrates that something is better than nothing.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[48:16] - Do not use the same password on multiple accounts. You need to have extra security for the accounts that are of value.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[49:18] - If you’re not going to take the steps for everything, apply it where you really</span> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">need</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">to, like bank accounts.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[50:08] - Pen tests give companies a lot of assurance, but in a lot of cases it takes away assurance.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[51:04] - A lot of times, security becomes a chore for a lot of companies.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[52:30] - Brian shares a personal story of hackers contacting one of his clients in an attempt to gain access to her network.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[54:07] - One major suggestion that Brian makes to everyone is to block out automatic image loading in emails.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://brianselfspeaks.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Brian Self Speaks Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/brianselfcybersecurityspeaker/"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Brian Self on LinkedIn</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

You need to have extra security for the accounts that are of value.</li> <li>[49:18] - If you’re not going to take the steps for everything, apply it where you really <em>need</em> to, like bank accounts.</li> <li>[50:08] - Pen tests give companies a lot of assurance, but in a lot of cases it takes away assurance.</li> <li>[51:04] - A lot of times, security becomes a chore for a lot of companies.</li> <li>[52:30] - Brian shares a personal story of hackers contacting one of his clients in an attempt to gain access to her network.</li> <li>[54:07] - One major suggestion that Brian makes to everyone is to block out automatic image loading in emails.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="https://brianselfspeaks.com/">Brian Self Speaks Web Page</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/brianselfcybersecurityspeaker/"> Brian Self on LinkedIn</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Cyber Security for Seniors with Scott Schober</title>
			<itunes:title>Cyber Security for Seniors with Scott Schober</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 10 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0ec4beea-c641-49df-a9d3-18efb62f7612]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/54]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Seniors are prime targets for cyber crime because many of them have been preparing for retirement and have sizable savings. Their lack of familiarity with technology can set them up to be deceived or hacked. Scammers are going to elaborate lengths to hide their deception. It's important to be aware of their schemes.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Scott Schober. Scott is the CEO of Berkeley Varitronics Systems. As a cyber security and wireless technology expert, Scott has had regular appearances on Bloomberg TV, ABC, CBS, FOX News, Good Morning America, CNN, CNBC, and many more. Scott is the author of</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober/dp/099690221X"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hacked Again</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">,</span></em> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Cybersecurity-Everybodys-Business-Security-Puzzle/dp/0996902260"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Cyber Security is Everybody’s Business</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">,</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and his latest book, we’ll talk about today,</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Senior-Cyber-Security-Practices-Golden/dp/1736315803"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Senior Cyber</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></em></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:10] - Senior Cyber is a little different than Scott’s other books. Scott was inspired to write it as he has helped his parents and grandparents with technology.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:22] - As he was looking for resources for his parents and grandparents, he found that the books tended to talk down to the audience. It makes the audience feel intimidated.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:36] - Typically, seniors have a little bit more disposable income because they’re saving for retirement. It makes them targets of scams. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:09] - Scott points out that seniors also tend to be more innocent and naive when it comes to trusting hackers. Hackers can more easily use phishing attacks.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:41] - Chris and Scott discuss the familiarity gap between generations. Bringing in terms like cryptocurrency and bitcoin is a way that confuses older generations.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:23] - There are many seniors who have taken the time to learn, become comfortable with, and embrace technology including online bill pay and communication. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:27] - Scott shares how he has heard from some readers of his book who said that through reading the book, it opened younger family members up to helping older family members navigate online.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:18] - Chris shares an experience with a friend who’s father went missing which caused Chris to really start thinking about his own parents and led to a great conversation with them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:23] - Scott describes a similar story of his daughter seemingly going missing while on a trip many years ago. Technology didn’t enter their mind as a solution, but now it can be helpful in making sure others are safe.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:00] - Using his own father as an example, many seniors who have a brilliant mind, feel discouraged because they can’t always remember usernames, passwords, and processes to stay safe online.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:20] - Imagine someone who has never used computers, listening to current buzzwords like phishing attacks, encryption, ransomware, etc.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:01] - Making it clear that seniors are not inherently doing anything wrong, communicating cyber security strategies in a way that is relatable to them is key.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:53] - In his experience, Scott sees most seniors accessing the internet through a computer and typically have their passwords written down in plain view. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:10] - Doing some “house cleaning” when it comes to cyber security for the seniors in your life can be very helpful. Remove unused apps and clean out things that aren’t necessary.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:38] - Scott shares a story about a credit card expiring and cutting it up. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:14] - Sharing stories with others can have a larger impact on those you are helping than making them feel like they are being lectured.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:04] - Scott explains that the scams that impact the elderly the most are always tied to emotions. Recently, there have been scams surrounding vaccines.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:09] - If something sounds a little fishy, pause and ask the questions.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:39] - Phone calls and emails asking for information to put you on a list for a vaccine are rampant right now.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:59] - Because it is also tax season, there are a lot of tax scams going on. Remember that the IRS is not going to call you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:53] - Scott learns about a new scam every single day. It keeps changing and evolving. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:55] - When someone calls and volunteers a small amount of personal information about you asking for you to confirm the rest and tries to do so very quickly, those are red flags of a scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:37] - An older generation was taught to answer the phone because it is courteous while a younger generation may screen calls or prefer texts.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:56] - Even if a senior has a smartphone and attempts to screen calls, call spoofing is so easy for scammers to do. Scott shares how he tried it himself and demonstrates just how easy it is.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:40] - Scott points out that seniors are more likely to respond to calls which causes them to keep calling and probing for more information.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:42] - Scott shares a personal story about his grandfather becoming a victim to a scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:26] - Fortunately in the case of his grandfather, the cashier performing the wire transfers knew of a scam and asked questions.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:19] - Once a scam is successful, even more calls and emails will come to try to scam again.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:05] - Some scammers will also try to coach you to lie to cashiers or banks. That is a red flag. You shouldn’t have to lie to access your funds.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[39:47] - Chris shares that some people he has helped, especially if they are older, tend to think that they are personally targeted. But it is really that everyone is targeted and a lot of people get the same calls.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:18] - Scott describes how he was able to talk with a scammer and how when he got caught, he became extremely angry.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[43:59] - When Chris and Scott answer these calls and talk to scammers knowing what they are trying to do, they are at least gaining knowledge on how they operate.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[45:26] - Chris explains a newer scam called brushing in, which is when packages are delivered to you that you did not order to cause you to reach out and give information to get the package to the right person.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[47:53] - Scott’s book,</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Senior-Cyber-Security-Practices-Golden/dp/1736315803"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Senior Cyber</span></em></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, is available on Amazon and his website.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[49:24] - Throughout the book, there are “Senior Tips” that bullet point quick tips and facts that are easy to understand. There is also a senior workbook that is enjoyable and educational. You can reach out to Scott to receive one of those.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast style="font-weight: 400;"> Scott Schober on YouTube</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Ponzi Schemes with Steve Weisman</title>
			<itunes:title>Ponzi Schemes with Steve Weisman</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 03 Mar 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b261cf2e-7f83-4b38-a954-079176a32cab]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/53]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some believe Ponzi schemes are doomed to fail. But with a sophisticated schemer and a broad enough base of people, they might just be able to keep it going. In honor of Charles Ponzi’s birthday, we talk about the history of the Ponzi scheme and some of the amazing stories of how they’ve been exposed and ways to see them coming. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Steve Weisman. Steve is a nationally recognized expert in scams and identity theft as well as a lawyer, college professor, and prolific author. His informative speeches, articles, and books make difficult subjects not only understandable, but enjoyable with the humor he brings to these complex issues. Steve is passionate about educating people through his website</span> <a href= "https://scamicide.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Scamicide.com</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:16] - Steve has a personal backstory with a Ponzi scam because his father became the victim of one several years ago. His father was an astute businessman and the people involved with it seemed very honest.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:50] - Steve also became a victim of identity theft himself and then wanted to help others not have the same problem.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:29] - After WWI, Charles Ponzi came up with a plan to make money. Steve admits that it is very hard to explain and that is the key to a Ponzi scheme.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:45] - Schemers blamed their victims for falling for the scheme. They claimed that they deserved what happened because they weren’t smart enough.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:58] - Steve describes how Charles Ponzi used the money from investors and shares why a more recent scheme in 2008 was successful.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:46] - In the case of Charles Ponzi, law enforcement didn’t bring him down. The media did.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:29] - Ponzi did spend time in prison and was kicked out of the country. He went back to Italy and actually scammed Mussolini.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:04] - Ponzi was probably not the first person to scam this way. In Steve’s research, there was an earlier scam by a woman named Sarah Howe in the 1870s.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:42] - Upon being released from prison, Sarah went back to her old ways and developed the same exact scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:16] - Steve shares the story of Brad Bleidt to illustrate the term “affinity fraud.” Brad was a Mason and other Masonic groups trusted him.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:01] - Sarah Howe targeted women. Brad Bleidt targeted other Masons. Bernie Madoff targeted mostly other Jewish people. We trust those who are like us.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:21] - Steve shares a story about how Bernie Madoff was actually found out much earlier and reported multiple times.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:10] - This is not just an American phenomenon. A massive Ponzi scheme in Romania took down most of the nation’s economy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:43] - When you deal with any kind of investment, you want to check out two things. The first thing is the person you’re dealing with. Steve is a nationally recognized expert in scams and identity theft as well as a lawyer, college professor, and prolific author. His informative speeches, articles, and books make difficult subjects not only understandable, but enjoyable with the humor he brings to these complex issues. Mike is a renowned hypnotist with 18 nominations and 6 awards for excellence in entertainment and is also considered an expert in the unique martial art of British Jiu Jitsu. He has trained both law enforcement and security personnel and boasts a diverse client list that includes Microsoft, Scotia Bank, and the Department of Defense. He has been featured on both British and Australian television, profiled in numerous publications including Martial Arts Illustrated, I Spy Magazine, and Toronto Star.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:07] - Mike shares his background as a hypnotist and training in British Jiu Jitsu. He went into business with a business partner who turned out to be a psychopath.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:09] - Before the issues with his business partner were revealed, Mike had an experience on a plane with him getting suddenly angry about his handwriting. Now, as a graphologist, Mike knows now that his writing was a clue.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:51] - After dealing with overwhelming stress, Mike reached out to a friend and former colleague who is a forensic psychiatrist who said that he was taken in by a highly functioning psychopath.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:46] - This experience led Mike to studying psychopathy and he now does lectures on the topic, specifically signs in handwriting.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:30] - The terms psychopath and sociopath are used synonymously.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:01] - Mike shares that there are many psychopaths who are immensely successful and some are in the armed forces. Generally speaking, they can rise to the top with ease because they don’t have the same fears as an average person.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:52] - Mike describes psychopaths as grandiose and good at luring people into their presentation.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:23] - There was a study done on psychopaths in the prison system where they were shown the same video of random people walking on the street and asked who they would target. They all chose the same person.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:18] - Psychopaths are very good at hiding their true selves and are extremely patient in waiting for their opportunity.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:27] - Psychopaths are so good at what they do. Mike shares that he has known detectives and psychiatrists who have been fooled.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:30] - Mike doesn’t think that psychopathy can be “fixed” as their brains simply do not process things the same way.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:02] - Almost every scam that Chris has heard of has some sort of emotional connection.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:19] - We need close friends in our lives, but the scary thing for Mike was that the psychopath that tricked Mike</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">was</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">a close friend.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:45] - The first tip Mike has is to be aware of your surroundings at all times. This awareness is also important in your online surroundings.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:18] - Mike shares a story about what he calls his “spider sense.” </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:02] - Mike describes a color system he has that illustrates a way to condition yourself in being cautious and aware of your surroundings.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:31] - The Witching Hour is a window of time between 11:00pm and 3:00am that your chances of being in a violent encounter are higher than other times of the day and night.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:50] - We don’t want to be paranoid, because if our spider senses are set too high then real problems are indistinguishable from the background.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:11] - Mike describes self defense versus self protection.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:40] - While in public, Mike is always assessing situations and never putting himself into a position that someone could surprise him.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:14] - You want to make it that it is an unconscious response.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:07] - Mike describes the different proximities and how safety comes through distance.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:17] - When asked about the prisoner study where psychopaths would pick the same people to target, Mike shares that one of the things they picked up on was an asymmetrical walk. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:51] - Mike describes how our level of confidence is apparent in our body language and many people seem to have a target on them because of, what Mike calls, a “victim signal.”</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:45] - Avoid everything and every place if it doesn’t feel right.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:52] - Chris and Mike make the connection between real-life and online targeting.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:01] - They use the psychological trick of appealing to scarcity and urgency. We are all vulnerable to these things even if we know about them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[40:20] - Mike shares a story about an experience with his online business being harassed by a client.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:12] - The way you disconnect from someone is to ignore and disconnect them. If you tell them over and over again that you’re not going to communicate, you are in fact communicating with them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[42:44] - Get toxic people out of your life. When you see signs of someone in your life that you feel are “off,” you need to be prepared to fire people out of your life.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[43:47] - Mike explains how the traits in the writing of the psychopath that was in his life stood out to him and shares how specific features look.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[45:08] - The “Felon’s Claw” is a trait of handwriting that indicates that someone feels guilty.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[47:37] - Mike’s final piece of advice is that you can’t change a psychopath and you will likely come across one in your life. 			<title>Privacy by Design with Nishant Bhajaria</title>
			<itunes:title>Privacy by Design with Nishant Bhajaria</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 17 Feb 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[1557bc52-47c0-4e00-8f85-2b71b5bea961]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/51]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Data privacy has often been an after-thought in software and platform development. Data breaches have increased consumer awareness and laws such as GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) and CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act) have been enacted. Programmers and engineers need to think about what data they are collecting, how it is being stored and accessed, and how it is shared to protect their end users. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Nishant Bhajaria. Nishant leads the technical privacy and strategy teams for Uber that include data scientists, engineers, privacy experts, and others as they seek to improve data privacy for the consumers and the company. Previously, he worked in compliance, data protection and privacy at Google. He was also the head of privacy engineering at Netflix. He is a well-known expert in the field of data privacy, has developed numerous courses on the topic, and has spoken extensively at conferences and on podcasts.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:09] - Nishant shares his background and how he got started in the field of data privacy. He started at Intel and explains the changes in data collection in the early 2010s.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:47] - Nishant started in the field “before it was cool,” because of his strengths as an engineer and writer.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:33] - GDPR stands for General Data Protection Regulation and Nishant describes what this law means and how it came about in Europe.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:47] - CCPA is the US’s approach and first step into data privacy laws.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:53] - Consent is going to be a big topic in 2021. Nishant describes how the events of the last decade have led to data privacy laws.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:56] - Nishant points out that a problem with data privacy laws as they stand right now is that they are not written by people who have the technological and engineering background.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:39] - The data privacy issues that have arisen in recent years did not happen all of a sudden. Nishant explains that many mistakes across the board have led to them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:00] - Nishant lists some of the conundrums and ethical questions that come up when discussing data privacy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:23] - One of the biggest problems with data privacy is the different understanding of what that means. European countries and the United States do not have the same understanding of what privacy is.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:46] - Security features exist for very good reasons, but people are generally very impatient with them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:12] - Nishant gives an example of microdecisions that come in to play when data gets into the hands of the wrong person.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:17] - Nishant gives an example of how some decisions, made by companies in response to GDPR, are making sure they are in compliance but are not always consumer friendly due to a lack of understanding of the law.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:56] - The internet was not designed with privacy in mind. Privacy was an afterthought.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:06] - Nishant describes the challenges that we face when consumers want to access apps and sites quickly and the domino effect that takes place.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:29] - There was a huge systemic change in the workforce in the field of data privacy and data collection that Nishant describes was due to most people joining this career after 2009.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:43] - A problem arose when engineers would think that they were always the ethical ones because they were collecting data or designing apps and platforms to collect data for the right reasons. But that isn’t always how that data is used. More to Nishant’s point that data collection needs to be regulated from the get go.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:03] - Privacy is all about not accessing or using data without the owner’s consent, but people don’t realize how much can be known about someone just with combining easily accessible data online.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:10] - We have built the internet for fast access and use. Customers sign up for a lot of access to sites and apps and don’t think about the use of their data when they do.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:31] - For companies that are small and don’t have the legal teams to handle a privacy problem, Nishant says the first thing to do is to make sure you really need the information you are asking for from your customers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:27] - It is much easier to look at what you’re collecting, the necessity of it all, and how that data could be compromised in the early stages because there’s not a lot of data to dig into.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:06] - Another tip from Nishant is to lean on tooling to build privacy at scale. He describes what this means with examples.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:36] - Nishant also explains to make sure that the wall between the legal team and the engineering/privacy team is broken down. Those teams need to work in harmony.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:10] - Chris and Nishant discuss the pitfalls of deleting data and the importance of consistency.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:07] - Many companies cannot afford to go through a data breach or legal problem with data privacy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:10] - There is an economical factor to consider when collecting too much data or duplicate data that Nishant describes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:18] - When signing up for services, sites, or apps, consider why they are asking for the data they say they need. A social security number, for example, is not needed for a grocery delivery.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:01] - As a result of the GDPR, companies are starting to be required to disclose the information of what consumers’ data is used for.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:28] - Nishant says that the biggest piece of advice he has for consumers is to always ask questions. At the end of the day, it is your data and you need to know what’s happening with it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:56] - Apple specifically has built a really strong privacy standard for other companies to live up to. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[40:01] - This time of Covid and the US’s political events have changed the landscape of privacy and data collection and through this crisis, Nishant is confident that great ideas and positive change come through times of unrest.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:37] - Regulators and lawmakers need the engineering support and need to be a part of our conversations regarding data privacy.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[43:24] - Nishant hasn’t met anyone that has thought that privacy is unimportant, but communicating the details and the prioritization is a different challenge.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[45:16] -</span> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Privacy by Design</span></em> <span style="font-weight: 400;">is Nishant’s book written to educate business owners, engineers, and CEOs that privacy is taken care of at the start instead of as an afterthought as a response to a problem.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[47:31] - Regardless of your current understanding of technology, Nishant’s book is a great read to better understand privacy and data collection.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/in/nishantjb/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Nishant Bhajaria on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><em><a href= "https://www.manning.com/books/privacy-by-design"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Privacy by Design</span> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">by Nishant Bhajaria</span></a></em></li> <li><a href= "https://twitter.com/nishantbhajaria?lang=en"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Nishant Bhajaria on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Romance Scams with David McClellan</title>
			<itunes:title>Romance Scams with David McClellan</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 10 Feb 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2969e9a0-6594-45c8-8ab9-a3dd3ad6d174]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/50]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Catfishing is when a person creates a fake identity often with corresponding social media accounts, phone numbers, photos, and addresses targeting a specific victim for abuse or fraud. These catfishers are organized, patient, and have a playbook that they follow to gain the trust of their target over the course of weeks, months, or even years. Effective deceviers even get advice from other scammers on how to proceed for their own success.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is David McClellan. David was an internet marketer and website builder for over ten years. He ran and executed SEO strategies for CNET where he added 1.4 billion visitors to the portfolio. He branched out as a visionary and entrepreneur 6 years ago when he created SocialCatfish.com. His website became the fastest growing company in Riverside, California and is an Inc 500 company.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:10] - David shares his background as an internet marketer turned entrepreneur and the start of SocialCatfish.com.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:01] - He and his business partner used to build websites and then flip them but discovered that there was no resource out there regarding catfishing. So they started the website and it was an immediate success.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:34] - Once David and his business partner figured out how to monetize their site, they were speaking directly with their customers and hearing their stories.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:21] - David also began a YouTube channel that shares real stories, interviews with scammers, and David even got his hands on a playbook used by scammers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:50] - There is also a Facebook watch group where people can upload pictures of “scammers” to look out for.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:22] - Romance scams are part of catfishing. David explains the similarities.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:19] - David shares one of the most upsetting client stories regarding a lawyer sending cash to Nigeria. But through it all, she was able to send a tracking device and use SocialCatfish.com to meet the real person behind the stolen photo.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:47] - David shares another story of a client who lost her husband and survived cancer herself being scammed through online dating. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:38] - Romance scammers, especially those overseas, will spend hours talking to someone everyday because if it results in thousands of dollars, that is a lot of money where they live.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:35] - Another story of a client building a relationship with a scammer and who she thought was his daughter. She had been secluded from her friends and family and the scammer even told her to commit suicide.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:29] - Effective scammers will seclude a victim from their friends and family using a convincing story and are very emotionally manipulative.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:50] - A newer trend in romance scams is that scammers are now starting to send inexpensive gifts to victims such as balloons, flowers, and cheap jewelry to build trust.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:51] - When interviewing scammers, David asks them what happens if they don’t get money and the answer is that they</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">always</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">get money. They even refer to victims as clients.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:40] - Another new trend is when scammers reveal themselves and convince the victim that they really did fall in love and need money to get out of their very poor country.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:09] - David shares the noticeable differences between men and women who are victims of catfishing and romance scams.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:01] - Although victims who are lonely, depressed, widowed, or divorced are the prime targets for scammers, David shares that even married people are being sucked into scams.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:09] - Chris shares a story about a previous podcast guest using other people’s videos in video chat is not always a reliable method of confirming identity.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:19] - David explains that there is open source software available where he could record anything and make the people in the video say whatever he wants them to say.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:25] - People whose images are stolen to use by scammers are victims, too. David also tries to help these people as well.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:19] - David shares a story about a man who was catfished, convinced of their real identity, and killed the woman he thought the scammer was.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:09] - If you are contacted randomly by a stranger, including games with chat features like Words with Friends, and someone ever asks you for some form of money, that is a big sign of a scammer.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:05] - Scammers will also tend to try to get a victim to chat outside of the dating app so their profile does not get reported and taken down.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:00] - Most of the time, scammers tend to start asking for money after about 90 days, but David says that sometimes they’ll wait less time or more time before asking.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:21] - Financial crimes seem not to have the same level of consequences when caught than in-person crimes. Many crimes like this are sometimes not even reported.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:06] - It is not illegal to give somebody money. When it is reported to law enforcement, there’s not much police can do. You should still report it, but it is a civil issue.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:18] - David also shares that sometimes there are people in the United States that are helping scammers overseas.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:39] - There’s not enough education surrounding internet safety. Education is empowering.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[38:51] - Chris shares an experience with his bank and how they are starting to be trained on making sure people are wiring money to someone they’ve actually met.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[39:54] - We are seeing it more and more that bank employees are noticing and advising clients that they are likely being scammed.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:22] - Social media sites and companies are getting better with helping educate people and prevent scams, but scammers are also getting better and more convincing.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[44:05] - David has a private Facebook group called SCF Seekers which is all about information without judgment.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Catfishing is when a person creates a fake identity often with corresponding social media accounts, phone numbers, photos, and addresses targeting a specific victim for abuse or fraud. These catfishers are organized, patient, and have a playbook that they follow to gain the trust of their target over the course of weeks, months, or even years. Effective deceviers even get advice from other scammers on how to proceed for their own success.</p> <p>Today’s guest is David McClellan. David was an internet marketer and website builder for over ten years. He ran and executed SEO strategies for CNET where he added 1.4 billion visitors to the portfolio. He branched out as a visionary and entrepreneur 6 years ago when he created SocialCatfish.com. His website became the fastest growing company in Riverside, California and is an Inc 500 company.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li>[1:10] - David shares his background as an internet marketer turned entrepreneur and the start of SocialCatfish.com.</li> <li>[2:01] - He and his business partner used to build websites and then flip them but discovered that there was no resource out there regarding catfishing. So they started the website and it was an immediate success.</li> <li>[3:34] - Once David and his business partner figured out how to monetize their site, they were speaking directly with their customers and hearing their stories.</li> <li>[4:21] - David also began a YouTube channel that shares real stories, interviews with scammers, and David even got his hands on a playbook used by scammers.</li> <li>[4:50] - There is also a Facebook watch group where people can upload pictures of “scammers” to look out for.</li> <li>[5:22] - Romance scams are part of catfishing. David explains the similarities.</li> <li>[6:19] - David shares one of the most upsetting client stories regarding a lawyer sending cash to Nigeria. But through it all, she was able to send a tracking device and use SocialCatfish.com to meet the real person behind the stolen photo.</li> <li>[8:47] - David shares another story of a client who lost her husband and survived cancer herself being scammed through online dating. </li> <li>[10:38] - Romance scammers, especially those overseas, will spend hours talking to someone everyday because if it results in thousands of dollars, that is a lot of money where they live.</li> <li>[11:35] - Another story of a client building a relationship with a scammer and who she thought was his daughter. She had been secluded from her friends and family and the scammer even told her to commit suicide.</li> <li>[13:29] - Effective scammers will seclude a victim from their friends and family using a convincing story and are very emotionally manipulative.</li> <li>[14:50] - A newer trend in romance scams is that scammers are now starting to send inexpensive gifts to victims such as balloons, flowers, and cheap jewelry to build trust.</li> <li>[15:51] - When interviewing scammers, David asks them what happens if they don’t get money and the answer is that they <em>always</em> get money. They even refer to victims as clients.</li> <li>[16:40] - Another new trend is when scammers reveal themselves and convince the victim that they really did fall in love and need money to get out of their very poor country.</li> <li>[18:09] - David shares the noticeable differences between men and women who are victims of catfishing and romance scams.</li> <li>[21:01] - Although victims who are lonely, depressed, widowed, or divorced are the prime targets for scammers, David shares that even married people are being sucked into scams.</li> <li>[23:09] - Chris shares a story about a previous podcast guest using other people’s videos in video chat is not always a reliable method of confirming identity.</li> <li>[24:19] - David explains that there is open source software available where he could record anything and make the people in the video say whatever he wants them to say.</li> <li>[25:25] - People whose images are stolen to use by scammers are victims, too. David also tries to help these people as well.</li> <li>[26:19] - David shares a story about a man who was catfished, convinced of their real identity, and killed the woman he thought the scammer was.</li> <li>[27:09] - If you are contacted randomly by a stranger, including games with chat features like Words with Friends, and someone ever asks you for some form of money, that is a big sign of a scammer.</li> <li>[28:05] - Scammers will also tend to try to get a victim to chat outside of the dating app so their profile does not get reported and taken down.</li> <li>[29:00] - Most of the time, scammers tend to start asking for money after about 90 days, but David says that sometimes they’ll wait less time or more time before asking.</li> <li>[31:21] - Financial crimes seem not to have the same level of consequences when caught than in-person crimes. Many crimes like this are sometimes not even reported.</li> <li>[33:06] - It is not illegal to give somebody money. When it is reported to law enforcement, there’s not much police can do. You should still report it, but it is a civil issue.</li> <li>[35:18] - David also shares that sometimes there are people in the United States that are helping scammers overseas.</li> <li>[37:39] - There’s not enough education surrounding internet safety. Education is empowering.</li> <li>[38:51] - Chris shares an experience with his bank and how they are starting to be trained on making sure people are wiring money to someone they’ve actually met.</li> <li>[39:54] - We are seeing it more and more that bank employees are noticing and advising clients that they are likely being scammed.</li> <li>[41:22] - Social media sites and companies are getting better with helping educate people and prevent scams, but scammers are also getting better and more convincing.</li> <li>[44:05] - David has a private Facebook group called SCF Seekers which is all about information without judgment.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="https://socialcatfish.com/">SocialCatfish.com</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/SocialCatfish">Social Catfish on Facebook</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/groups/SCFseekers">SCF Seekers Facebook Group</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/socialcatfish">Social Catfish on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC9lVBXYB-dUYJRevrELEmxg"> Social Catfish on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.instagram.com/socialcatfish/">Social Catfish on Instagram</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>
