			<title>Surviving a Romance Scam with Debby Montgomery Johnson</title>
			<itunes:title>Surviving a Romance Scam with Debby Montgomery Johnson</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 03 Feb 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[7bec1bc5-2661-4481-9fa5-60bd694952b6]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/49]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many are resigned to stay silent about the pain of being scammed, but today’s guest helps empower others by vulnerably communicating her experience and sharing specific warning signs.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Debby Montgomery Johnson. Debby is founder of The Woman Behind the Smile, Inc. She is a best-selling author, international speaker, entrepreneur, podcast host, former Air Force officer who served at the Pentagon, and is a woman on a mission. In her book</span> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Woman Behind the Smile,</span></em> <span style="font-weight: 400;">she shares her personal experience with a love that turned to betrayal and financial disaster. She removes the mask of shame and shows others how to do the same. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:07] - Debby shares the person she was before she was scammed. Her husband of 26 years had unexpectedly passed away, she had a varied career background, and is a mother and grandmother.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:08] - After her husband passed away, she had to step up and run his business without a lot of training or knowledge.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:05] - Debby had very little time to grieve as she would work her job and then go straight into managing her late husband’s business.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:59] - When her friends noticed that she was staying home so much to work on the business, they told her she needed to get out and “have a life.” A friend recommended online dating.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:56] - Debby was very transparent in her online dating profile. She stepped into it very carefully.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:46] - Although Debby was very particular, she did eventually meet someone who caught her attention and that’s how everything started.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:43] - Debby explains that something that scammers do is try to take you off the dating sites to talk and Debby would talk to him on Yahoo Chat instead.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:39] - After speaking with a psychologist later on, Debby was told that she likely never felt listened to based on her behaviors and she admits that Eric, the man she met online,</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">did</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">listen to her.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:47] - Over two years of communicating with Eric, Debby felt listened to and shares that she had wonderful conversations through writing with him.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:22] - At this point in time, Debby was familiar with online dating scams and never felt like anything sinister was going on.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:23] - Debby began lending money to Eric as a way to help him through his jobs until he would get paid. He always promised to pay her back. The energy came from the sooner he finished a job, the sooner he would come home.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:01] - The first red flag for Debby was when he asked her to set up a power of attorney and use Western Union to send him money.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:43] - In addition to asking for money, Eric also was successful in further isolating Debby from her friends and family. Debby shares how her sons warned her against a relationship with Eric.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:50] - After being married for so long, Debby wasn’t ready for a physical relationship, but she was ready for a friendship. Eric turned into a confidante.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[18:59] - Debby explains how she wanted to video chat with Eric but that he always had an excuse as to why he couldn’t get online to do that.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:13] - Eric continued to ask Debby for money for his issues with his international business. Looking back, she shares that it all seems so ridiculous but the urgency was overpowering.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:01] - Debby admits that she did not have the large sums of money Eric needed and she dipped into retirement funds, sold jewelry, and even borrowed a very large sum from her parents.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:47] - When asked if she would go back and change things if she could, Debby says she would actually let things happen the way they happened. She learned so much about herself during this time and is now able to help others.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:36] - Chris shares a story that illustrates the lack of knowledge surrounding scams and security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:28] - When you think of an online romance scam, you’ll think ‘oh that will never happen to me.’ That’s not the point. It could happen to your mother, your daughter, or your best friend.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:31] - Other victims that have been scammed reach out to Debby after reading her book and Debby has noticed that everyone’s story is exactly the same. These scammers are very well trained.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[29:59] - Debby’s sons were very upset after the scam was revealed, but they also felt that they had not done their job to protect their mother as well.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:54] - Eric and Debby had a lengthy conversation about forgiveness and he confessed that it all had been a scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:13] - Initially Debby didn’t believe Eric and asked for proof that it was a scam. They finally conducted a video chat and she saw the real person behind it all.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:09] - Eric admitted that throughout the scam, he had started to feel real feelings for Debby and had to come clean. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:30] - Debby went to the FBI and they told her that there was nothing they could do because he was not in the country.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:04] - She told a new friend her story and through their conversation she discovered that the other woman’s mother was also scammed. That was the moment Debby realized that she had a mission now.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[38:14] - Debby was put in contact with an organization called Society of Citizens Against Relationship Scams that has been working with victims and survivors all over the world.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:08] - Chris and Debby discuss other popular scams that are happening that drain a lot of money from individuals and businesses.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[43:02] - Chris references a past episode that also proved that many victims and survivors don’t report things because of the embarrassment of being scammed.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[45:01] - A friend of Debby’s is now dating online and Debby shares that she can spot a scammer very quickly now and objectively helps her friend navigate different profiles.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[47:36] - Many men have had their pictures used by scammers. And sometimes they are able to contact people who have been communicating with a scammer through their likeness and convince them that it is a scam.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[49:03] - Debby and Chris discuss why many scammers use the likeness of people in the military. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[51:10] - The first people you need to tell if you’ve been scammed this way is your family so you can have support and be surrounded by people who love you.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[53:45] - Something more recent that is happening with the onset of more available video chat platforms is now scammers can steal videos and voice over to provide more convincing communication.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[56:01] - All different age groups are hit by romance scams in different ways. Older generations are more reliant on Skype and Facetime but the younger generations are using different mobile apps like Snapchat and Instagram.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[56:32] - When making a dating profile, do not list that you are widowed or divorced. It may make you a target.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[57:35] - Don’t put your business or any way to look up your finances on your dating profile.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[58:21] - Pictures used in profiles can also be red flags. You can reverse Google the image and sometimes find that they’re photos of a model or stock photo.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[59:24] - If someone you are talking to is constantly international and can’t get home, that is a romance scam red flag.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[60:11] - Currently, money is being sent to scammers through cryptocurrency, gift cards, or even gaming platform credit.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[61:45] - If you think you might be involved in a scam or know someone who is, Debby recommends you check out Anyscam.com or AgainstScam.org.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[62:47] - Debby says you need to report everything and take the time to write down your story to get it out. Find someone who you trust and can help you move forward.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[64:09] - Another sad reality of romance scams is that victims shut themselves off from love and dating again and isolate themselves from potential positive relationships.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><em><a href="https://thewomanbehindthesmile.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">The Woman Behind the Smile Web Page</span></a></em></li> <li><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Woman-Behind-Smile-Ultimate-Betrayal/dp/0692794999"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">The Woman Behind the Smile: Triumph Over the Ultimate Online Dating Betrayal</span> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">by Debby Montgomery Johnson</span></a></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">EMAIL:</span> <a href= "mailto:debby@thewomanbehindthesmile.com"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">debby@thewomanbehindthesmile.com</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://thewomanbehindthesmile.com/show/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Stand Up and Speak Up Show</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

That was the moment Debby realized that she had a mission now.</li> <li>[38:14] - Debby was put in contact with an organization called Society of Citizens Against Relationship Scams that has been working with victims and survivors all over the world.</li> <li>[41:08] - Chris and Debby discuss other popular scams that are happening that drain a lot of money from individuals and businesses.</li> <li>[43:02] - Chris references a past episode that also proved that many victims and survivors don’t report things because of the embarrassment of being scammed.</li> <li>[45:01] - A friend of Debby’s is now dating online and Debby shares that she can spot a scammer very quickly now and objectively helps her friend navigate different profiles.</li> <li>[47:36] - Many men have had their pictures used by scammers. And sometimes they are able to contact people who have been communicating with a scammer through their likeness and convince them that it is a scam.</li> <li>[49:03] - Debby and Chris discuss why many scammers use the likeness of people in the military. </li> <li>[51:10] - The first people you need to tell if you’ve been scammed this way is your family so you can have support and be surrounded by people who love you.</li> <li>[53:45] - Something more recent that is happening with the onset of more available video chat platforms is now scammers can steal videos and voice over to provide more convincing communication.</li> <li>[56:01] - All different age groups are hit by romance scams in different ways. Older generations are more reliant on Skype and Facetime but the younger generations are using different mobile apps like Snapchat and Instagram.</li> <li>[56:32] - When making a dating profile, do not list that you are widowed or divorced. It may make you a target.</li> <li>[57:35] - Don’t put your business or any way to look up your finances on your dating profile.</li> <li>[58:21] - Pictures used in profiles can also be red flags. You can reverse Google the image and sometimes find that they’re photos of a model or stock photo.</li> <li>[59:24] - If someone you are talking to is constantly international and can’t get home, that is a romance scam red flag.</li> <li>[60:11] - Currently, money is being sent to scammers through cryptocurrency, gift cards, or even gaming platform credit.</li> <li>[61:45] - If you think you might be involved in a scam or know someone who is, Debby recommends you check out Anyscam.com or AgainstScam.org.</li> <li>[62:47] - Debby says you need to report everything and take the time to write down your story to get it out. Find someone who you trust and can help you move forward.</li> <li>[64:09] - Another sad reality of romance scams is that victims shut themselves off from love and dating again and isolate themselves from potential positive relationships.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><em><a href="https://thewomanbehindthesmile.com/">The Woman Behind the Smile Web Page</a></em></li> <li><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Woman-Behind-Smile-Ultimate-Betrayal/dp/0692794999"> The Woman Behind the Smile: Triumph Over the Ultimate Online Dating Betrayal by Debby Montgomery Johnson</a></li> <li>EMAIL: <a href= "mailto:debby@thewomanbehindthesmile.com">debby@thewomanbehindthesmile.com</a></li> <li><a href="https://thewomanbehindthesmile.com/show/">Stand Up and Speak Up Show</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Keeping Kids Safe Online with Susan McLean</title>
			<itunes:title>Keeping Kids Safe Online with Susan McLean</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 27 Jan 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2c810a95-4fe3-4197-b778-93bac9e8871e]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/48]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Keeping children safe online is a concern for every parent. Children can have a technical skill that is far more advanced than their cognitive development and it is not easy to know how and what boundaries to set. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Susan McLean. Susan is Australia’s foremost expert in the area of cyber safety and was a member of Victoria Police for 27 years. Widely known as The Cyber Cop, she was the first Victoria police officer appointed to a position involving cyber safety and young people. In 2003, she was a Victoria Police Region 4 Youth Officer of the Year. She has also been awarded the National Medal and Victoria Police Service Medal. Susan established a consulting firm in March 2007 called Cyber Safety Solutions and has grown to be the most highly respected and in demand cyber safety consultancy in Australia.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Show Notes:</span></span></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:21] - Susan shares her background in law enforcement and her first online appointment was in 1994.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:17] - She was led to America in her quest to learn as much as she could about cyber safety. The training she was a part of was The Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force Team training and more trainings in Texas.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:35] - When Susan returned to Australia, she outlined a plan of action for law enforcement in Australia.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:14] - When Susan’s support retired, she lost all internal support at that time. Others claimed she was making things up to create a job opportunity and that because she was a woman, she couldn’t do this job.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:07] - Susan quit her job because she became passionate about this concern and took a risk in developing her own consultant agency. She works extensively with schools, parents, and teachers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:46] - Now, law enforcement takes cyber crime more seriously.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:51] - Susan says that although there is acknowledgement of cyberbullying and online safety issues, there is still a lack of training of front line police officers.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:50] - Susan describes JACKET teams in Australia and how it works in her country.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:30] - The amount of arrests is phenomenal, but Susan would much rather there were no arrests because we can educate young people to not fall victim to these types of crimes.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:27] - Susan shares that most arrests are made within Australia but that there are international crime gangs specifically in sex trafficking and sexual exploitation that are elsewhere.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:08] - The statistics in Australia show that a quarter of all teens have been cyber bullied at some point. This can mean a lot of different things. It's almost always an extension of schoolyard bullying.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:47] - Nude photos are also prominent and fit the definition of child exploitation offenses.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:58] - To be an effective parent in the 21st century, you have to parent in the digital space.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:43] - The internet is 100% an adult world that you are putting your child into. Risks cannot be removed but you can identify and limit the risk with boundaries for your child.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:18] - Young people’s technical skill far outweighs their cognitive and brain development. There is a massive gap between what they can actually do and what they can understand.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:29] - Susan explains that if your child is under 13, you should be in complete control over everything your child does online.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:33] - Start with one platform that you can manage when you feel they are ready for it. Constant monitoring and parent judgement on maturity is necessary.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:01] - Susan recommends having a rule in place that you will check all accounts and devices a certain number of random days per month.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:33] - Checking lists of friends and contacts, the child has to explain who they are to the parent’s expectations. If you can’t invite them over for dinner, they don’t belong on their list.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:55] - Susan shares how the majority of in-person sexual abuse or exploitation are with people the victim knows. But online, the majority are people who are unknown to the child or teen.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:02] - If you are familiar with the person and are unsure if it is their real account, ask them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[24:27] - Parents also need to have conversations prior to online use to make sure their children are not being the ones doing the bullying.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:45] - If you are the caretaker of any child or minor, you have to be aware that they are targets.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[26:03] - Susan explains that the majority of inappropriate photos are taken in bedrooms and bathrooms with the doors closed. She shares examples of ways a parent can prohibit devices with cameras in those rooms.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[27:48] - Especially during Covid, the limitation of devices and children online became difficult.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:28] - One of the biggest mistakes parents make is giving their child or teen a phone thinking it will keep them safe. They are handy, but they are not safety devices.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:18] - Susan also lists the other issues that come with extensive use of electronic devices, including posture, muscular and skeletal problems, and eye strain.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:27] - Every adult has a responsibility to keep children safe on and offline. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:34] - Susan recommends several websites for parent and child education on cyber safety that include games and kid friendly language.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:59] - Susan is also the author of</span> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sexts, Texts, and Selfies</span></em> <span style="font-weight: 400;">which is an internationally available book. The only changes based on the country are the laws and legislation.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[40:12] - It is everywhere no matter the crime. Cyber safety is absolutely crucial.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Links and Resources:</span></span></p> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.cybersafetysolutions.com.au/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">CyberSafety Solutions Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/TheCybercop1"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Susan McLean on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/thecybercop/">Susan McLean on Facebook</a></span></li> <li><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Sexts-Texts-Selfies-Children-Digital/dp/0143791419/ref=sr_1_1?dchild=1&keywords=sexts+texts&qid=1611624087&sr=8-1"> <em>Sexts, Texts, and Selfies: How to Keep Your Children Safe in the Digital Space</em> by Susan McLean</a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Student Loan Scams with Robert Farrington</title>
			<itunes:title>Student Loan Scams with Robert Farrington</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 20 Jan 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[70172e13-8d81-48a7-99a6-991f637b8ff8]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/47]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’ve got student loans, you feel the pressure of that financial obligation, but watch out. There are scammers looking to take advantage of your situation, offering student loan consolidation or elimination for a fee. Our guest today is Robert Farrington.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Robert is founder of</span> <a href="https://thecollegeinvestor.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">The College Investor</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. He has been featured in many media outlets such as The New York Times, Washington Post, ABC and NBC News. As America’s millennial money expert and America’s student loan debt expert, he is on a mission to help people escape student loan debt and start building wealth for their future.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Show Notes:</span></p> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[0:54] - Robert founded</span> <a href="https://thecollegeinvestor.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">The College Investor</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">website when he was a college student. He shares his background as a blogger and his experience when a post about student loan debt went viral.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:33] - College is a great investment for a lot of people, but like any investment, if you spend too much it might not be worth it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:01] - You don’t go to college to learn because you find everything you need online for free. College is a signal to potential employers that you have a degree.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:02] - Robert points out that trade schools and “dirty jobs” are a fantastic opportunity to make a lot of money without going to college but that many young adults don’t know enough about them.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:29] - There are three main types of schools: state school, non-profit, and for-profit. Robert gives examples of each kind.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:39] - One type of student loan is federal student loans through the government with the requirement that you attend an accredited school.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[7:23] - The other type of student loan is a private student loan that comes from a bank, credit card company, or other private lender. These are similar to a mortgage.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:15] - Robert shares that there are so many student loan scams out there but they all have the same theme: to either lower the monthly payment or lower the total amount somehow.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:32] - There are many programs that are legitimate and that</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">will</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">lower your monthly payment. The red flag is the fee that you pay. Robert explains how this works.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[10:01] - The most popular loan forgiveness program that is fully legitimate is the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program that there is no fee for.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:11] - There is loan consolidation which takes all your loans and puts them into one loan. Robert doesn’t recommend this and explains why.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:13] - If you call your lender and let them know that you can’t pay, there is something they can do. It is a scam if you pay a third party and they can fill out your paperwork incorrectly.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:26] - Robert describes another type of scammers that pose as a pseudo law firm that tells people to stop paying their loans and then go to court for them to represent you to get you lower payments. But this trashes your credit and doesn’t get you ahead.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:03] - Robert recommends to always start with caller your lender and talk to them about your options. Communicate your needs.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:51] - There are also really great apps available that will help you manage your finances and Robert points out that there are valid and legitimate paid programs.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:16] - The legitimate paid financial advisors won’t do anything</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">for</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">you. They will give you a plan and you will need to take the steps to follow the plan.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:39] - Robert admits that most loan service providers make errors and there are definitely problems. However, they manage loans for millions of people.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:51] - All paperwork done on your behalf needs to be looked over. A lot of companies that have been shut down were because of falsified information.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:38] - Robert explains how some scam companies will take your fees and not do any work at all. They’ll send you email updates as if things are being done and then you default.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[22:28] - Even if you are going to work with someone, you still need to log in to your loan provider account and check things every month. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>If you’ve got student loans, you feel the pressure of that financial obligation, but watch out. There are scammers looking to take advantage of your situation, offering student loan consolidation or elimination for a fee. Our guest today is Robert Farrington.</p> <p>Robert is founder of <a href="https://thecollegeinvestor.com/">The College Investor</a>. He has been featured in many media outlets such as The New York Times, Washington Post, ABC and NBC News. As America’s millennial money expert and America’s student loan debt expert, he is on a mission to help people escape student loan debt and start building wealth for their future.</p> <p>Show Notes:</p> <ul> <li>[0:54] - Robert founded <a href="https://thecollegeinvestor.com/">The College Investor</a> website when he was a college student. He shares his background as a blogger and his experience when a post about student loan debt went viral.</li> <li>[2:33] - College is a great investment for a lot of people, but like any investment, if you spend too much it might not be worth it.</li> <li>[3:01] - You don’t go to college to learn because you find everything you need online for free. College is a signal to potential employers that you have a degree.</li> <li>[4:02] - Robert points out that trade schools and “dirty jobs” are a fantastic opportunity to make a lot of money without going to college but that many young adults don’t know enough about them.</li> <li>[5:29] - There are three main types of schools: state school, non-profit, and for-profit. Robert gives examples of each kind.</li> <li>[6:39] - One type of student loan is federal student loans through the government with the requirement that you attend an accredited school.</li> <li>[7:23] - The other type of student loan is a private student loan that comes from a bank, credit card company, or other private lender. These are similar to a mortgage.</li> <li>[8:15] - Robert shares that there are so many student loan scams out there but they all have the same theme: to either lower the monthly payment or lower the total amount somehow.</li> <li>[9:32] - There are many programs that are legitimate and that <em>will</em> lower your monthly payment. The red flag is the fee that you pay. Robert explains how this works.</li> <li>[10:01] - The most popular loan forgiveness program that is fully legitimate is the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program that there is no fee for.</li> <li>[11:11] - There is loan consolidation which takes all your loans and puts them into one loan. Robert doesn’t recommend this and explains why.</li> <li>[12:13] - If you call your lender and let them know that you can’t pay, there is something they can do. It is a scam if you pay a third party and they can fill out your paperwork incorrectly.</li> <li>[13:26] - Robert describes another type of scammers that pose as a pseudo law firm that tells people to stop paying their loans and then go to court for them to represent you to get you lower payments. But this trashes your credit and doesn’t get you ahead.</li> <li>[15:03] - Robert recommends to always start with caller your lender and talk to them about your options. Communicate your needs.</li> <li>[16:51] - There are also really great apps available that will help you manage your finances and Robert points out that there are valid and legitimate paid programs.</li> <li>[17:16] - The legitimate paid financial advisors won’t do anything <em>for</em> you. They will give you a plan and you will need to take the steps to follow the plan.</li> <li>[19:39] - Robert admits that most loan service providers make errors and there are definitely problems. However, they manage loans for millions of people.</li> <li>[20:51] - All paperwork done on your behalf needs to be looked over. A lot of companies that have been shut down were because of falsified information.</li> <li>[21:38] - Robert explains how some scam companies will take your fees and not do any work at all. They’ll send you email updates as if things are being done and then you default.</li> <li>[22:28] - Even if you are going to work with someone, you still need to log in to your loan provider account and check things every month. Ultimately, you are responsible.</li> <li>[24:09] - Congress wants government loan servicers to promote these programs but they never do. </li> <li>[26:01] - If you feel that you have been scammed, you need to lock down all of your information. Change all passwords and check all of your accounts to make sure your information has not been changed.</li> <li>[27:20] - No legitimate company will ever ask you for your password or log in on your behalf. It is a literal federal crime.</li> <li>[27:58] - Robert shares the most incredible dollar amounts that some scam companies have collected.</li> <li>[28:51] - Robert also explains that some people pay companies to do this work for them because they don’t take the time to do the research.</li> <li>[30:01] - Student loans are challenging because it seems like there’s no way out. People know that there’s not a lot of options. Scammers are preying on.</li> <li>[32:36] - There are 100 Americans with over 100 million dollars in student loans. They got there because of graduate schools.</li> <li>[33:00] - There are two types of people who benefit the most from student loans. The first are low-income who plan to make between $30-$50k a year. The other one are the ones who borrow over $100k per year for graduate school.</li> <li>[35:34] - It always starts with getting organized. If you’re feeling overwhelmed, get it organized and look at it all.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <p>Links and Resources:</p> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="https://thecollegeinvestor.com/">The College Investor Site</a></li> <li><a href= "https://thecollegeinvestor.com/audio-show/">The College Investor Audio Site (Podcast)</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/c/thecollegeinvestor">The College Investor on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/thecollegeinvestor/">The College Investor on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/CollegeInvestin">The College Investor on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/thecollegeinvestor">The College Investor on Facebook</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Women in Infosec with Eleanor Dallaway</title>
			<itunes:title>Women in Infosec with Eleanor Dallaway</itunes:title>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In this episode, we deviate a bit from our traditional topics to incorporate the growing diversity in the Infosec world. In the past, this has been a male dominated field, but the culture is changing. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest today is Eleanor Dallway. Eleanor is the Editorial Director at Infosecurity Magazine, and she is at the front of the security industry. She has more than 15 years of online job experience and knows more about information security than most English Literature graduates should. She spends her working days interviewing industry professionals, keeping the website updated with news on a regular basis, editing the magazine, and attending industry events. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:03] - Eleanor’s experience in Infosec began in 2006 when she started working for Infosecurity Magazine. She also has experience editing for a wine and spirits magazine as well as one for retail.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:03] - Eleanor admits that information security is her favorite, because she’s worked in it the longest and it is constantly changing.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:51] - Her favorite part of her job is interviewing industry professionals. She shares several famous individuals who she has been able to interview.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:18] - Eleanor admits that she was very nervous to interview Kevin Mitnick and describes the experience.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[5:57] - Kevin Mitnick did magic tricks for Eleanor for fun, but demonstrated how con artists are very much like magicians.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:55] - Chris and Eleanor chat about their different interviews with previous podcast guest John McAfee.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:14] - John McAfee spoke an unscripted rant at an event that Eleanor was able to be present for.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:30] - Infosec trends are compared to fashion trends because they are cyclical and come back again.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[13:38] - Some trends that Eleanor discusses are the Cloud, artificial intelligence, and the focus on the human side of security.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[15:13] - Awareness now is much different than it was 15 years ago when Eleanor began working for Infosecurity Magazine. Now, they are major headlines and mainstream news.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:48] - Eleanor’s company puts in software that randomly tests people. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[19:31] - We start to distrust people who are actually trustworthy and tend to become cynical. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[20:18] - The types of scams that trend ebb and flow. Sometimes the trend is text scams, emails, or phone calls, generally speaking.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[21:40] - There are clever scammers who use the current climate to change their approach. Eleanor shares that she has seen a lot of scams with packages delivered because more people are shopping online.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[23:56] - When someone targets Eleanor, she knows she can handle it, but she gets very angry when scammers target her parents and grandmother.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[25:52] - Eleanor discusses various conferences and events. She doesn’t tend to worry about heavy security for some of them, but for several of them, she takes every precaution.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[28:10] - For the most part, Eleanor tends to go to more of the businessy conferences.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[30:42] - Eleanor admits that most of the things on her phone or computer are not that interesting so she feels comfortable taking her devices with her to other countries when traveling.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[31:28] - In regards to women in the industry, Eleanor says that it is still male dominated but it is moving in the right direction.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[32:48] - Eleanor has worked with programs that encourage teenage girls in high school to get into the infosec and technology world.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:25] - Eleanor launched Women in Cybersecurity Networking Group that began small in the UK but is now national. The purpose is to create a community.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:02] - Marketing cybersecurity needs a lot of change to include more accurate images and descriptions.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:11] - There’s a lot of going on in this space in regards to diversity in the industry, but Eleanor feels that it is not being done quickly enough.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:33] - The security industry is very resilient and has not been hurt by the pandemic except that they are shorthanded. Unemployment is high in many places, so people should be jumping ship and going into it.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.infosecurity-magazine.com/profile/eleanor-dallaway-1-1-1/"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Infosecurity Magazine Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.wicys.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Women in Cybersecurity Networking Group</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/InfosecEditor"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Eleanor Dallaway on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/eleanordallaway/?originalSubdomain=uk"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Eleanor Dallaway on LinkedIn</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

		<item>
			<title>Avoiding Mentoring Disasters with Mark Timm</title>
			<itunes:title>Avoiding Mentoring Disasters with Mark Timm</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 06 Jan 2021 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3dbfbeca-91f8-4cc1-801f-c4f51bb7ad2a]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/45]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As we start the new year, we often contemplate resolutions and adopting new behaviors into our lives. Good mentoring relationships can have an amazingly powerful impact on both our personal and professional lives, but a bad one can lead to a devastating outcome. Learn how to identify a great match in today’s episode with Mark Timm.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mark Timm has been a serial entrepreneur and exponential thinking practitioner for nearly two decades. He started more than two dozen companies, several of which have multiplied and been sold. His experience with dealing with the entrepreneurial challenges has fueled his passion for teaching people how to balance the demands of family life and business.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:15] - Mark co-wrote the book</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Mentor-Millions-Secrets-Business-Relationships-ebook/dp/B082ZQ84XL"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mentor to Millions</span></em></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">because of his experiences (good and bad) with mentors. He describes how he met the friend he wrote the book with.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:32] - Where mentorship goes bad is when you think you have found the right person due to their success.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:28] - The first thing to look for in a mentor is to ask them about their failures. You want a mentor who is not only a big success story.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:17] - The second thing to look for in a mentor is their ability to really listen. A good mentor will listen and learn about you in order to help you down the right path.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:58] - The third thing to look for is a mentor who has a mentor themselves. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>As we start the new year, we often contemplate resolutions and adopting new behaviors into our lives. Good mentoring relationships can have an amazingly powerful impact on both our personal and professional lives, but a bad one can lead to a devastating outcome. Learn how to identify a great match in today’s episode with Mark Timm.</p> <p>Mark Timm has been a serial entrepreneur and exponential thinking practitioner for nearly two decades. He started more than two dozen companies, several of which have multiplied and been sold. His experience with dealing with the entrepreneurial challenges has fueled his passion for teaching people how to balance the demands of family life and business.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li>[1:15] - Mark co-wrote the book <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Mentor-Millions-Secrets-Business-Relationships-ebook/dp/B082ZQ84XL"> <em>Mentor to Millions</em></a> because of his experiences (good and bad) with mentors. A good mentor will listen and learn about you in order to help you down the right path.</li> <li>[4:58] - The third thing to look for is a mentor who has a mentor themselves. Are you ready to be coached and taught?</li> <li>[11:59] - You already know everyone you need to know in order to accomplish everything that you need to accomplish in this world. 			<title>Protecting Your Business with Dr. Mary C. Kelly</title>

As business professionals, we need to learn how to choose who to be in partnerships with so that we are able to protect ourselves and our businesses from lawsuits and poor decisions.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest today is Mary Kelly. Dr. Mary C. Kelly has many titles, but her favorite is as a teacher. She is focused on teaching professionals to navigate the economy, build their business, be a true leader, and get more done. Mary has authored thirteen books on business leadership and today she is sharing with us a few ways not to be easy prey in business.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:05] - Dr. Kelly primarily works as a corporate speaker and advisor to improve profit growth. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[1:44] - Businesses need to make sure that they are protecting themselves against people who want to sue them for stupid things.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[2:31] - When you are interviewing someone coming into your business, you have to be careful of the questions you ask. </span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[3:12] - Dr. Kelly also points out the importance of keeping your brick and mortar location safe and secure.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[4:22] - Mary shares an example of campsites getting sued by people who were taking advantage of the owners.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[6:01] - In 2020, vulnerabilities became more apparent to business owners.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[8:48] - As a business, one of the number one things people want to know is if you can deliver what you say you can deliver.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[9:06] - Dr. Kelly gives several tips for businesses including Google searching yourself and watching your Yelp reviews.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[11:08] - Mary references a book that she co-wrote regarding trust in the business world. How you build trust with your employees is how they build trust with your clients.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[12:29] - Chris shares how he approaches business partners.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[14:10] - Mary admits to some early mistakes she made after taking the advice of someone else that cost her in thousands of dollars.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[16:01] - Don’t be afraid to differentiate and brand yourself for the core values of your business. Let people know what your core values are.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[17:49] - Your posts on social media are being looked at. It is your job to stay in touch with your client in a way that adds value and trust.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[33:09] - Dr. Kelly wrote a book about business during Covid-19 and shares a lot of her research that can benefit current businesses.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[34:29] - Mary shares current scams for businesses during Covid-19 and how common they are.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[35:29] - There are several car dealership scams going on at the moment as well and Mary describes what this looks like.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[36:57] - If you sign anything, take a picture of it.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[37:49] - Chris shares another current scam that has been very common lately with overcharging customers as their business practice.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[39:17] - We need to not be afraid to ask clients for referrals and feedback.</span></li> <li><span style="font-weight: 400;">[41:37] - When it comes to mistakes, own up to them and move on. Mary shares her free productivity sheet that she uses every single day to help avoid mistakes.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Fraud Detection with Traci Brown</title>
			<itunes:title>Fraud Detection with Traci Brown</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 16 Dec 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[50033542-0693-4910-b564-ca35b5dbc63e]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/42]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our body can give clues to what we are thinking or feeling and review of what we’re saying is the truth or deception. How can we use that fact to detect when</span> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">others</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">are being deceptive?</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Traci Brown. Time magazine has named Traci as one of the nation’s top deception detection experts. She’s trained alongside the country’s top law enforcement, and she is a frequent television guest and the author of</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Detect-Lies-Fraud-Identity-Theft-ebook/dp/B06X9668WZ"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">How to Detect Lies, Fraud, and Identity Theft Field Guide</span></em></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. Her fraud-spotting learning platform has helped companies stop millions in fraud loss.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li>[0:51] - Traci shares her background as a cyclist and how observing and learning other cyclists behavior and body language led her to eventually become a body language expert.</li> <li>[2:29] - Many had thought that Traci was able to read people’s minds, but really she was just noticing body language.</li> <li>[3:34] - Traci shares how an experience of her brother’s led her to training with law enforcement and started her path in fraud and deception detection.</li> <li>[5:19] - While a lot of attacks happen online, Traci encourages listeners to know about in-person fraud and protect themselves.</li> <li>[6:17] - 40% of people lie in a job interview but only 2% of people hiring them can tell. </li> <li>[6:54] - Traci works with a lot of sales people because “buyers are liars.”</li> <li>[7:43] - Traci has even worked with world renowned poker players. She describes how poker tournaments work and how body language impacts how you feel as well.</li> <li>[9:54] - The number one thing that law enforcement looks at is baseline behavior. Everyone runs in patterns.</li> <li>[10:40] - You want to believe the body first and when there’s a mismatch between the body and the words, that’s the hotspot.</li> <li>[11:47] - Traci lists and describes body language signs that something is not true.</li> <li>[12:55] - As you are talking to someone and notice these signs, Traci suggests saying, “It seems like you have something more to say about that,” and then stop talking. </li> <li>[13:58] - If you ask people questions they have no reason to lie about, then you can see the shift when you ask them something more pressing.</li> <li>[15:19] - Some people can’t help but lie. Some people lie to cope with something trauma or were conditioned to lie in simple conversations.</li> <li>[17:12] - Lying is not just indicated through body language. It is a combination of body language, tone, pacing, volume, and word choice.</li> <li>[18:21] - Everyone is unique in that baseline behavior so you need to know that first.</li> <li>[19:15] - Some people have a nervous baseline that doesn’t necessarily mean they’re lying but that they are just nervous people in general.</li> <li>[20:12] - Traci shares a story about an experience with her husband in the grocery store and how her knowledge of body language can benefit relationships.</li> <li>[22:03] - Security takes full enrollment from your senses at all times.</li> <li>[23:15] - Traci hosts a podcast called Fraud Busting and interviews criminals.</li> <li>[25:01] - Traci refers to presidential debates and how candidates practice their answers ahead of time, but that body language is telling. The answers to questions that are on the spot is where you can tell a lot.</li> <li>[26:30] - Watching a debate with the sound off and not knowing what the candidates are saying is a great way to start noticing body language.</li> <li>[28:03] - Even Chris can tell when a podcast guest is launching into a response that is rehearsed. He asks Traci if that could be an indicator that someone is being deceptive in certain situations.</li> <li>[29:37] - We have the least control over our feet. So watching peoples’ feet can give you a lot of information.</li> <li>[30:54] - Traci describes the “pain” people and businesses pay with when they aren’t paying attention.</li> <li>[31:52] - Know more than is immediately obvious and use it when the time is right. The idea is to make people comfortable around you enough to talk.</li> <li>[33:04] - Traci also can look at social media profiles and can tell a lot about a person before actually meeting them.</li> <li>[35:29] - Traci shares that she watched a video of Paris Hilton describing the abuse at a school she went to as a child and determined that she is telling the truth.</li> <li>[36:21] - Body language is not admissible in court, so using the body language to dig is important.</li> <li>[38:06] - Chris and Traci briefly discuss psychopathic and sociopathic behaviors.</li> <li>[40:07] - The reason Traci started her podcast is because looking back, everyone knows something is not right but didn’t do anything about it. Listen to yourself.</li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ">Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.bodylanguagetrainer.com/">Body Language Trainer - Traci Brown Web Page</a></li> <li><a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/fraud-busting-with-traci-brown/id1506695449"> Fraud Busting Podcast</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/BodyLanguageSpeaker">Fraud Busting Body Language Expert Facebook</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/tracibrown37">Traci Brown on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/bodylanguageexpert1/">Traci Brown on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Detect-Lies-Fraud-Identity-Theft-ebook/dp/B06X9668WZ"> How to Detect Lies, Fraud, and Identity Theft Field Guide</a> by Traci Brown</li> </ul>]]></description>

			<pubDate>Wed, 09 Dec 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[45b2b426-4cc3-4cc8-b06c-150784c254a5]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/41]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Most of us have received that call from someone claiming to be from Microsoft Tech Support saying that there is an issue with our computer that they want to help us resolve. This scam has evolved into something so sophisticated and so refined that it has become big business in and of itself.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Jim Browning. Jim can’t stand scammers, so he’s doing something about it. Jim has been baiting, investigating, and exposing scammers on his YouTube channel for over 5 years. His channel now has over 2.3 million subscribers and many of his videos showing how these scams work have been watched millions of times. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[0:51] - Most people recognize tech support scams as a cold call where the scammer claims they are working for a company that needs you to get on your computer to gain access.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:34] - Jim says the way to put these people off is to deny having the device they are asking for you to connect.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:13] - These types of scammers might also claim they are your bank or credit card company. Either way, this scam is all about logging into your account and giving them access.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:32] - Jim describes what would happen if a scammer gains access to your computer after you follow the steps they give you over the phone.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:01] - Jim never intended to be a YouTuber. In fact, he has a “proper” job in IT and is an engineer at heart. But as someone who received these calls, he became curious and one day recorded what a scammer did.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:23] - More often than not, the people running these scams are out of a different country and it is near impossible to do anything about it through law enforcement.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:21] - Jim shares that India’s equivalent to the FBI has recently conducted raids and some of these operations may actually be dealt with.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:27] - Through running scams, Jim describes how one operation brought in over a million dollars per month and employed several hundred people.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:19] - When hiring, these operations may hire people who don’t know they’re scammers. Some, though, actually advertise that they are scammers.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:27] - With enough computer knowledge and the curiosity, Jim let scammers access his computer but was able to reverse it and gain access to their computer instead.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:31] - Jim tells a story about how he accessed a scammer’s CCTV recording and was able to see and hear how they are running their operation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:12] - These scammers take the business very seriously and professionally. Like legitimate organizations, they record calls and use them to train their employees.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:39] - Sometimes scammers will retain the access to the computer, but most of the time, they will get their one-off payment and it will likely be the last time you hear from them or you won’t hear from them for a while.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:56] - If you are scammed once, your information will be sold to other scammers. Once you’ve been victimized, you are far more likely to fall victim again.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:10] - The cold calls are the most common, but a more subtle scam is to Google for genuine support. Some sites are not genuine and many people do not check the legitimacy of the site.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:27] - There are various software you can install on your computer that help identify a site that is not legitimate.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:14] - If you think you are a victim of a scam, you need to start by contacting your bank or credit card company as quickly as possible. If it has been several months, it is very hard to get your money back.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:40] - The most safe thing to do if you fall victim of a scam is to completely wipe your computer and start over. But Jim does state that most of the time, scammers are only in it for a one-off payment so you might not need to do that.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:01] - Jim has also seen scammers take identities to open up bank accounts in order to launder money.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:46] - There are scams that ask for gift cards, which is as good as cash in most cases. If you use a gift card or read out a gift card number, you will not get your money back.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:40] - No legitimate online business is going to ask for gift cards and is a big red flag. The big one right now are Amazon gift cards.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:52] - A lot of employees who sell gift cards are trained to ask the customer who is buying large denominations on a gift card to ask if they have been put up to it. But Jim gives examples about how scammers get around this.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:55] - Scamming organizations have also recruited people in the US and the UK to be a part of these scams to make it more believable because of their lack of foreign accent.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:42] - Scammers have been known to cunningly coach people into willingly transferring money to them.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:40] - No legitimate company will ever have a problem with you asking questions. Be a skeptic.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:44] - Another red flag for a scam is urgency to take action. Always stop and ask questions and call them on the number you know is accurate.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:28] - Anyone can forge a number. You cannot trust the caller ID. But there is something possibly happening in the United States that will help identify real numbers.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:49] - Jim’s YouTube channel shows how scams work and can help you recognize when a call could be a scam. His YouTube channel’s mission is to bring awareness.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCBNG0osIBAprVcZZ3ic84vw"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Jim Browning on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/JimBrowning11"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Jim Browning on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking with Ed Skoudis</title>
			<itunes:title>Penetration Testing and Ethical Hacking with Ed Skoudis</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 02 Dec 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[19883b33-a37a-44a3-b61a-43b9348d39b5]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/40]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Is there such a thing as an ethical hacker? Do all hackers use their skills to attack infrastructures? If you’re interested in ethical hacking and penetration testing, this is the episode for you. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Ed Skoudis. Ed has taught upwards of 20,000 security professionals globally and his contributions to information security have had an immense impact on the community. His courses distill the essence of real world frontline case studies he accumulates, because he is consistently one of the first authorities brought in to provide post-attack analysis on major breeches. He’s not just an expert in the field, he’s created many of the founding methodologies empowered by governments and organizations around the world to test and secure their infrastructures.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ed is the founder of the SANS Penetration Testing Curriculum and Counter Hack; leads the team that builds NetWars, Holiday Hack, and CyberCity; and serves on the Board of Directors for the SANS Technology Institute. A consummate presenter, Ed is a keynote speaker appearing internationally at conferences, and is an Advisory Board member for RSA.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:14] - Ed introduces himself as a penetration tester and hacker. He does expert witness work on large scale breeches and incident response.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:37] - He started this path as hacking for phone companies. He explains how he started and why he was hired.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:55] - Ed describes what penetration testing (or pen testing) is. It is when he models the techniques used by real world attackers and then apply them in structured fashion to help protect companies from future attacks.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:53] - Pen tests can be used by an organization for a specific reason or can be done as a “check-up” to make sure everything is okay.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:40] - Zero Day is researching vulnerabilities that aren’t known yet. It is called Zero Day because it has been known for zero days.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:18] - Ed never believed the cybersecurity industry would be as huge as it is today and explains some of the more recent issues we’ve been seeing through Covid.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:52] - Security is now a part of the process and is becoming less of an afterthought. Ed shares this idea long-term, but sees the same vulnerabilities repeatedly.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:49] - There is no such thing as 100% safe and secure. The goal is to raise the bar to make things more difficult for an attacker.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:31] - With ransomware, attackers have figured out a really reliable way to get paid for their malware.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:08] - Ransomware is a real problem and have even attacked hospitals and local governments.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:37] - There is so much that we do that leaves us vulnerable.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:29] - One major piece of advice that Ed gives in regards to general consumer security is to keep all of your devices patched and updated.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:18] - Another area to be aware of is always spear phishing. Don’t click unless you are confident in the link.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:19] - Ed has a separate computer that is separate and independent that he</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">only</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">uses for financial transactions. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:17] - Chris and Ed discuss routers that consumers buy from their ISP.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:01] - Ed shares how “Live Off the Land” attacks work by using what is already installed on a computer. These are harder to detect.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:18] - With ransomware, organizations have to think about what is best for the business. Is it better to give the attacker the money or spend the time and money to fix the problem?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:27] - The dominant trend in technology today is cloud storage.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:18] - Ed describes how this works and some of the various problems associated with it.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:39] - The US Army, Tesla, and Uber are a few organizations that have lost data to this common vulnerability.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:10] - Ed describes the Holiday Hack Challenge and the fun way he has modeled this problem to educate users.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:03] - Although there are some security risks if not managed properly, Ed shares that cloud data storage is a very cost effective option for small to medium sized businesses.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:24] - Most organizations use multiple cloud services. Cloud migration is good if a different service is necessary, but the previous cloud service is left alone and vulnerable.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:01] - The Holiday Hack Challenge is a free educational event that Ed and his team have created to solve cybersecurity challenges. This is a worldwide event.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:02] - The Holiday Hack Challenge is something that some people participate in with their kids due to the video game aspect. There is also a social aspect to it with the chat feature.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:29] - Not only is the Holiday Hack Challenge free, but all of the past challenges are free and accessible to play. This can build your skills.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:30] - Chris asks if Holiday Hack Challenge has ever been compromised. Ed admits that there are three people who have hacked their way in as players, but there were no purposeful attacks.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:43] - Ed admits that he sees the world through the eyes of an ethical hacker because he likes to explore and see what’s beyond the edges. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[40:48] - Chris and Ed discuss Bug Bounty Programs and can be useful.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span
