"https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.sans.org/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">SANS Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.counterhack.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Counter Hack Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/edskoudis?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Ed Skoudis on Twitter</span></a></li> <li Ed has taught upwards of 20,000 security professionals globally and his contributions to information security have had an immense impact on the community. His courses distill the essence of real world frontline case studies he accumulates, because he is consistently one of the first authorities brought in to provide post-attack analysis on major breeches. He’s not just an expert in the field, he’s created many of the founding methodologies empowered by governments and organizations around the world to test and secure their infrastructures.</p> <p>Ed is the founder of the SANS Penetration Testing Curriculum and Counter Hack; leads the team that builds NetWars, Holiday Hack, and CyberCity; and serves on the Board of Directors for the SANS Technology Institute. A consummate presenter, Ed is a keynote speaker appearing internationally at conferences, and is an Advisory Board member for RSA.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[1:14] - Ed introduces himself as a penetration tester and hacker. He does expert witness work on large scale breeches and incident response.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[1:37] - He started this path as hacking for phone companies. He explains how he started and why he was hired.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[3:55] - Ed describes what penetration testing (or pen testing) is. It is when he models the techniques used by real world attackers and then apply them in structured fashion to help protect companies from future attacks.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[4:53] - Pen tests can be used by an organization for a specific reason or can be done as a “check-up” to make sure everything is okay.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[5:40] - Zero Day is researching vulnerabilities that aren’t known yet. It is called Zero Day because it has been known for zero days.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[6:18] - Ed never believed the cybersecurity industry would be as huge as it is today and explains some of the more recent issues we’ve been seeing through Covid.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[7:52] - Security is now a part of the process and is becoming less of an afterthought. Ed shares this idea long-term, but sees the same vulnerabilities repeatedly.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[8:49] - There is no such thing as 100% safe and secure. The goal is to raise the bar to make things more difficult for an attacker.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[9:31] - With ransomware, attackers have figured out a really reliable way to get paid for their malware.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[10:08] - Ransomware is a real problem and have even attacked hospitals and local governments.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[12:37] - There is so much that we do that leaves us vulnerable.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[13:29] - One major piece of advice that Ed gives in regards to general consumer security is to keep all of your devices patched and updated.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:18] - Another area to be aware of is always spear phishing. Don’t click unless you are confident in the link.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[15:19] - Ed has a separate computer that is separate and independent that he <em>only</em> uses for financial transactions. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:17] - Chris and Ed discuss routers that consumers buy from their ISP.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:01] - Ed shares how “Live Off the Land” attacks work by using what is already installed on a computer. These are harder to detect.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[20:18] - With ransomware, organizations have to think about what is best for the business. Is it better to give the attacker the money or spend the time and money to fix the problem?</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:27] - The dominant trend in technology today is cloud storage.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:18] - Ed describes how this works and some of the various problems associated with it.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:39] - The US Army, Tesla, and Uber are a few organizations that have lost data to this common vulnerability.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:10] - Ed describes the Holiday Hack Challenge and the fun way he has modeled this problem to educate users.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[28:03] - Although there are some security risks if not managed properly, Ed shares that cloud data storage is a very cost effective option for small to medium sized businesses.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:24] - Most organizations use multiple cloud services. Cloud migration is good if a different service is necessary, but the previous cloud service is left alone and vulnerable.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[31:01] - The Holiday Hack Challenge is a free educational event that Ed and his team have created to solve cybersecurity challenges. This is a worldwide event.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[34:02] - The Holiday Hack Challenge is something that some people participate in with their kids due to the video game aspect. There is also a social aspect to it with the chat feature.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[35:29] - Not only is the Holiday Hack Challenge free, but all of the past challenges are free and accessible to play. This can build your skills.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[36:30] - Chris asks if Holiday Hack Challenge has ever been compromised. Ed admits that there are three people who have hacked their way in as players, but there were no purposeful attacks.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[39:43] - Ed admits that he sees the world through the eyes of an ethical hacker because he likes to explore and see what’s beyond the edges. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[40:48] - Chris and Ed discuss Bug Bounty Programs and can be useful.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.sans.org/">SANS Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.counterhack.com/">Counter Hack Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/edskoudis?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> Ed Skoudis on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://holidayhackchallenge.com/2020/">2020 Holiday Hack Challenge</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Charity Scams with Michael Thatcher and Zachary Weinsteiger</title>
			<itunes:title>Charity Scams with Michael Thatcher and Zachary Weinsteiger</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 25 Nov 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[1c87ee34-d15f-43ce-8f38-fb70b9c3d2ce]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/39]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">With Giving Tuesday right around the corner, it is important to make sure that the money we give gets to the causes we are passionate about. In the midst of the season of giving, scammers are working to get as much of your charity as they can.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guests are Michael Thatcher and Zachary Weinsteiger. Michael leads</span> <a href= "https://www.charitynavigator.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Charity Navigator</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and its efforts to make impactful philanthropy easier for all by increasing the breadth and depth of ratings coverage of a large number of charities. He has held various board positions within the non-profit and tech sector, holds several patents in enterprise systems management, and has a degree from Columbia University in New York. Zachary is on Charity Navigator’s analyst team and is responsible for data collection, research analysis, and the evaluation of the performance of America’s largest charities. He also works towards improving the evaluation system and process.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:16] - Michael has been with Charity Navigator for about 5 years, but previously worked for Microsoft. He was attracted to Charity Navigator to make a more positive impact.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:04] - Zachary initially intended on being an educator on the college level, but during the course of study he felt that he wanted to do more. He wound up with Charity Navigator after hearing someone speak at his graduation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:53] - Charity Navigator was started in the early 2000’s by someone who was wealthy and wanted to donate money. He noticed that there was no way to evaluate the organizations he would invest in, so he started it himself.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:42] - Michael shares how large the non-profit and charity sector is in the United States.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:10] - On one hand, there are several successfully run charities, but then there are some that fall apart.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:42] - Michael started working in the non-profit sector when he opened a dance company with his wife. Unfortunately, it failed, but now he has found himself in a similar position running Charity Navigator.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:03] - The hardest part about charity scams is that they’re scams and until they get caught, we don’t know they’re scams.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:32] - Zachary says that sometimes the donors might not actually know they were scammed and move forward without knowing.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:43] - If you feel like you have been scammed, you need to report it, regardless of the feeling of embarrassment that many people feel.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:04] - Look for transparency. Legitimate charities will have a website and will be able to direct you over the phone to a way to find out more about them.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:10] - Be intentional with your giving. Donate to causes that you care about and find out if the charity in question is on Charity Navigator.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:29] - During times of crisis, people change their giving philosophy. This year, the United States has seen different crises and people may be donating to charities they don’t normally notice.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:21] - Charity Navigator has a relationship with GoFundMe and Michael says it is a legitimate, strong, and successfully run crowd-funding site. But if you don’t know the person and have a real relationship with that person, you need to be wary.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:04] - What Zachary notices with GoFundMe is when individuals donate to others they don’t know, there’s no form of accountability.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:09] - There are organizations that are a good filter to avoid fabricated stories on GoFundMe. Michael shares them as</span> <a href="https://www.givedirectly.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Give Directly</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and</span> <a href= "https://www.donorschoose.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Donors Choose</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:39] - When you donate to charities through Give Directly and Donors Choose instead of GoFundMe, you can use them as a tax write off. When you donate to an individual on GoFundMe, you cannot.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:08] - One of the key things that Charity Navigator looks for is strong financial performance. Michael describes what this looks like and why it is important.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:41] - Another important facet that Charity Navigator looks for to establish their ratings is the charity’s level of transparency and governance.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:33] - Overhead costs are not a bad thing. The salaries of the people that work with the charity organizations are important too. Charity Navigator looks at this as well.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:02] - Michael dives into the way their rating system works and what a rating could mean.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:19] - There really isn’t a one-size-fits-all that works in this space. Michael compares a charity that supports an orchestra versus an organization for a homeless shelter. Charity Navigator does not cross compare.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:36] - Charity Navigator is the largest independent evaluator of charities in the US and has been around for 20 years.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:14] - Charity Navigator has a team of only 26 people to maintain a small business feel and keep their costs low as well. Each analyst is assigned a specific type of charity that they themselves care about. Zachary explains how this works.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:25] - Another thing Charity Navigator sees frequently is when costs disappear. Zachary explains how this works and how it goes into an evaluation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:53] - Charity Navigator uses the form charities fill out to establish and maintain the organization. This creates uniformity, consistency, and gives them a way to determine if a charity is being truthful.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:42] - Michael explains how and why the end of the year sees an increase in donations and traffic to their site.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[41:18] - Scams pop up during this time of year as well because scammers know that people are in a rush and are in an emotionally driven time to give.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[43:13] - Charity Navigator has a feature called The Giving Basket which allows you to donate to an organization through their website. This is a very safe way to make a donation to make sure it goes directly to the right place.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:55] - Before you give, do your research. Slow down and look at everything you can find about the organization.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[45:39] - Think of your giving as an investment and follow the money. Stay connected to the non-profits you give to because you are investing in the changes they bring to the world.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelthatcher/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Michael Thatcher on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= 			<itunes:subtitle><![CDATA[With Giving Tuesday right around the corner, it is important to make sure that the money we give gets to the causes we are passionate about. In the midst of the season of giving, scammers are working to get as much of your charity as they can....]]></itunes:subtitle>

			<title>Psychological Security with Adam Anderson</title>
			<itunes:title>Psychological Security with Adam Anderson</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 18 Nov 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[514f00dd-f5f1-4090-933e-caf08cdf8fc7]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/38]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As cybercrime grows more sophisticated day by day, so do technical defenses. But great technology is no match for an employee clicking on a simple phishing email. Psychological security is designed to protect the human mind from manipulation that leads to compromises.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today’s guest is Adam Anderson. Adam is chairman of the board for Hook Security and a serial cybersecurity entrepreneur. He is one of the founders of the Psychological Security Movement. Psychological Security or “Psy-Sec,” was born to create new technologies and processes to help build resilient human minds that can resist manipulations through technology.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400; font-size: 14pt;">Show Notes:</span></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:10] - Adam introduces himself as a serial cybersecurity entrepreneur who has launched 21 companies over 20 years. He is passionate about this topic.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:24] - The human part of cybersecurity is always the weakest link.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:01] - Chris and Adam discuss how when you work in IT, you look at things through an IT lens, but there is a human side.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:21] - Security is typically an afterthought that comes after an incident.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:51] - Adam breaks down the meaning of security and what types you will see within a company or corporation as being physical security and info security.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:42] - Adam says that both types of security are vulnerable to social engineering.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:31] - Hook Security was created after Adam worked in frustration for 20 years. He is chairman of the board and hired a successful educator as CEO who is an expert in how people learn.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:23] - Adam is a firm believer that “Psy-Sec” needs to be a separate department of professionals who can work to build resilience in human brains to resist manipulation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:15] - It is unreasonable to expect the IT department to be proficient in the human interface as it is not in their skillset.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:42] - Adam states that systems are 95% safe from compromise which is a great improvement, but when you have a large company, 5% is still too much.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:12] - Right now, Adam is working with the cognitive brain function and explains the details on how this works in regards to psychological security.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:10] - There are two ways to lay down memories and “fight or flight.” One is through fear and one is through humor.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:27] - People are better at remembering something that made them laugh and Adam trains people with this in mind.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:26] - Hook Security provides Security Awareness Training that people actually enjoy.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:06] - Hook Security is being very careful with how they present their findings and taking their time with the science elements involved so that it is used for good and not as a tool for attackers.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:54] - Social engineering is no different from simple marketing. Marketing is there to show you something that you may find valuable and hope that you click on it. Social engineering is the same, but “with a different punch line.”</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:56] - There’s a database. You’re in it. You are a product. If you are getting something for free or are paying something low, you are the product. Adam uses a Netflix example to demonstrate this.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:52] - With the way YouTube and Netflix work, you are trusting big corporations to have your best interests at heart.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:52] - We are all wired to help others. These hard-wired responses allow marketers and attackers to take advantage.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:16] - Chris and Adam discuss that the way marketing works is not a bad thing because they want to see the recommendations based on their interests. But they can be used negatively.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:39] - Fake news and “echo chambers” that we find ourselves in are designed to polarize people to different extremes.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:02] - Just like marketers who know who they are targeting to sell to, cybercriminals know what your triggers are to manipulate you into a compromising situation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:46] - There are different types of triggers that cause us to fall for scams.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:08] - These triggers are wonderful when they happen organically and to help others but are terrifying when they are used against us.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:53] - Learning how to pause and evaluating whether something is true or not is crucial. If you can’t do that, Adam says to “reprogram your auto-pilot.”</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:14] - Your perception of the phone is that it is something that you get a lot of value from but it is also a place where people will call you and text you with fraudulent stuff. Some people can pause and question it and some cannot.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[38:12] - We all have blind spots and we don’t know what they are, so always have a support system to get others’ opinions on the matter before making certain choices.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:50] - It is imperative that we treat this seriously. We are throwing a burden on our “nerds” by having them try to understand the nuances of the human brain.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[41:39] - None of this science is new. We just need to apply it.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://hooksecurity.co/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Hook Security</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/adamandersonceo"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Adam Anderson on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCw2cDTARaFfLRFmygOMTO4w"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Adam Anderson on YouTube</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>The Life of a Cybercriminal with Brett Johnson</title>
			<itunes:title>The Life of a Cybercriminal with Brett Johnson</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 11 Nov 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[fc4b179b-7ad4-4d61-b779-8fdf397d3b55]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/37]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">What is it like to be a world-renowned cybercriminal and what motivates them? Today’s guest referred to as the original internet Godfather shares his experience running a cybercriminal empire, going on the run, and ultimately turning his life around.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Brett Johnson was responsible for refining modern financial cybercrime as we know it today. After being placed on the United States’ Most Wanted list, captured and convicted of 39 felonies, Brett promptly escaped prison. Captured again, Brett served his time, accepted responsibility, and found redemption through his loved ones and the help of the FBI.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today he is considered a leading authority on internet crime, identity theft, and cybersecurity. Brett speaks and consults around the world to help protect people and organizations from the type of person he used to be.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:11] - Brett starts telling his story by summing up why he got the title, “The Original Internet Godfather.” What really got him the title was him building the first organized cybercrime community called ShadowCrew.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:24] - Brett ran both ShadowCrew and CounterfeitLibrary. The other primary cybercrime site that he did not run was CarderPlanet.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:14] - ShadowCrew and CounterfeitLibrary were run like forums and marketplaces to connect and network with other criminals.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:37] - Brett was arrested in 2005 and was offered a job to work with the Secret Service, but chose to continue pursuing criminal activity and eventually made his way onto the United States Most Wanted List.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:40] - Secret Service used a Trigger Fish, now called a Stingray, which locates targeted cell phones in a specific area. This device was used to find Brett at Disney World and to arrest him.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:37] - Brett shares the experience of his car and house being searched and how his choices got him caught.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:54] - Brett’s tendency to break the law started when he was 10 years old and his mom was also a criminal. He shares a lot of his childhood background in shoplifting.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:13] - Although he started shoplifting as a child, Brett says that as an adult, he made the choice to continue criminal activity.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:32] - Brett’s first cybercrime was on eBay by posting a Beanie Baby for sale, requiring the buyer to send a money order that couldn’t be canceled, and sent her an item that did not match the post.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:07] - Brett kept going and his eBay crimes led to pirated software, which led to modchips, which led to programming satellite DSS cards.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:40] - After bringing in several thousand dollars per week under his real name, Brett got scared he would get caught, so he shares his story about getting a fake ID to open a bank account.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:17] - Brett’s fear of being abandoned became a reality when his wife left him.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:36] - Brett remarried a stripper who was an addict. Through all of his crimes, his second marriage caused his sister to disown him.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:06] - It took several years of not speaking to his sister and justifying his actions for Brett to realize that he was in prison because he</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">chose</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">to break the law.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:08] - For three after being released from prison on probation in 2011, he couldn’t get a job because he wasn’t allowed to use a computer.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:13] - Brett met his current wife during this time and moved in with her. He was able to find a job doing yard work.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:00] - Although he was doing better, during the winter months when there was no yard work to do, he got online to find stolen credit card information and started making orders. He went back to prison for 10 months.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:24] - After his 10 months, he got married, and started to turn his life around. He contacted an FBI agent for job advice and now he feels he is living a blessed life.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:40] - Now Brett does a lot of consulting and hosts a few podcasts. He also works with AARP and other types of organizations.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:19] - A big misconception people have about cybercriminals is that they are very educated and can hack into anything. But 98% of cybercriminals out there are really good social engineers and know-how to manipulate someone using technology and psychology.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:56] - The number 1 group for identity theft is children.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:51] - Most people use the same password across multiple accounts. Brett says to always use a password manager.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:38] - The reason a scam works is because the scammer and the victim are on opposite sides of the field. The scammer works to get the victim to his side by establishing trust through technology and social engineering.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:36] - How good is the scammer at establishing trust with a victim using the technology they have?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:09] - The scammer’s job is to make sure the victim is not thinking objectively.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:50] - People like to trust. Generally, people like to see the best in people. Brett says to trust, but verify.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:08] - In his experience as a consultant, Brett has found that most victims suspect something might be a scam but alienate themselves from telling anyone out of embarrassment as society tends to blame the victim.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[42:16] - Chris asks Brett when a scammer stops caring about the victims and only cares about the money. Brett answers that it depends on whether or not the scammer is a sociopath. He says that most scammers are not and come to believe their own justifications.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:18] - There’s no beneficial thing about being a criminal.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:50] - Be proactive, not reactive, when it comes to security.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>What is it like to be a world-renowned cybercriminal and what motivates them? Today’s guest referred to as the original internet Godfather shares his experience running a cybercriminal empire, going on the run, and ultimately turning his life around.</p> <p>Brett Johnson was responsible for refining modern financial cybercrime as we know it today. After being placed on the United States’ Most Wanted list, captured and convicted of 39 felonies, Brett promptly escaped prison. Captured again, Brett served his time, accepted responsibility, and found redemption through his loved ones and the help of the FBI.</p> <p>Today he is considered a leading authority on internet crime, identity theft, and cybersecurity. Brett speaks and consults around the world to help protect people and organizations from the type of person he used to be.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[1:11] - Brett starts telling his story by summing up why he got the title, “The Original Internet Godfather.” What really got him the title was him building the first organized cybercrime community called ShadowCrew.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[2:24] - Brett ran both ShadowCrew and CounterfeitLibrary. The other primary cybercrime site that he did not run was CarderPlanet.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[3:14] - ShadowCrew and CounterfeitLibrary were run like forums and marketplaces to connect and network with other criminals.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[4:37] - Brett was arrested in 2005 and was offered a job to work with the Secret Service, but chose to continue pursuing criminal activity and eventually made his way onto the United States Most Wanted List.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[5:40] - Secret Service used a Trigger Fish, now called a Stingray, which locates targeted cell phones in a specific area. This device was used to find Brett at Disney World and to arrest him.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[7:37] - Brett shares the experience of his car and house being searched and how his choices got him caught.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[9:54] - Brett’s tendency to break the law started when he was 10 years old and his mom was also a criminal. He shares a lot of his childhood background in shoplifting.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[12:13] - Although he started shoplifting as a child, Brett says that as an adult, he made the choice to continue criminal activity.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[13:32] - Brett’s first cybercrime was on eBay by posting a Beanie Baby for sale, requiring the buyer to send a money order that couldn’t be canceled, and sent her an item that did not match the post.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:07] - Brett kept going and his eBay crimes led to pirated software, which led to modchips, which led to programming satellite DSS cards.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:40] - After bringing in several thousand dollars per week under his real name, Brett got scared he would get caught, so he shares his story about getting a fake ID to open a bank account.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:17] - Brett’s fear of being abandoned became a reality when his wife left him.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:36] - Brett remarried a stripper who was an addict. Through all of his crimes, his second marriage caused his sister to disown him.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:06] - It took several years of not speaking to his sister and justifying his actions for Brett to realize that he was in prison because he <em>chose</em> to break the law.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:08] - For three after being released from prison on probation in 2011, he couldn’t get a job because he wasn’t allowed to use a computer.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:13] - Brett met his current wife during this time and moved in with her. He was able to find a job doing yard work.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:00] - Although he was doing better, during the winter months when there was no yard work to do, he got online to find stolen credit card information and started making orders. He went back to prison for 10 months.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:24] - After his 10 months, he got married, and started to turn his life around. He contacted an FBI agent for job advice and now he feels he is living a blessed life.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:40] - Now Brett does a lot of consulting and hosts a few podcasts. He also works with AARP and other types of organizations.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[28:19] - A big misconception people have about cybercriminals is that they are very educated and can hack into anything. But 98% of cybercriminals out there are really good social engineers and know-how to manipulate someone using technology and psychology.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:56] - The number 1 group for identity theft is children.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[30:51] - Most people use the same password across multiple accounts. Brett says to always use a password manager.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[32:38] - The reason a scam works is because the scammer and the victim are on opposite sides of the field. The scammer works to get the victim to his side by establishing trust through technology and social engineering.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[34:36] - How good is the scammer at establishing trust with a victim using the technology they have?</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[37:09] - The scammer’s job is to make sure the victim is not thinking objectively.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[37:50] - People like to trust. Generally, people like to see the best in people. Brett says to trust, but verify.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[39:08] - In his experience as a consultant, Brett has found that most victims suspect something might be a scam but alienate themselves from telling anyone out of embarrassment as society tends to blame the victim.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[42:16] - Chris asks Brett when a scammer stops caring about the victims and only cares about the money. Brett answers that it depends on whether or not the scammer is a sociopath. He says that most scammers are not and come to believe their own justifications.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[44:18] - There’s no beneficial thing about being a criminal.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[44:50] - Be proactive, not reactive, when it comes to security.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.anglerphish.com/">AnglerPhish Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/GOllumfun?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> Brett Johnson on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/gollumfun">Brett Johnson on LinkedIn</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Embezzlement with Kelly Paxton</title>
			<itunes:title>Embezzlement with Kelly Paxton</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 04 Nov 2020 11:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c02d6e4f-0dbb-4172-9c14-a17baec0703b]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/embezzlement-with-kelly-paxton/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Embezzlement is on the rise, but only a  few incidents ever get reported to law enforcement. Why do people steal and how are they doing it? What can business owners do to help prevent these crimes and what should they do if they suspect them?</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest today is Kelly Paxton. She has more than 25 years of investigation experience and is a certified fraud examiner and private investigator. She started her career in law enforcement as a special agent for the US Customs Office of Investigation in 1993. She has worked white-collar crime, fraud, money laundering, embezzlement, and conflict of interest cases. Kelly is also the proud owner of Pink Collar Crime, a passion of hers about embezzlers in the workplace.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:02] - Kelly has always been interested in money. She started her career in finance but had a client arrested for fraud. She then became interested in investigating why people steal money.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:57] - Kelly’s goal is never to put someone in jail. Her goal is to find out why the person stole the money and to hopefully see the money returned to the victim.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:32] - Why do people steal money? Generally speaking, Kelly says most people will steal because they think that money will help them fix their problems.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:51] - Most people are good people, but life happens, and most people think money fixes it.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:11] - Embezzlement is stealing money from business. Kelly defines Pink Collar Crime as petty amounts stolen by low to mid-level employees, primarily women, from the workplace. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:40] - In the 80s, this was a shift in thinking. Up until then, most people hadn’t thought about embezzlement as a common crime.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:17] - Kelly explains that in embezzlement cases, there is a lot of victim shaming. Due to this, only 15% of embezzlement cases are reported to law enforcement.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:01] - Most victims</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">like</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">the employee and that is how the employee is able to steal. Trust is not an internal control.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:46] - 60%, or 3 out 5, of all dentists have been ripped off.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:13] - Kelly calls embezzlement “the crime of main street.”</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:01] - Financial audits are not always when losses are noticed. Tips and hotlines are actually more effective in finding out about these problems.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:06] - 90% of bookkeepers in the United States are women. Women push back against the title “Pink Collar Crime,” but should be pushing back that women are in lower-level positions as a whole.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:30] - Kelly shares an example of a woman who stole millions of dollars over 20 years. When she was arrested, she was exhausted because she could never take a vacation as she was afraid of being caught.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:48] - Another warning sign is a control freak, especially when it comes to changing computer programs.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:53] - The number one way people embezzle from the workplace is forged or unauthorized checks.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:28] - It is never good to be ripped off, but there are good things that come from it, including connections with other people and lessons learned on how to manage the business moving forward.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:36] - The principle doesn’t pay the principal, meaning the principle of being ripped off doesn’t pay the loss.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:16] - At the end of the day, you have to get back to work. The money is replaceable. The trust is difficult to get over.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:00] - Intuitively, you trust a coworker more than you trust a stranger. So you won’t always see this coming.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:41] - Trust but verify. Kelly uses an example of trusting your dentist when you have a cavity.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:47] - If you are a small business owner, Kelly recommends that you mail your bank statements mailed to your home or to a P.O. Box that only you can control.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:27] - Always look at the images of the checks on your online bank statements.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:49] - Mix up when you check things. Check different size checks, audit your own finances at different times of the year. Keep everyone guessing so they don’t see a pattern that they can take advantage of.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:10] - Kelly also suggests that you have a binder or system of some sort that outlines everything in the event that you need to show details in a case.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:23] - Business owners don’t generally look at all the checks going in and out of the business. Some business owners even have pre-signed blank checks to make tasks easier, but puts them at risk of fraud.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:01] - Kelly would rather train business owners to help prevent these events than to sit across from someone she is investigating as a criminal.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:48] - Kelly shares an example of one of the craziest cases she worked.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:18] - If someone starts at a business and if they steal within the first 6 months of working there, they’ve done it before. They may not have a criminal history or have not been caught yet.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:45] - If you walk into your house and you see a dead body, you call the police and you don’t touch anything. Unfortunately, with embezzlement, when a business owner notices something wrong, they go in and try to figure things out themselves and oftentimes mess up the crime scene.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:46] - Kelly is writing a book, but admits that it will be an ebook because most people won’t go into a bookstore to buy a book about embezzlement. This can be seen as embarrassing.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:07] - If you have proof of embezzlement, most of the time the employee will confess when confronted. But you need to be prepared and never confront them alone. Kelly recommends having a lawyer with you as a reliable witness.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[42:16] - The more people who have access to the information, the less likely the crime will happen.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[43:13] - There is no CSI Embezzlement. These cases take an extremely long time.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:40] - Law enforcement has limited resources and will need to put their focus on different types of cases due to the length of time and investigation needed to work on these cases. As a business owner, you will need to spend a lot of money to have things investigated.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[46:10] - There is also a level of embarrassment when things like this happen. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[48:42] - There’s not a national database of arrests and convictions. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span 			<title>Surveillance and Digital Rights with Danny O’Brien</title>
			<itunes:title>Surveillance and Digital Rights with Danny O’Brien</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 28 Oct 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[61e88580-d53a-4441-8698-4c72b86eca9e]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/35]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">With the cost of surveillance and mass information gathering becoming cheaper and easier, laws are struggling to keep pace. Who is fighting for transparency and working to protect</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">your</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">digital rights?</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest today is Danny O’Brien. Danny has been an activist for online free speech and privacy for over 20 years. He co-founded the Open Rights Group and has defended reporters from online attacks at the committee to protect journalists. He is now the Director of Strategy at Electronic Frontier Foundation.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[0:59] - Danny began working with Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF) in 2005 but had been interested in them and digital rights overall since 1990 as a journalist.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[2:18] - In the early days of EFF, the topics they were writing about seemed very theoretical to the everyday person. It became confusing, but a lot of these hypothetical situations were becoming reality in the early 2000s.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:06] - The assistance Danny gave to journalists to keep them safer from online attacks began on a case by case basis.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:23] - Danny explains that now they are seeing a rise in targeted attacks on journalists with government connections.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:50] - The tools to conduct a spyware style monitoring of a particular person are now so ridiculously cheap. It can be anyone. In the early days, it always seemed like an attack was government based or done by professionals.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:42] - Journalists in particular are highly targeted for attacks because they have likely upset someone they’ve reported about.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:49] - When Gmail was hacked in 2009, it became apparent that the people that were targeted in that attack were Tibetan activists.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:42] - There has been a shift into a professionalization of attacks. It is someone’s job to clock on, hack and make someone’s life unpleasant, and clock off.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:10] - One of the key cases in the last several years in regards to digital privacy rights is the Apple San Bernardino case in which the FBI wanted a back door into the iPhone of a suspect in a shooting.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:36] - There is a gray area where governments are saying that as long as they have the ability to do these things, they should. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:16] - The globalization of technology has caused confusion and blurred lines on what is legal and illegal in each country.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:25] - Danny gives an example of a loophole in United States law regarding getting geolocation data from phones.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:13] - The process of getting information is very murky especially in the United States.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:41] - We need transparency before we will ever see reform.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:40] - Google would do something called The Creepy Test where they would demonstrate something they could do internally and determine whether it was something that could be used in a “creepy” way.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:29] - Something may seem like a great idea but wind up causing more bad than good. Danny uses apps for tracking the pandemic as an example.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:20] - As technologists, we are capable of acting very quickly and reaching for a toolkit that we can use.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:19] - Sometimes we have to be careful that the solutions that are the simplest from a technological point of view aren’t just shifting the complexity elsewhere. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:02] - The consequences of simply uploading photos online in regards to privacy were very unexpected at the start of the internet and social media.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:49] - In the 90s there was a strong fight against encryption. Now that encryption is what holds entire economies together.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:08] - While encryption is useful, it is also being used by cybercriminals to hide illegal activity, particularly child pornography.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:00] - We used to argue about digital rights but now all rights are digital. Now, all laws are about the internet.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[41:53] - Danny and Chris discuss the passage of a bill about the digital rights of sex workers that had several unintended consequences.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[43:12] - There is a big push right now to undermine encryption particularly for fighting against sex trafficking.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:04] - There are a lot of problems that have been created that were unintentionally created by technology that needs to be solved.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[45:06] - Large companies, like Apple, Google, and Amazon, have a lot of control of our personal devices.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[46:46] - We will start to see a lot of technological compromises between large companies and the government.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[48:44] - Pick the privacy tools and try out different tools to find what works for you. It exercises your right to remove trackers and ads from your web experience.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[50:27] - In order to exercise your rights, you need to know them.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[52:38] - People wind up being the consumers of technology and they don’t become active citizens in this digital community. Education is important.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[54:54] - Danny shares links to useful material to educate yourself on surveillance (listed in the Links and Resources).</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[57:21] - Sometimes, lawmakers don’t know all about these technological problems, so write to your lawmakers when you have concerns.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[59:30] - EFF is membership driven and a huge proportion of their funding is from individual members. If you are interested in becoming a member or donating to</span> <a href= "https://www.eff.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">EFF</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, visit their</span> <a href="https://www.eff.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">website</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">for more information.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.openrightsgroup.org/"><span 			<title>Charity and Personal Finance Scams with Dori Zinn</title>
			<itunes:title>Charity and Personal Finance Scams with Dori Zinn</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 21 Oct 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b9d3360f-08e2-408c-b425-af167109d10a]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The pandemic has taken an economic toll on millions of lives. People are struggling, people want to help, and others are looking to take advantage of both. Before panicking about your bills or giving to the latest charitable cause, you need to listen to this episode to make sure your money is going where you think it is.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest today is Dori Zinn. Dori has been a personal finance journalist for more than a decade with work featured in</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Forbes, Huffington Post, CNET, Yahoo Finance</span></em><span style="font-weight: 400;">, and more. Her writing covers topics like banking, investing, credit, debt, student loans, personal loans, budgeting, and overall financial literacy. But today, she is talking about charities. Which ones are legitimate and which ones are raising those red flags?</span></p> <p> </p>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>The pandemic has taken an economic toll on millions of lives. People are struggling, people want to help, and others are looking to take advantage of both. Before panicking about your bills or giving to the latest charitable cause, you need to listen to this episode to make sure your money is going where you think it is.</p> <p>Our guest today is Dori Zinn. Dori has been a personal finance journalist for more than a decade with work featured in <em>Forbes, Huffington Post, CNET, Yahoo Finance</em>, and more. Her writing covers topics like banking, investing, credit, debt, student loans, personal loans, budgeting, and overall financial literacy. But today, she is talking about charities. Which ones are legitimate and which ones are raising those red flags?</p> <p> </p>]]></content:encoded>

		<item>
			<title>You Can Stop Stupid with Ira Winkler</title>
			<itunes:title>You Can Stop Stupid with Ira Winkler</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 14 Oct 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3c57bf07-0c9a-41db-9ae5-ed8ca56a7150]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/33]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Information security is not just technical. There is a human aspect involved and fixing that is more than just identification and awareness. Our guest today is Ira Winkler. Ira is the president of Secure Mentem and the author of the book</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/You-CAN-Stop-Stupid-Accidental/dp/1119621984/ref=sr_1_4?dchild=1&keywords=ira+winkler&qid=1602558223&sr=8-4"> <em><span style="font-weight: 400;">You Can Stop Stupid</span></em></a><em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></em> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">He is referred to as the modern-day James Bond, given his skills both physically and technically in infiltrating organizations. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Today, Ira shares with us many of his personal and professional experiences in the area of cybercrime. His valuable tips and information can change how you look at potential threats and scams. He is an expert in how to make people easy prey and how to prevent people from being easy prey. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[0:51] - Ira graduated college as a psychology major and the only job he could get at that time was in the National Security Agency. This led him into the computer field within the military.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:31] - He always wound up working on the human side of things.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:03] - Ira shares his background and how he became a world-renowned penetration expert, which is a fancy name for a hacker.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[5:21] - The way you break something is not the way you fix it. This is an important concept when looking at psychology.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:01] - Psychology helps Ira exploit others but it is also important to understand when helping them.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:55] - Telling someone the problem and then telling them not to fall for a scam doesn’t work.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:50] - Ira and Chris discuss the recent Twitter hacks. Ira says that in this situation, anyone could have done what the hacker did because it was easy. 			<title>Disinformation and Misinformation with Morgan Wright</title>
			<itunes:title>Disinformation and Misinformation with Morgan Wright</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 07 Oct 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3466a946-b81f-4466-8b11-224d48b36597]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">With the 2020 elections right around the corner, do you know who is trying to influence you and how they’re doing it? Listen on to learn about the ins and outs of disinformation, misinformation, interference, and influence. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Morgan Wright is an internationally recognized expert on cybersecurity strategy, cyberterrorism, and advanced technology. His landmark testimony before Congress on healthcare.gov changed how the government collected personally identifiable information. He has made hundreds of appearances on national news - radio, print, and web - and has spoken to audiences around the world. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[1:21] - Morgan Wright shares his background, including his childhood in a military family and his original college major as music. He moved into law enforcement and then shifted in computer crime.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[3:26] - Morgan moved into cybercrime because of his interest in both people and technology.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[4:40] - On 9/11, Morgan was supposed to be in the Pentagon but was in the Reagan building instead. Because of the attacks on 9/11, he was thrown into cyberterrorism as well.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[6:11] - Morgan also worked for Cisco and was the technical advisor for the show</span> <em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">America’s Most Wanted</span></em><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[7:35] - Another facet of Morgan’s career is even working on cold case homicide files.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:36] - The next generation of leadership needs to be educated in technology. Every company is a software company whether you like it or not.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:36] - Disinformation is information that is intentionally changed to achieve a particular objective. The person spreading the information knows it isn’t true, but wants to incite public outrage against someone.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:06] - Misinformation is when someone hears something and believes it to be correct and shares it, to then later find out that it wasn’t accurate information.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:40] - Twitter was monitored to see how quickly disinformation and misinformation spread and it spread faster than legitimate truthful news.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:23] - Russia has been targeting people’s biases by spreading disinformation since 1917 and they understand how to take advantage of how a system works.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:56] - The real danger is when people or organizations understand how news spreads and take advantage of these algorithms to influence major decisions, events, and even human lives.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:42] - Chris and Morgan discuss Pizzagate as an example of spreading disinformation and misinformation and how the use of social media spreads it extremely fast.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:35] - Interference is a sovereignty issue. Morgan gives an example of how interference is even considered an act of war in some places.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:59] - The United States has spent a great deal of money in the influence field.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:58] - Influence is a massive social engineering operation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:03] - Disinformation runs so deep that sometimes even trained professionals miss it.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:52] - You do not have to react to every single post you see. Take a moment to digest what you are seeing before you react to it as truth.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:44] - Parents have to be vigilant about what their kids see and read on the internet. You need to curate what your kids view and what you yourself view as well.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:08] - It is important for adults to be adults. Even with opposing views, you need to be able to be an adult and have a respectful conversation with others.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:13] - It seems that we have lost the ability to get things done with others who have opposing views.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:31] - It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has all the data. What happens is you twist facts to fit theories instead of twisting theories to fit the facts.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:13] - Nobody wants to do their own research. They just want information spoon fed to them.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:31] - The danger of conspiracy theories is that you are fed just enough kernels of truth to make it believable.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:00] - Chris and Morgan discuss a few 9/11 conspiracy theories and why it is easier to believe them than to believe the truth.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:47] - If you listen to the news, don’t believe a thing you hear. Do your own independent research before you share something on social media.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:00] - The oxygen this disinformation and influence operation needs to spread is you. It's you clicking that link and sharing it.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.morganwright.us/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Morgan Wright Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/morganwright150"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Morgan Wright on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/morganwright_us"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Morgan Wright on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

You need to curate what your kids view and what you yourself view as well.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:08] - It is important for adults to be adults. Even with opposing views, you need to be able to be an adult and have a respectful conversation with others.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:13] - It seems that we have lost the ability to get things done with others who have opposing views.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[27:31] - It is a capital mistake to theorize before one has all the data. What happens is you twist facts to fit theories instead of twisting theories to fit the facts.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[28:13] - Nobody wants to do their own research. They just want information spoon fed to them.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:31] - The danger of conspiracy theories is that you are fed just enough kernels of truth to make it believable.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[32:00] - Chris and Morgan discuss a few 9/11 conspiracy theories and why it is easier to believe them than to believe the truth.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[33:47] - If you listen to the news, don’t believe a thing you hear. Do your own independent research before you share something on social media.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[35:00] - The oxygen this disinformation and influence operation needs to spread is you. 			<title>Dating Scams with Kezia Noble</title>
			<itunes:title>Dating Scams with Kezia Noble</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 30 Sep 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[cec75263-4345-4f21-b9a6-c2a99bda61a5]]></guid>
