"font-weight: 400;">ThreatSTOP</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.bambenekconsulting.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Bambenek Consulting</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://stopstalkerware.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Coalition Against Stalkerware</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>I’m contacted by people on a regular basis who believe that their devices have been compromised and that they’re being stalked and spied on. Sometimes they’ve misinterpreted what they’re looking at but sometimes they are actually being digitally stalked. Find out what to do about it in this episode. </p> <p>Today’s guest is John Bambenek. John is the Vice President of Security Research and Intelligence at ThreatSTOP and the President of Bambenek Consulting where he provides security consulting, penetration testing, forensics, and auditing. He has spoken at numerous security conferences including Black Hat. He has spent 20 years doing investigation work on cybercrime threats.</p> <p>John is going to go over what Stalkerware is, in what scenarios it is most common, and things we can do to mitigate the harm it can do.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[1:00] - John Bambenek is the Vice President of Security Research and Intelligence at ThreatSTOP and owns his own company, Bambenek Consulting. He has been working in cybersecurity since college.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[3:01] - John explains that Stalkerware is a malicious mobile app that is put on your phone to track your movements, monitor who you are talking to, see your texts, and other various activities through your phone.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[3:26] - Stalkerware is most commonly found in cases of former relationships, but John shares his experience with Stalkerware found on the mobile device of an assassinated politician in South America.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[4:39] - Odds are, if there is Stalkerware on your phone or mobile device, that that is not all that is going on. There are usually many signs of abusive or controlling behavior.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[5:45] - There are also ways that people can be stalked without installing Stalkerware, such as monitoring Instagram and Facebook activity.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[6:29] - Multiple IP addresses and their locations are often misinterpreted.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[9:14] - Stalkerware is most commonly installed onto someone’s phone by someone who has physical access to it, although remote installation is possible.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[9:58] - There are also built-in features that can be misused, such as Find My Friends on an iPhone.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[11:18] - Stalkerware is different from malware that is accidentally downloaded where hackers may have access to a device belonging to someone they don’t know. Stalkerware is intentional and usually involves some prior relationship.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:08] - Whenever you can, have a password on your phone that you don’t give to someone, multi-factor authentication on accounts and other important logins.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:50] - Multi-factor authentication is a very useful early warning system. John shares an experience he had in another country and how multi-factor authentication helped catch something unusual early on.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:07] - John is a unique case because he <em>wants</em> a device compromised to aid him in his career in security research and shares some stories about his experiences.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:12] - Chris and John discuss devices to bring or not to bring to conferences like Black Hat.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:52] - A factory reset and changing all passwords is largely sufficient in eliminating Stalkerware installed on a phone.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:28] - Once you start getting real-world indication that you are being stalked, establishing a police report is an important next step.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:28] - With effort and with a court order, it may be possible to determine who has installed the Stalkerware on your device if you don’t know who it is.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:31] - One thing to keep in mind is when you wipe the phone, you also wipe the evidence.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[27:13] - Taking down the people who create these Stalkerware malware is more valuable to police and investigators than individual cases of Stalkerware.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[28:23] - The Coalition Against Stalkerware is a community of activists providing resources to victims and who are trying to figure out what can be done about Stalkerware on a larger scale.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:30] - Language needs to be precise because there are software creators whose intentions are not malicious.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[31:40] - There are laws that need to be changed and police detectives need to be educated so they can become experts in examining mobile phones.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[33:00] - John explains that if you give someone access to your phone years ago and then they install Stalkerware on your phone maliciously later, they will not go to jail for it because you gave them permission at some point.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[34:43] - There are industry coalitions and other groups dedicated to helping victims of stalking, but stalking has been a prevalent behavior in long term documented history. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[35:27] - There are people who want these tools to monitor and control someone’s movements and there are people who want to make money by providing this malware to them.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[36:01] - There are lots of ways someone can be stalked without the use of Stalkerware. Because of the nature of social media sites like Facebook, we are leaking information all the time that can be watched and used.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[37:41] - People don’t understand the difference between anonymous and private. John gives examples of how this can be a problem.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[39:10] - To get the benefits of advancing technology, we have to give up something in exchange. These things are not necessarily good or bad, you just need to understand what you’re giving up to have this service.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[40:16] - Every decision has its pros and cons and you have to be mindful of what they are and be okay with that. And sometimes there are ways to mitigate some of those harms.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[40:40] - John explains the problem with Bluetooth: We have so many devices and it's all or nothing.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[43:16] - There are many contact tracing apps that are created for a legitimate purpose that can be misused for the purpose of stalking.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/bambenek?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Eauthor"> John Bambenek on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/johnbambenek">John Bambenek on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.threatstop.com/">ThreatSTOP</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.bambenekconsulting.com/">Bambenek Consulting</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://stopstalkerware.org/">Coalition Against Stalkerware</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>SIM Swapping with Haseeb Awan</title>
			<itunes:title>SIM Swapping with Haseeb Awan</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 22 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[fbfd4253-8750-400f-a278-b99303209430]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/22]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’ve been telling people for years that they need to implement two-factor authentication wherever possible.  Now that you’ve done that, imagine the havoc that would happen if those security codes were sent to somebody else enabling them to access your email, social media accounts, and worse your bank accounts. It is called SIM swapping, porting out, and SIM jacking. Today’s guest is Haseeb Awan. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Haseeb is CEO of Efani, American’s most secure and private cell phone service. He is an expert at protecting high profile individual cell phone numbers. Haseeb was also co-founder of the first bitcoin ATM company. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Haseeb shares his many experiences with working with SIM swapping. We talk about how we are all at risk and the precautions we can take to avoid becoming a victim of SIM swapping. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:26] - SIM swap, SIM port, SIM hack, and telephone takeover are all the same.  SIM swapping is when a criminal takes over your telephone.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:05] - The criminal takes control of your social media accounts or email accounts and then drains your bank account.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:06] - If a person gets your account number, pin number, and telephone number and then the criminal can transfer your phone number.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:36] - Often they go online and buy a new SIM card and trick someone to transfer the number to them.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:51] - Social engineering is as simple as pretending to be someone you are not to gain information maliciously or for fun.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:05] - Telephone companies have the ability to sell, monetize, and track your data.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:47] - If I haven’t done anything wrong then why do I need privacy?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:49] - The people that are criminals are working 24/7 to destroy you. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:31] - The average customer is more at risk because they don’t take as many precautions.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:41] - Make sure your cell phone carrier supports a pin code at a minimum.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:30] - Whatever setting you have the criminal can override.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:42] - The port lock might help keep your number from being taken to a different carrier, but if they go to your carrier’s store it doesn’t help at all.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:58] - These criminals only need a few hours to have complete access to everything.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:36] - Often they attack when you are most vulnerable like after 9 PM in the evening.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:16] - You should always use an app-based or hardware key vs. SMS two-factor identification. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:32] - Keep it simple and have a password on your phone and then use the Google authenticator app.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:52] - We often get attacked because we are lazy and put security off until tomorrow.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:22] - Efani focuses on pricing and security. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:18] - Most of their customers are people who don’t want their information sold on the internet and want that extra layer of security. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:15] - Doctors are the number one victims of SIM swapping attacks.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:40] - Seniors are at a significantly higher risk.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:19] - It is really easy to forge caller id, so never assume it is a real call. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:25] - Within 90 days you will see a 90% reduction in spam calls with Efani.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:27] - When you have a cell phone plan try not to be on a family plan.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:47] - The two most important numbers in your life are your social security number and your cell phone number and you have way more linked to your cell phone number.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:14] - He suggests getting two telephone numbers.  Use one for all authentications and don’t give that number out to anyone. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:42] - Keep your cell phone software up to date and don’t let children play on your phone.  </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 		<item>
			<title>Narcissists, Psychopaths, and Sociopaths with Dr. Ramani Durvasula</title>
			<itunes:title>Narcissists, Psychopaths, and Sociopaths with Dr. Ramani Durvasula</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 15 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[6f27039b-7cc5-446c-9d85-1201f1cb5f71]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/21]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Just because someone isn’t trying to scam you out of your hard-earned money doesn’t mean that they don’t see you as a pawn, stepping stone, or a means to an end. Find out how to protect yourself from a narcissist. Our guest today is Dr. Ramani Durvasula. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dr. Ramani Durvasula is one of the world-leading experts on narcissism. She is a clinical psychologist, professor, best selling author, and speaker. She is on a mission to demystify and dismantle the toxic influence of narcissism on all of our lives. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dr. Ramani shares her many experiences with working with narcissists. We talk about warning signs and risks for being in a relationship or working for a narcissist. We also talk about how to protect yourself if you are in a relationship or working with a narcissist.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:48] - Dr. Ramani shares how she got involved in psychology. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:55] - The fall out for the people that stay in relationships with narcissists with chronic invalidating was shredding. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:46] - Narcissism is a pattern of a person who lacks empathy, is deeply entitled, arrogant, superficial, and constantly needs validation. 			<title>Credit Card Skimming with Scott Schober</title>
			<itunes:title>Credit Card Skimming with Scott Schober</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 08 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[9ab66038-5497-44f4-a78b-58a103d42312]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/20]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ve all had that random fraudulent charge show up on our credit card and we wonder how did that happen.  Do I need to cancel my credit card? Do I need to get a new one?  Today we talk about credit card skimming with Scott Schober. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scott Schober is the president and CEO of Berkeley Varitronics Systems, a 48-year-old leading provider of advanced world-class wireless test and cybersecurity solutions.  Scott is a highly sought after author and expert for live security events, media appearances, and commentary on ransomware, wireless threats, drone surveillance hacking, and cybersecurity for consumers and small businesses. He is the author of</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Hacked Again</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">and</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Cybersecurity-Everybodys-Business-Security-Puzzle/dp/0996902260/ref=sr_1_1?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129441&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-1"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Cybersecurity is Everybody’s Business</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scott shares his many experiences about personally being hacked and finally getting the money back. We talk about what you need to know, how to protect yourself, and more.   </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:02] - Scott shares how he got involved in cybersecurity.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:01] - Cybercriminals want to silence you.  They don’t want you to share tips or expertise on how to keep companies secure or even individuals.   These attacks lead to the creation of his first book,</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Hacked Again</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:02] - In that process, he learned that there were some fundamental things that they were doing wrong.  So he had to relearn and reimplement best practices for the company and himself. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:34] - We should create more secure passwords and not use them across multiple sites.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:14] - Anonymity is extremely powerful in the criminal empire.  Criminal gangs often get educated to conduct criminal activity.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:42] - We can now use technology to fight back.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:29] - The challenge is to get the skimmers out before it even happens.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:02] - Follow the money and it usually tells you why things are done or not done. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:12] - Scott uses Apple Pay and Google Wallet when possible.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:22] - When you’re at a gas station use cash if you are afraid of a skimmer.  Use common sense.  If things look like they have been tampered with, use caution.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:17] - The part of the iceberg sticking out of the water is the surface web that we use for searches and purchases.  Below is tons of information that don’t make a lot of sense to us working at the surface web. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:38] - If you see a small transaction on your credit card ($0.50/$1) it could likely be that it is on the dark web and has been posted to be tested.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:37] - It is hard for law enforcement because this is an attractive way to make money.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:50] - Don’t be complacent.  Start out by doing best practices across the board in your personal life and business.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:12] - The best thing to do is to add layers of security like multi-factor or two-step authentication.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:29] - Scott doesn’t share his actual birthday on social media, because that is one of the critical pieces of information if someone tries to compromise your identity.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:07] - When setting up security questions put a password instead of the actual answer that can be researched about you.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:42] - They discuss the pros and cons of freezing your credit.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:25] - The process and investigation when Scott lost $65,000 took months, but he did finally did get the money back.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:28] - Cybercriminals create fictitious accounts, steal money from multiple people in a bank, and quickly close them out.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:32] - You can do things to prevent it from happening to you.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:49] - You can’t be too trusting to anyone. Don’t use their means of communication to verify. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:49] - Take a few minutes to question everything. Use caution. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[40:07] - Many of these scams look very convincing.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[42:50] - Your better to spend the time and effort upfront securing things then pay for it later.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[44:04] - A small business owner can do small practical things to protect themselves.  </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Hacked Again</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Cybersecurity-Everybodys-Business-Security-Puzzle/dp/0996902260/ref=sr_1_1?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129441&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-1"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Cybersecurity is Everybody’s Business</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>We’ve all had that random fraudulent charge show up on our credit card and we wonder how did that happen.  Do I need to cancel my credit card? Do I need to get a new one?  Today we talk about credit card skimming with Scott Schober. </p> <p>Scott Schober is the president and CEO of Berkeley Varitronics Systems, a 48-year-old leading provider of advanced world-class wireless test and cybersecurity solutions.  Scott is a highly sought after author and expert for live security events, media appearances, and commentary on ransomware, wireless threats, drone surveillance hacking, and cybersecurity for consumers and small businesses. He is the author of <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> Hacked Again</a> and <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Cybersecurity-Everybodys-Business-Security-Puzzle/dp/0996902260/ref=sr_1_1?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129441&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-1"> Cybersecurity is Everybody’s Business</a>.  </p> <p>Scott shares his many experiences about personally being hacked and finally getting the money back. We talk about what you need to know, how to protect yourself, and more.   </p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[01:02] - Scott shares how he got involved in cybersecurity.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:01] - Cybercriminals want to silence you.  They don’t want you to share tips or expertise on how to keep companies secure or even individuals.   These attacks lead to the creation of his first book, <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> Hacked Again</a>. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[03:02] - In that process, he learned that there were some fundamental things that they were doing wrong.  So he had to relearn and reimplement best practices for the company and himself. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[03:34] - We should create more secure passwords and not use them across multiple sites.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[06:14] - Anonymity is extremely powerful in the criminal empire.  Criminal gangs often get educated to conduct criminal activity.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[08:42] - We can now use technology to fight back.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[10:29] - The challenge is to get the skimmers out before it even happens.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[12:02] - Follow the money and it usually tells you why things are done or not done. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:12] - Scott uses Apple Pay and Google Wallet when possible.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[15:22] - When you’re at a gas station use cash if you are afraid of a skimmer.  Use common sense.  If things look like they have been tampered with, use caution.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:17] - The part of the iceberg sticking out of the water is the surface web that we use for searches and purchases.  Below is tons of information that don’t make a lot of sense to us working at the surface web. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:38] - If you see a small transaction on your credit card ($0.50/$1) it could likely be that it is on the dark web and has been posted to be tested.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:37] - It is hard for law enforcement because this is an attractive way to make money.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:50] - Don’t be complacent.  Start out by doing best practices across the board in your personal life and business.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:12] - The best thing to do is to add layers of security like multi-factor or two-step authentication.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:29] - Scott doesn’t share his actual birthday on social media, because that is one of the critical pieces of information if someone tries to compromise your identity.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:07] - When setting up security questions put a password instead of the actual answer that can be researched about you.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[27:42] - They discuss the pros and cons of freezing your credit.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:25] - The process and investigation when Scott lost $65,000 took months, but he did finally did get the money back.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[31:28] - Cybercriminals create fictitious accounts, steal money from multiple people in a bank, and quickly close them out.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[33:32] - You can do things to prevent it from happening to you.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[35:49] - You can’t be too trusting to anyone. Don’t use their means of communication to verify. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[37:49] - Take a few minutes to question everything. Use caution. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[40:07] - Many of these scams look very convincing.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[42:50] - Your better to spend the time and effort upfront securing things then pay for it later.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[44:04] - A small business owner can do small practical things to protect themselves.  </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://haveibeenpwned.com/">Have I Been Pwned</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.bvsystems.com/">Berkeley Varitronics Systems</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://scottschober.com/">Scott’s Website</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Hacked-Again-Scott-N-Schober-ebook/dp/B01CFCHAHG/ref=sr_1_2?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129412&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-2"> Hacked Again</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Cybersecurity-Everybodys-Business-Security-Puzzle/dp/0996902260/ref=sr_1_1?crid=C1GYTA7Y3IIY&dchild=1&keywords=scott+schober&qid=1594129441&s=books&sprefix=scott+schober%2Caps%2C366&sr=1-1"> Cybersecurity is Everybody’s Business</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Tracking Scammers with Wayne May</title>
			<itunes:title>Tracking Scammers with Wayne May</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 01 Jul 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[38e39b7d-1fc3-4eeb-93e7-a5e775bcbc10]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/19]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many of us have seen James Veitch’s comedic YouTube videos of him interacting with email scammers.  Today’s guest shares how he helps real-world victims of those scams and he has participated in taking down criminal enterprises. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Wayne May is the owner of</span> <a href="https://scamsurvivors.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">scamsurvivors.com</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. He began as a scam baiter in 2005 before concentrating and helping the victims of scams. </span> <a href="https://scamsurvivors.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Scam Survivors</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">was created in 2012 by Wayne along with a small group of like-minded volunteers.  He has appeared in the media worldwide as well as being a guest speaker at the</span> <a href= "https://idateconference.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">IDate conferences</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">discussing romance scams.   </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Wayne shares his many experiences working with email scams, sextortion, and romance scams. We also discuss specific things you can look for when receiving a spammy email and how to research and check it out for yourself.  Awareness and education are the keys to helping more people. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:01] - He created the</span> <a href= "https://scamsurvivors.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scam Survivors</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">website fifteen years ago when he was looking for something fun to do.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:52] - He started as a scam baiter and fell into working with romance scammers.  People would write to him and ask for his help.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:41] - He went from having fun with scammers to really helping the people who were being scammed or thought they were being scammed. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:57] - When receiving a scammy email a scam baiter would write back and ask for more details instead of deleting the email.   Then you can post the information online to warn other people.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:41] - It is important to get the scammer information out there so the public can find it.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:21] - Wayne isn’t seeing a lot of new scams.  Instead, he is seeing variations of old scams.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:07] - The first step in getting the site taken down is to get as much information as you can from the scammer. He then sends all the information to the hosting company in the hope that they will take down the site.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:41] - Wayne shares about the horrible sextortion situations he has seen.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:39] - Wayne shares other experiences dealing with minors.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:58] - You don’t give scammers money.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:57] - He hopes that they have so much success that all the scammers stop.  In reality, they hope to get more people involved and educate more people. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:45] - Wayne’s site has a forum where you can share spam emails and they will check them out for you.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:08] - They try to get as much information as possible because then they can do more about it.  You need their email address, not just their name.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:19] - The emails are often repeated because they are scripts.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:52] - People can do the same checks and searches they do at home.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:02] - One telltale sign is inconsistency in language or grammar.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:01] - As soon as anyone asks for money you know it is a scam.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:17] - He does not use cash baiting because you are not getting the scammers money you are actually getting some other victim’s money.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:38] - Wayne has a book called</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Stupid-Scammer-Files-collection-ridiculous/dp/B085RM9QR8"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">The Stupid Scammer Files</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">where he shares the stupid things that scammers say.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:31] - Wayne shares some examples of stupid things scammers have said.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:15] - If you get these emails, come to their website and post them to help other people that don’t realize it is a scam.  </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Stupid-Scammer-Files-collection-ridiculous/dp/B085RM9QR8"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">The Stupid Scammer Files</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 			<title>Red Collar Crime with Richard Brody</title>
			<itunes:title>Red Collar Crime with Richard Brody</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 24 Jun 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[489fd4ac-82b7-46cf-bffb-1a0aeca12191]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/18]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Accounting doesn’t sound like a sexy career choice. How about forensic accounting and getting to work with the FBI and Secret Service? Now that’s getting interesting. White-collar crime is typically committed by business or government professionals that engage in fraud, insider trader, embezzlement, or cybercrime. It can destroy companies, individuals, and families. What happens when a murder occurs during these cases? </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Richard Brody is a professor and chair of the accounting department at the Anderson School of Management at the University of New Mexico. He is a certified fraud examiner, certified public accountant, and a forensic certified public accountant. He serves as an expert witness and has experience in both civil and criminal cases. He has worked with the U.S. Secret Service, the U.S. Department of Justice, and the New Mexico Attorney General’s office. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Rich shares many experiences working in white-collar and red-collar crime. 			<title>Cyber Security Awareness with Jake Moore</title>
			<itunes:title>Cyber Security Awareness with Jake Moore</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 17 Jun 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3c440186-bb90-4e86-a232-dadc0f3bf070]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have you ever wondered what strange things a digital forensic investigator has to dig through? Listen to this episode to find out.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest for this episode is Jake Moore. Jake Moore is a cybersecurity specialist for ESET, Europe’s number one internet security and anti-virus company. Jake previously worked in the police force for 14 years investigating cybercrime in the Digital Forensics Unit and Cyber Crime Team in Dorset.  In 2016, he was asked to implement cybersecurity advisers in order to make local communities more aware of ever-increasing cybersecurity threats.    </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Jake shares many experiences working in digital forensics and cybersecurity. We also discuss simple things you can do to keep cybercriminals away and social media accounts safe.  </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:05] - Jake shares the background on how he got started in cybersecurity. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:20] - Without an understanding of cybercrime and what they are doing there is a huge chance that these companies are going to end up losing millions of dollars down the line.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:57] - When Chris was in college he was very interested in crime scene investigation and he did a ride-along with a crime scene investigator.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:13] - Jake shares a story about a time he received a laptop as part of a murder investigation.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:37] - In the UK, they have a system for reporting all cybercrimes called Action Fraud. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:53] - Cybercrime and fraud are making up over 50% of crime in the UK.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:03] - Prevention is the best cure.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:31] - Use a password manager.  90% of people are using two or three passwords for everything.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:29] - Jake also suggests turning on two factor or multifactor identification.  Every social media and email account offers it.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:14] - If it hasn’t happened to them or their nearest and dearest then people think cybersecurity won’t happen to them.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:22] - Sometimes in scamming emails they include an old password that they acquired from a data breach.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:39] - Jake likes to make people aware that you can phish people’s information.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:04] - Even people with awareness tend to forget about things as soon as something amazing comes along.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:24] - Cybercriminals are very crafty and they are doing their homework. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:34] - They often feed their victims’ egos just enough to get them to bite.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:24] - Cybercriminals use urgency as one of the key factors.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:06] - The use of authority is another key factor.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:14] - Always backup your data.  This is a good practice for everyone and can be beneficial in many different circumstances.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:31] - It is important to have a local back-up and a cloud back-up.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:01] - Chris has two back-up cloud services and a rotating clone of his hard drive.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:15] - Chris shares a back-up story about a company that he worked for.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[35:19] - Some people learn the hard way and sometimes that is what it takes.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:46] - It is important to have a place to store your photos and just use your phone for recent photos. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:21] - If Jake’s 73-year-old mum can do it then anyone can.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:12] - Sometimes providing more information can almost backfire and trip people up.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:44] - Awareness and education have to go hand and hand. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[40:36] - The number one rule is never to click on any link in an email. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[41:02] - Jake’s best advice is to do one of the things they talked about today in the podcast. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://haveibeenpwned.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have I Been Pwned</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://jakemoore.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Jake’s Website</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/Jake_MooreUK"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Jake on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>

			<title>Psychology of Scams with Dr. Stacey Wood</title>
			<itunes:title>Psychology of Scams with Dr. Stacey Wood</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 10 Jun 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[3186f6a3-6f93-41e6-b91b-f839623c659e]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/16/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I have always been curious as to why so many people fall for scams. What are some of the consistent elements that scammers use to hook us? In this episode, we find out. We talk about the different psychological tactics scammers use to successfully scam their victims. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest for this episode is Dr. Stacey Wood. Dr. Wood is a clinical neuropsychologist and full Professor of Psychology at Scripps College in Claremont, California. She is an expert on a number of issues related to neuropsychology including aging, decision making, and capacity issues. Dr. Wood also works on the frontline with fraud victims as a consulting neuropsychologist with Adult Protective Services on cases in Riverside and San Bernardino, California. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dr. Wood shares her experiences working with scam victims including the psychological tactics she sees scammers using the most. We also discuss red flags and practical tips for helping and talking with parents and grandparents. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:01] - Dr. Wood shares how she got into the psychology aspect of scams and frauds. She has worked with older adults most of her career, and she loves that. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:43] - When you are interviewing scam victims you start to understand the complexity of these scams. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:05] - Dr. Wood goes on calls to interview scam victims and she works with the Elder Abuse Forensic team. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:59] - Scammers use very complex psychological tactics. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:48] - There are certain risk factors among older people that are more common. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:58] - A loss in the past year greatly increases the chance of fraud. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:07] - Cognitive impairment is a huge risk factor in older adults. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:54] - Scammers are like a virus. They change and mutate incredibly quickly. Scammers went from mailing solicitations to older people to phishing emails, robocalls, and now social media. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:06] - When someone suffers a loss it is a huge transition in their life. It can be a loss of a sounding board and create isolation. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:41] - Adult children should initiate conversations with their parents about money because the parents most likely won’t do that. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:08] - Dr. Wood suggests adding an adult child to a bank account just for monitoring purposes. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:58] - You have taken care of me and watched over me all these years, now I have to start thinking about laying the groundwork of taking care of you guys as you age. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:30] - Most decisions we make are more impulsive and automatic. We really don’t have the resources to dig into every small decision we make during the day. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:57] - When there is scarcity it causes consumers to act more quickly. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:12] - Dr. Wood recommends taking time out or finding a sounding board before making a decision. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:38] - Urgency, scarcity, and authority are all red flags to be watching out for.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:44] - Scammers use the fire hose approach. They target everyone and hope that certain consumers will be in an emotional state or be prime to respond to their solicitation. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:06] - There are three types of reactions by consumers. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:22] - If you are wary about an email at all just delete it. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:48] - Scammers don’t care who they cheat. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:54] - When someone is scammed they are often terrified to tell anyone because they are in fear of how they would be perceived and how it would hurt their reputation. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:31] - Scammers often use the psychological tactic of always calling and always being in their life. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:01] - The bad guys only have to get it right once. The good guys have to get it right 100% of the time.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:44] - Having an open family dialogue about these issues is useful. Be more aware in these times of uncertainty. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:54] - Discussing your decisions with your parents may open the door to a broader discussion. It may help to foster a better conversation in general. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 			<title>Hacking with James Kettle</title>
			<itunes:title>Hacking with James Kettle</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 03 Jun 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0ec55bcf-33ba-4c84-96bd-1ad2b5f2b8cc]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/15/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have you ever wondered how hackers find vulnerabilities and how companies can find and fix their own? You will find out today! On average 30,000 new websites are hacked every day.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guest for this episode is James Kettle. James is the Director of Research at PortSwigger Web Security where he explores new ways to attack websites and designs and refines vulnerability detection techniques for the Burp Suites scanner. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">James shares his hacking experience and hard work helping companies keep their websites secure from all the crazy stuff going on out there.  On today’s episode, James shares his expertise to help you be more aware of possible red flags and prevention measures to take to protect yourself and your website.</span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:40] - When James was at university he saw that Google said they would pay anybody that could hack their website. He thought that sounded like fun and spent a huge amount of time doing that. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:02] - Now James works at PortSwigger and researches new techniques to hack websites. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:11] - Bounty programs are where a company wants to make sure their product or website doesn’t get hacked by malicious people so they go out and publicly say that anyone is welcome to try and hack their website. If you are successful and you don’t do any damage, but you tell them how you did it they will pay you for it and then fix it. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:45] - Pen testing is the classic approach to securing your website where you pay a consultant to spend one or two weeks trying to hack your website. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:14] - It is totally worth it to get that third party view. Developers often can’t find problems with their own products. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:13] - If you want to find a vulnerability on a website you need to use an attack technique.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:15] - These days they see a lot of cross-site scripting vulnerabilities and it’s the most common one they see. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:37] - One of the most common causes of high impact breaches is access control issues.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:45] - James shares the biggest data breach they were able to do during their testing. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:31] - Try to use a framework whenever possible, because it makes things like sequel injection less likely to happen.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:01] - The standard approach after you make the website is to try to get someone else to look at it. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:27] - With Wordpress, it is very important to keep it up to date, install as few plug-ins as possible, and choose a good password. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:08] - Use as few browser extensions as possible to avoid possible malware issues. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:25] - Most people are not being personally targeted by hackers so the threats that most people need to watch out for are things that can be automated. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:10] - If you are using the same password on multiple websites you are going to get hacked. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:02] - A common misconception is that if you have a strong unique password then it doesn’t matter if you reuse it. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:03] - James uses websites with the assumption that all the data I give this website is going to end up public at some point. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:45] - Provide the minimum information possible. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:19] - James shares his all-time favorite story. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:33] - If an entity builds their security around detecting when people are attacking them then running a bug bounty would be harmful because they have no idea who is legitimate or hostile. If your website is on the internet, it is being attacked.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:35] - When you are being attacked, it is important to know that it most likely isn’t personal.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">PortSwigger</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://portswigger.net/burp"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Burp Suite</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://portswigger.net/web-security"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Web Security Academy</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/Burp_Suite"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">BurpSuite on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Have you ever wondered how hackers find vulnerabilities and how companies can find and fix their own? You will find out today! On average 30,000 new websites are hacked every day.</p> <p>Our guest for this episode is James Kettle. James is the Director of Research at PortSwigger Web Security where he explores new ways to attack websites and designs and refines vulnerability detection techniques for the Burp Suites scanner. </p> <p>James shares his hacking experience and hard work helping companies keep their websites secure from all the crazy stuff going on out there.  On today’s episode, James shares his expertise to help you be more aware of possible red flags and prevention measures to take to protect yourself and your website.</p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[00:40] - When James was at university he saw that Google said they would pay anybody that could hack their website. He thought that sounded like fun and spent a huge amount of time doing that. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[01:02] - Now James works at PortSwigger and researches new techniques to hack websites. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[01:11] - Bounty programs are where a company wants to make sure their product or website doesn’t get hacked by malicious people so they go out and publicly say that anyone is welcome to try and hack their website. If you are successful and you don’t do any damage, but you tell them how you did it they will pay you for it and then fix it. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[03:45] - Pen testing is the classic approach to securing your website where you pay a consultant to spend one or two weeks trying to hack your website. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[05:14] - It is totally worth it to get that third party view. Developers often can’t find problems with their own products. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[06:13] - If you want to find a vulnerability on a website you need to use an attack technique.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[07:15] - These days they see a lot of cross-site scripting vulnerabilities and it’s the most common one they see. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[07:37] - One of the most common causes of high impact breaches is access control issues.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[08:45] - James shares the biggest data breach they were able to do during their testing. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[10:31] - Try to use a framework whenever possible, because it makes things like sequel injection less likely to happen.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[11:01] - The standard approach after you make the website is to try to get someone else to look at it. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[11:27] - With Wordpress, it is very important to keep it up to date, install as few plug-ins as possible, and choose a good password. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:08] - Use as few browser extensions as possible to avoid possible malware issues. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[15:25] - Most people are not being personally targeted by hackers so the threats that most people need to watch out for are things that can be automated. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:10] - If you are using the same password on multiple websites you are going to get hacked. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:02] - A common misconception is that if you have a strong unique password then it doesn’t matter if you reuse it. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:03] - James uses websites with the assumption that all the data I give this website is going to end up public at some point. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:45] - Provide the minimum information possible. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[20:19] - James shares his all-time favorite story. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:33] - If an entity builds their security around detecting when people are attacking them then running a bug bounty would be harmful because they have no idea who is legitimate or hostile. If your website is on the internet, it is being attacked.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:35] - When you are being attacked, it is important to know that it most likely isn’t personal.</li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://haveibeenpwned.com/">Have I Been Pwned</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://portswigger.net/">PortSwigger</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://portswigger.net/burp">Burp Suite</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://portswigger.net/web-security">Web Security Academy</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/Burp_Suite">BurpSuite on Twitter</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Multi-level Marketing with Casey Bond</title>
			<itunes:title>Multi-level Marketing with Casey Bond</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 27 May 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[07146239-cbf0-4531-9488-67a43d8036af]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/14/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">You have probably heard of multi-level marketing also called MLM or network marketing. A multi-level marketing company is a company that recruits people to sell their products to their network including their friends and family. Network marketers typically buy inventory and then try to sell it. They can also recruit people underneath them and create a triangular shape in which they can collect commissions on the people underneath them who are also making sales.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Casey Bond is a certified personal finance counselor and a lifestyle reporter for Huff Post covering money, home, and living. Her work has also appeared on Business Insider, Yahoo! Finance, MSN, The Motley Fool, U.S. News & World Report, Forbes, TheStreet, and more. Casey has been reporting on MLM’s for the past year. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The big question many people wonder is if multi-level marketing is a great business opportunity or an opportunity to lose thousands. On today’s episode, Casey shares her expertise to help you make the decision that is right for you and help you beware of possible red flags. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:13] - A multi-level marketing company is a company that recruits people to sell their products to their friends and family and their network. It is also called network marketing or direct selling. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:29] - They typically buy inventory and then try to sell it. They can also recruit people underneath them and create a triangular shape in which they can collect commissions on the people underneath them who are also making sales. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:14] - You will find a wide range of products offered including everything from kitchen knives to insurance products. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:23] - Most multi-level marketing companies sell products that are traditionally marketed towards women. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:06] - These days the gig economy is huge. One-third of adults are involved in the gig economy somehow. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:02] - It is often presented as a way to make a ton of money in your spare time, and be able to win vacations, cars, and extra products. That is usually the case for a small percentage of people involved in MLM’s who usually got in very early and built a huge downline. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:41] - The key for being successful in an MLM is not necessarily making a lot of sales, but instead recruiting a lot of people underneath you. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:37] - A big red flag is having to buy your inventory upfront. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:10] - Another big red flag is when the initial details of this opportunity are vague or coming from someone you don’t know very well. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:40] - MLM’s really play into the emotional side of people who would really like to have something of their own and who would really like to become more financially independent. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:39] - The FTC watches and keeps an eye on the MLM industry. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:14] - Illegal pyramids schemes do operate legally until they are caught. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:50] - The Direct Selling Association oversees all MLM and direct selling companies. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:48] - Casey is very hesitant to recommend multi-level marketing to anyone because it is so easy to get in a hole with debt or overspending when there are so many other ways to make extra income. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:28] - It’s best to go out and create something for yourself instead of relying on an MLM. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:52] - The FTC does have an option on their website to report companies that are operating questionably. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:46] - Working for an MLM can put strains on relationships and friendships. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li><a href="https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://www.huffpost.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Huff Post</span></a></li> <li><a href= "https://www.huffpost.com/author/casey-bond"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Casey on Huff Post</span></a></li> <li><a href="https://twitter.com/CaseyLynnBond"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Casey Lynn Bond on Twitter</span></a></li> </ul>]]></description>
