			<title>Workplace Bullying with Timothy Dimoff</title>
			<itunes:title>Workplace Bullying with Timothy Dimoff</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 20 May 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[0d8fbe62-7302-46a2-9198-cafaa35b1865]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/13/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Workplace bullying and violence seldom happens in a vacuum but rather are led up to with warning signs and events. In this episode, I talk with Timothy Dimoff about workplace bullying and violence. Workplace bullying is usually not physical, but it is ongoing. We talk about steps you can take if you are a victim of workplace bullying and ways to prevent it from the very beginning. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Timothy Dimoff is president of SACS Consulting and Investigative Services, a high-risk HR and security consulting and investigation firm. As a nationally recognized expert in high-risk security and human resources, he is a sought after consultant, speaker, media commentator, and expert witness. Timothy has more than 40 years of experience in law enforcement, corporate security, and consulting. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We talk about workplace bullying and violence and exactly what they are and the difference between the two. We specifically discuss what types of behaviors to look out for, things you can do to limit these behaviors, and how you can protect yourself from emotional and physical violence. Timothy shares steps you can take if you are a victim of workplace bullying or violence. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:48] - Timothy’s first career was 20 years in law enforcement at an Akron, Ohio police department, and then the federal task force. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:04] - His career has been rewarding because he has been able to take everything he has been taught in both careers and apply it toward a positive. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:34] - The low-level workplace bullying is intimidation. People go out of their way to embarrass, intimidate, or degrade someone to get themselves to a higher level, promotion, or even just look better. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:21] - Higher-level workplace bullying is when somebody that really just has a higher level of anger or dislike for someone and they really want to go out of their way to damage them in some way. It could be physical, but a lot of times it is just mental or social. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:05] - You need to watch out for someone setting up and presenting you as somebody that you're not. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:18] - Human nature is simple. Where you get your reaction is where you continue and the severity increases. Try and downplay anything that happens especially in the beginning stages. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:50] - Bullying is defined by one major thing. It is an ongoing continuous off and on type of action. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:39] - You should be logging what is going on with the date, time, what they said, and what they did. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:47] - About a third of the accusations that happen they discover are false. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:27] - It is very difficult for companies to investigate these types of cases internally by themselves. Using an outside company sets the tone that this type of behavior will not be tolerated. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:49] - If the bullying goes unanswered by management it can turn into workplace violence. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:50] - Sometimes employers terminate an employee and get some pretty strong messages of aggression or potential retaliation. Once you have any kind of termination and there is an indication of these things you need to put some precautionary measures in place. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:02] - SACS has a threat response team that they deploy out to boost security, research the potential perpetrator, assess their level of anger and aggression, monitor them, and figure out how to track them and defuse them down. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:32] - As a society, we are showing more aggression as an answer to disagreements. Many people think that it is a proper reaction and they have a right to respond that way. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:23] - Sports, politics, and other types of events and debates can get very aggressive, mean, and attacking. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:48] - Timothy’s number one suggestion for any employee that feels uncomfortable or unsafe is logging the instances. That gets more effective results than anything else they can do. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:16] - What if it’s the owner of the company that is treating their employees this way?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:37] - If you are having problems with your direct supervisor then you take your complaints to the CFO, HR person, or another supervisor you respect and ask if they can help you. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:12] - Bullying is not just between employee and employee. A supervisor has a distinct advantage to use their level against an employee in the wrong way. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:05] - SACS Consulting works with both companies and individuals. Most companies call them to objectively find the truth. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:37] -SACS Consulting will work with companies if they want to find and live with the truth. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Workplace bullying and violence seldom happens in a vacuum but rather are led up to with warning signs and events. In this episode, I talk with Timothy Dimoff about workplace bullying and violence. Workplace bullying is usually not physical, but it is ongoing. We talk about steps you can take if you are a victim of workplace bullying and ways to prevent it from the very beginning. </p> <p>Timothy Dimoff is president of SACS Consulting and Investigative Services, a high-risk HR and security consulting and investigation firm. As a nationally recognized expert in high-risk security and human resources, he is a sought after consultant, speaker, media commentator, and expert witness. Timothy has more than 40 years of experience in law enforcement, corporate security, and consulting. </p> <p>We talk about workplace bullying and violence and exactly what they are and the difference between the two. We specifically discuss what types of behaviors to look out for, things you can do to limit these behaviors, and how you can protect yourself from emotional and physical violence. Timothy shares steps you can take if you are a victim of workplace bullying or violence. </p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[00:48] - Timothy’s first career was 20 years in law enforcement at an Akron, Ohio police department, and then the federal task force. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:04] - His career has been rewarding because he has been able to take everything he has been taught in both careers and apply it toward a positive. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:34] - The low-level workplace bullying is intimidation. People go out of their way to embarrass, intimidate, or degrade someone to get themselves to a higher level, promotion, or even just look better. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[03:21] - Higher-level workplace bullying is when somebody that really just has a higher level of anger or dislike for someone and they really want to go out of their way to damage them in some way. It could be physical, but a lot of times it is just mental or social. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[04:05] - You need to watch out for someone setting up and presenting you as somebody that you're not. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[05:18] - Human nature is simple. Where you get your reaction is where you continue and the severity increases. Try and downplay anything that happens especially in the beginning stages. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[06:50] - Bullying is defined by one major thing. It is an ongoing continuous off and on type of action. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[07:39] - You should be logging what is going on with the date, time, what they said, and what they did. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[09:47] - About a third of the accusations that happen they discover are false. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[10:27] - It is very difficult for companies to investigate these types of cases internally by themselves. Using an outside company sets the tone that this type of behavior will not be tolerated. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[12:49] - If the bullying goes unanswered by management it can turn into workplace violence. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:50] - Sometimes employers terminate an employee and get some pretty strong messages of aggression or potential retaliation. Once you have any kind of termination and there is an indication of these things you need to put some precautionary measures in place. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:02] - SACS has a threat response team that they deploy out to boost security, research the potential perpetrator, assess their level of anger and aggression, monitor them, and figure out how to track them and defuse them down. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:32] - As a society, we are showing more aggression as an answer to disagreements. Many people think that it is a proper reaction and they have a right to respond that way. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:23] - Sports, politics, and other types of events and debates can get very aggressive, mean, and attacking. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:48] - Timothy’s number one suggestion for any employee that feels uncomfortable or unsafe is logging the instances. That gets more effective results than anything else they can do. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[20:16] - What if it’s the owner of the company that is treating their employees this way?</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:37] - If you are having problems with your direct supervisor then you take your complaints to the CFO, HR person, or another supervisor you respect and ask if they can help you. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:12] - Bullying is not just between employee and employee. A supervisor has a distinct advantage to use their level against an employee in the wrong way. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[24:05] - SACS Consulting works with both companies and individuals. Most companies call them to objectively find the truth. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:37] -SACS Consulting will work with companies if they want to find and live with the truth. </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li 			<title>Trust and Encryption with Casey Crane</title>
			<itunes:title>Trust and Encryption with Casey Crane</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 13 May 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[c680c195-71be-4822-963d-63a157ddd903]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/12/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Just because something is secure, doesn’t mean that it’s safe. The S in HTTPS doesn’t always mean safe. In this episode, I talk with Casey Crane about trust and encryption. We discussed many practical ways for you to avoid being a victim of a scam. Prevention and knowledge can help stop many attacks before they even begin. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Casey Crane is a cybersecurity writer for Hashed Out at The SSL Store. Casey is a regular contributor to Hashed Out with 10+ years of experience in journalism and writing, including crime analysis and IT security. She also serves as a Content Marketer at The SSL Store. She has bachelor’s and master’s degrees in mass communications (in journalism and media studies) from the University of South Florida and USF St. Petersburg. Casey is passionate about data privacy and wants to educate others about encryption because it plays such an integral role in our daily lives (even though many people don’t know it!). </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We talk about trust and encryption and best practices for protecting you, your family, and your business. We specifically discuss what you need to look for before clicking on a link or downloading anything. We talk about different types of SSL certificates and how to figure out which one would be the best fit for your website. This episode will help you figure out if you need an SSL certificate and reputable and trusted sources that can help.  </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Show Notes:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:35] - Casey works at the SSL Store as a content writer for the website and Hashed Out. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:17] - She wrote her master thesis on the relationship between serial killers and the media in terms of how they are represented. She has always had a keen interest in learning more about crime and criminal elements and it just transitioned over time into the realm of technology and cybersecurity. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:22] - What are HTTPS and SSL certificates?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:15] - HTTPS is an encrypted communication channel between one party to another. Passwords and personal information are encrypted. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:59] - Domain validated means that the person who requested the certificate gets an email. The email typically has a link or some files they need to upload to and that is about it. Organization and extended validation are two levels of validation above that. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:29] - The Anti-Phishing Working Group reported nearly three-quarters of websites that were phishing websites used an SSL or TSL certificate. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:21] - There are Unicode domains which basically pull from different languages, character, numerals, and signs. Those are now being used in web domains. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:25] - Criminals tend to go for the lowest hanging fruit. They want to make this as easy as possible for themselves to save time and make the most profit or achieve their agenda quickest. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:50] - If you get an email before you actually click on anything check the header in the email and see who the email is coming from. Check that the email and name match. Often the email is off by one letter or digit.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:59] - Scams often create some sort of feeling of urgency, curiosity, fear, or concern so people are motivated to want to answer that email quickly by clicking on the link or calling a provided number. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:25] - From a website owner perspective or an admin perspective it is about knowing which certificate you should be putting on your site. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:02] - If you are collecting any financial information you should be using an OV certificate at minimum. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:48] - In countries where the internet service is less reputable or you are concerned about your government snooping on what you’re doing, having the encrypted communication channel between you and the website prevents the content that is going back and forth from being seen. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:57] - Sometimes an issue that people tend to run into is that they just forget to check their certificates. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:40] - The shorter the validation is for a certificate the more secure it is because there would be less time for a cybercriminal to be able to crack the encryption. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:14] - The current standard for validation is 2 years for public certificates. It is continually changing and will keep changing.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:16] - Certificate managers are programs that can help you manage the certificate and the life cycle of the certificate. There are different programs based on your preferences and needs. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:56] - When you are able to keep your certificates valid you are avoiding issues and downtime. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:09] - The actual encryption from certificate to certificate is the same. It is still the standard encryption that is provided. It is just the extra features that vary per certificate.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:45] - Where can people go to get an SSL certificate? What should they be looking at to decide what is right for them?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:36] - Find a reputable source and then figure out what level of validation you need for a certificate. Then you need to choose the functionality of the certificate. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:57] - You want to make sure to choose a warranty as well. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Links and Resources:</span></h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span 			<title>Ransomware with Craig MacAlpine and Joel Witts</title>
			<itunes:title>Ransomware with Craig MacAlpine and Joel Witts</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 06 May 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[1b93abc1-c357-402e-909b-6ea259ee5a21]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/11]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">School districts, health care organizations, cities, and towns have all been victims of ransomware. Families have lost access to photo albums of 20 years of memories and personal finances. It can be a very devastating experience. It is very scary to not be able to do your job or access your data.  Now attackers are not only threatening to delete your data, but they are also threatening to leak the data.  This can cause lawsuits, legal ramifications, and a huge headache for businesses large and small. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">What is ransomware?  Ransomware is a type of malware that gets installed on your machine and it locks all of your files so you can’t access them.  It spreads very quickly through your computer and you may be unable to access crucial programs and files.  Often you get a message from the attackers requesting money or your data will be leaked or deleted. Craig and Joel share their expert insights on how to prevent these attacks. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Craig MacAlpine is the founder and CEO of</span> <a href= "https://www.expertinsights.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Expert Insights</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and a passionate security innovator with over 20 years of experience in information security and product management previously founding e-mail security company EPA Cloud. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Joel Witts is a Senior Content Editor at</span> <a href= "https://www.expertinsights.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Expert Insights</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">covering a multitude of areas including cybersecurity.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We talk about ransomware and best practices for protecting you, your family and your business.  We specifically discuss ways ransomware can get in, how you can be affected, and ways to protect against it.  We talk about secure gateway products, post-delivery protection, and isolation.  This episode will help you figure out what solution can offer the best protection to your family and business.  </span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:38] - Ransomware is a type of malware that gets installed on your machine and it locks all of your files so you can’t access them.  It spreads very quickly through your computer and may be unable to access crucial programs and files.  Often you get a message from the attackers requesting money or your data will be leaked or deleted. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:14] - With a lot of scams there is a level of emotion and urgency in the ransom component.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:50] -</span> <a href= "https://www.travelex.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Travelex</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">was hit on New Year’s Eve this past year and it closed their operations down for a week while they had to go to a manual basis and had a 32 million dollar hit. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:08] - Ransomware is something that affects all the way up from small to large businesses.  The most common targets are healthcare, education, towns, and cities.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:19] - The average ransom sum is increasing to over $40,000. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:01] - There is conflicting advice on whether the company should pay the ransom or not.  There is no guarantee that you will get your data back.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:59] - Ransomware has become more of a well-known issue.  Businesses are putting more measures in place to try and mitigate the risks from these threats. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:10] - A common way for ransomware to start in an organization is through phishing attacks which are difficult to stop.  Phishing is a type of email that tries to trick a user into performing an action.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:31] - If you have got a savvy phisher whose updating that content it is really hard for the gateway systems to pick that up.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:14] - The email may be the start of the phish, but not the method that the malware is downloaded that is just where they start the conversation. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:03] - Secure gateway products usually do a good job stopping spam and phishing emails.  Typically 98-99% of these threats will get stopped with those products.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:03] - Someone can get remote access to your email account and forward the emails.  The user isn’t even aware of what is going on in their email account. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:04] - Post-delivery protection looks for compromised accounts and phishing emails coming from a genuine internal account emailing someone else within your business. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:10] - If you are an IT manager or IT professional you’re asking for trouble not installing two-factor or multifactor identification.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:17] - E-mail is your gateway to connect with someone, but the malware usually comes through the web like a download.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:34] - Isolation could be the solution, but it will be a while before this option comes to consumers.  It is a process that takes a while to get to the home-use level.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:55] - With isolation videos or documents would be rendered for your viewing, but not actually be downloaded to your machine.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:43] - If someone does become a victim of ransomware what are their options?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:59] - Realistically if back-ups are not automated they are not going to happen.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:06] - The IT manager is often a jack of all trades trying to oversee the phone systems, PC updates, and more.  Back-ups are not prioritized, because if something isn’t broken then we don’t have time to fix it today.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[36:13] - Over time there will be more advanced and automated systems that will block the vast majority of ransomware, but there will still be some carefully crafted scams that will be hard to catch.  It will probably become less frequent, but never entirely go away. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:07] - The scammers only have to get it right once, but the people that are protecting against it have to get it right 100% of the time. There will always be an element of human mistake because of emotions and fear.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:46] - The attacks can be very effective because of fear and time sensitivity even if technologically we are able to stop them.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[40:28] - Great advice is to not panic if you get hit by ransomware.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 			<title>Identity Theft with Dana Mantilia</title>
			<itunes:title>Identity Theft with Dana Mantilia</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 29 Apr 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[728a98f0-7417-4e4a-82cf-9ecf320b262a]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/identity-theft-with-dana-mantilia/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><!--more--></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Identity theft comes in many forms. Children and adults can be victims of identity theft.  Each year there are over 9 million identity victims.  1 million of these victims are minor children. The worst part is that we often don’t notice a problem until we need to buy a car, house, or get a college loan. The clean-up process can be costly and time-consuming.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dana Mantilia is the founder of</span> <a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Identity Protection Planning</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.  Dana grew up in the car business.  She was running and still oversees her family’s car dealership today.  In 2014 they wanted to open an insurance agency so they could offer insurance to their customers, and shortly after in 2017 she decided to get into the identity theft world and business. </span></p> <p><a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Identity Protection Planning</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">helps Americans protect themselves, their family, and businesses from identity theft and cybercrime.</span> <a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Identity Protection Planning</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">was established to help educate, organize, and protect folks against identity theft. Her team established a user-friendly B2B software platform that allows agents, advisors, employers, and association managers to offer Identron identity theft protection plans to their clients, employees, or members.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We talk about identity theft, data breaches, and best practices for protecting you, your family, and your business.  Dana shares several practical tips and best practices that you can put in place today to help protect against identity theft. </span></p> <h3>Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:32] - Dana shares how she got into the identity theft business.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:58] - Often with identity theft cases, you have to pay first to start the cleaning process. It can be expensive to start the process and maybe you will get some of that money back later.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:59] - What is identity theft? Identity theft is someone using someone’s social security number to get a loan, a job, get credit, or file taxes.  It often happens with children’s information. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:35] - The best thing to do with a child’s social security number is to freeze their credit.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:32] - Don’t give out your social security number or your child’s unless absolutely necessary. Be careful not to give your personal information out online.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:34] - Informed delivery with the post office is a great service to make sure all your mail actually makes it to you.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:18] - It is very important to have different passwords for different accounts. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:02] - Dana suggests getting a different email to associate with all financial accounts.  Use a password manager app with more complex passwords.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:15] - Stop doing Facebook quizzes.  Identity thieves actually create some of these quizzes.  They often ask questions to figure out security question answers. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:42] - Identity theft prevention service helps you with forms you need to fill out, government agencies you need to contact, and they help you along the process if your identity was stolen.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:45] - Keep close tabs and don’t give out your driver’s license number, medical insurance card, and birth date unless absolutely necessary.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:57] - Everybody should have either a fingerprint lock, gesture, or passcode on their phone because we are logged into most of our accounts.  If you lose that phone, they can change your passwords and log-in credentials.    </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:53] - Use two-factor identification is a great security measure to protect your accounts. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:18] - On Google and Apple phones, you can enable a service that allows you to remotely wipe your phone.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:33] - On your phone, you can see which apps have access to your photos, microphones, contacts, and location. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:57] - One time per year on each of the three different credit bureaus you can run your credit for free.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:33] - Identity theft protection services and insurance are a valuable service because it is something we are not good at and don’t want to spend the time doing those things if we can even remember to do them.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:57] - Most children are getting social security numbers right when they are born.  As soon as you get your hands on your child’s social security number, you should be freezing it.  </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p>[bctt tweet="“Your identity is great until it is messed up. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p></p> <p>Identity theft comes in many forms. Children and adults can be victims of identity theft.  Each year there are over 9 million identity victims.  1 million of these victims are minor children. The worst part is that we often don’t notice a problem until we need to buy a car, house, or get a college loan. The clean-up process can be costly and time-consuming.  </p> <p>Dana Mantilia is the founder of <a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/">Identity Protection Planning</a>.  Dana grew up in the car business.  She was running and still oversees her family’s car dealership today.  In 2014 they wanted to open an insurance agency so they could offer insurance to their customers, and shortly after in 2017 she decided to get into the identity theft world and business. </p> <p><a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/">Identity Protection Planning</a> helps Americans protect themselves, their family, and businesses from identity theft and cybercrime. <a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/">Identity Protection Planning</a> was established to help educate, organize, and protect folks against identity theft. Her team established a user-friendly B2B software platform that allows agents, advisors, employers, and association managers to offer Identron identity theft protection plans to their clients, employees, or members.</p> <p>We talk about identity theft, data breaches, and best practices for protecting you, your family, and your business.  Dana shares several practical tips and best practices that you can put in place today to help protect against identity theft. </p> Show Notes: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[00:32] - Dana shares how she got into the identity theft business.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:58] - Often with identity theft cases, you have to pay first to start the cleaning process. It can be expensive to start the process and maybe you will get some of that money back later.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[03:59] - What is identity theft? Identity theft is someone using someone’s social security number to get a loan, a job, get credit, or file taxes.  It often happens with children’s information. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[05:35] - The best thing to do with a child’s social security number is to freeze their credit.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[06:32] - Don’t give out your social security number or your child’s unless absolutely necessary. Be careful not to give your personal information out online.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[07:34] - Informed delivery with the post office is a great service to make sure all your mail actually makes it to you.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[08:18] - It is very important to have different passwords for different accounts. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[09:02] - Dana suggests getting a different email to associate with all financial accounts.  Use a password manager app with more complex passwords.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[11:15] - Stop doing Facebook quizzes.  Identity thieves actually create some of these quizzes.  They often ask questions to figure out security question answers. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[13:42] - Identity theft prevention service helps you with forms you need to fill out, government agencies you need to contact, and they help you along the process if your identity was stolen.   </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[15:45] - Keep close tabs and don’t give out your driver’s license number, medical insurance card, and birth date unless absolutely necessary.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:57] - Everybody should have either a fingerprint lock, gesture, or passcode on their phone because we are logged into most of our accounts.  If you lose that phone, they can change your passwords and log-in credentials.    </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:53] - Use two-factor identification is a great security measure to protect your accounts. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:18] - On Google and Apple phones, you can enable a service that allows you to remotely wipe your phone.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:33] - On your phone, you can see which apps have access to your photos, microphones, contacts, and location. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[20:57] - One time per year on each of the three different credit bureaus you can run your credit for free.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:33] - Identity theft protection services and insurance are a valuable service because it is something we are not good at and don’t want to spend the time doing those things if we can even remember to do them.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:57] - Most children are getting social security numbers right when they are born.  As soon as you get your hands on your child’s social security number, you should be freezing it.  </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <p>[bctt tweet="“Your identity is great until it is messed up. The challenges identity theft can bring are monumental.” - Chris Parker" username="easypreypodcast"]</p> Links and Resources: <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.identityprotectionplanning.com/">Identity Protection Planning</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.identron.com/">Identron</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/Identron.Protection/">Identron on Facebook</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnKQTPi2Td2Kx7m4-1hD2cA"> Identity Protection Planning on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/dana-mantilia/">Dana on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/data-breaches-with-troy-hunt/"> Data Breaches with Troy Hunt</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.ssa.gov/">SSA.gov</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>

			<title>Website Attacks with John Graham-Cumming and Evan Johnson</title>
			<itunes:title>Website Attacks with John Graham-Cumming and Evan Johnson</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 22 Apr 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[d472f848-dcde-4b70-8b18-8292703b255b]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Website attacks are very common.  They are often not personal, but they can create a mess for website operators.  As website owners and operators, we need website privacy and security especially if we are collecting data and personal information.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">As I was making more money from my business in 2015,  the need for better performance became an issue.  I also needed to be able to keep my site up 24/7 and not have to deal with outages. My website started getting sustained 500-bit denial service attacks.  I realized very quickly that this was not my expertise, but that is when I began my partnership with Cloudflare.  </span></p> <p><a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">provides services that increase the security performance of over 26 million internet properties around the world from individual blogs to governments to Fortune 500 companies. </span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">offers services to accelerate internet applications and mobile experiences, mitigate DDoS attacks, prevent customer data breaches, stop malicious bot abuse, and more.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our guests on today’s show are John Graham and Evan Johnson. John Graham is a British software engineer and the current CTO at</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">. Evan is a Product Security Manager at</span> <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We talk about attacks on websites, distributed denial of service attacks, and how to protect your own website.  If you want to keep your website up and running without skipping a beat, this is a must-listen episode. </span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:58] - Chris is a</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">customer and shares how he became a</span> <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">customer. He shares his history of working with</span> <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.    </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:05] - In 2015 Chris started getting sustained 500-bit denial services attacks. He realized it was not his expertise and he needed help with this.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:23] - John and Evan share the risks that</span> <a href="https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">helps website owners protect against.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:53] - What things should we worry about as website operators?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:09] - Evan is recommending businesses move more of their applications to the edge with workers with</span> <a href="https://workers.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare Workers</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.  It has real security benefits. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:29] - The big benefit of</span> <a href= "https://workers.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare Workers</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is that there is no back-end server to overwhelm.  It just moves the application to all of their servers.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:38] - Often hackers are using automated tools to scan websites, so you really want to limit the ability for that scanner to see something.  Then they will just move on.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:39] - Anyone that has a database should prepare for the contingency if you get your database breached. Know your legal obligations in dealing with that especially if you are storing personally identifiable information.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:01] - With</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">, you can identify a problem and have it blocked almost immediately.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:58] - It is really hard to patch your website fast enough.  So a WAF can give you some breathing room while you patch the back end systems.  Everyone should have a WAF, it is an extra layer that can really, really help. A WAF is a web application firewall.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:16] - If you are connected to the public internet and you provide a service or website</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">can protect that.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:13] - Use a good password and have two-factor identification.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:11] -</span> <a href= "https://workers.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare Workers</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is super flexible and easy to write since you use Javascript.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:46] - John shares how</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is able to offer free DDos services to their users.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:12] -</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">believes that your data is your data.  They analyze it for you to provide your analytics and to look for attacks but they don’t use your data. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:34] -</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is a way to get a level of protection for an inexpensive price.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:40] - With your back-end servers, you want to make sure you orange cloud things. </span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is seeing the requests and it is being proxied through their network.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:09] - With</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">’s new project</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/magic-transit/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Magic Transit</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">they can take over the IP space and become your network.  The traffic comes to</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">so they can run the services they provide and then pass the good traffic back on to you. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:30] -</span> <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cloudflare</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">tries to take things that are expensive and complex and make them easy to use and cheap so that everyone gets access to these cool tools.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:16] - People started to realize that they are using the internet for absolutely everything from banking to dating and it really matters that they protect that and use things that are trustworthy.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:51] - If there is one password and two-factor you are going to use, put it on your personal email because if someone breaks into your personal email they can probably reset the password on every other service you use. Secure your email first. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p><strong>Links and Resources:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast The traffic comes to <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/">Cloudflare</a> so they can run the services they provide and then pass the good traffic back on to you. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[30:30] - <a href= "https://www.cloudflare.com/">Cloudflare</a> tries to take things that are expensive and complex and make them easy to use and cheap so that everyone gets access to these cool tools.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[32:16] - People started to realize that they are using the internet for absolutely everything from banking to dating and it really matters that they protect that and use things that are trustworthy.</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[32:51] - If there is one password and two-factor you are going to use, put it on your personal email because if someone breaks into your personal email they can probably reset the password on every other service you use. Secure your email first. </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Catfishing, Coronavirus, and Cybercrime, oh my, with Tyler Cohen Wood</title>
			<itunes:title>Catfishing, Coronavirus, and Cybercrime, oh my, with Tyler Cohen Wood </itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 15 Apr 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[b1158799-af80-4aa1-b9a2-e47fc0710f8b]]></guid>

			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your online identity is quickly becoming more crucial to your personal and professional success than in-person communications. But most of us don’t understand this digital Wild West and the dangers that lurk around every corner. Most of us are unaware of the digital breadcrumbs that we leave behind with every post, and how easy it is for a person with malicious intent to harm us. In her book,</span> <a href= "https://www.amazon.com/Catching-Catfishers-Pretenders-Predators-Perpetrators/dp/1601633076/"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">Catching the Catfishers</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">and on today’s episode Tyler Cohen Wood teaches us how to protect ourselves and our families from online predators.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tyler Cohen Wood is a cyber-authority with 20 years of highly technical experience at the Department of Defense. As a Cyber-, Intelligence, National Security Expert, three-time Author, and Public Speaker, Tyler is relied on for her wealth of knowledge and unique insights. Tyler served with the Defense Intelligence Agency as a Senior Intelligence Officer where she developed highly technical cyber-solutions and made recommendations significantly developing and changing critical cyber-policies and directives affecting current and future intelligence community programs. She has helped the White House, DoD, federal law enforcement and the intel community thwart many cyber threats to the USA. Tyler’s expertise has made her a frequent guest and writer for both national and local television, radio, print, and online media.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">What is catfishing?  What do parents need to do to protect their children online? What can you do in this uncertainty to protect yourself from cybersecurity issues?  In this information-packed episode, we answer all these questions and more.</span></p> <h3>Show Notes:</h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:02] - When Tyler first started her cybersecurity career, she was doing digital forensics for The Department of Defense Cyber Crime Center.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:01] - Parents often post pictures of kids and information without privacy settings.  This can put kids in potential danger.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:57] - Catfishing is someone pretending to be someone they're not in order to get you to do something or to give them information.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:31] - In most catfishing cases there are some monetary or other things they are actually looking for.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:30] - These attacks are always based on some fear or urgency. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:55] - It is really concerning that kids are being targeted now more than ever. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:35] - Predators target kids through online gaming platforms and social media apps.  It is so important for parents to really know what their kids are doing, who they are talking to and what accounts they have. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:05] - It is good to talk with your kids and sit with them and see what they are doing.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:36] - What do parents need to do to protect their children online?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[12:35] - Make sure you have accounts on all the same platforms that your kids do.  Often predators will start a conversation on Instagram and then move to an encrypted platform like TikTok, WeChat or WhatsApp.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:43] - Once a predator has a target they will continue to go after that target.  If they see someone that they consider “easy prey” they are going to go after that.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:58] - One of the number one things you should be watching out for is if someone claims to be somebody, but they don’t have an online presence normal for that person.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:15] - A Home Incident Response Plan involves talking with your kids about what to do if you have problems online including downloading malware.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:06] - In a Home Incident Response Plan you want to include a paper copy of all of the numbers of people that you would need to call in the event of identity theft or other emergency and all of your accounts. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:53] - If your friend sends you something that seems out of character or they’re using words that they don’t typically use that is an indication of a potential scam.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:12] - If anyone ever asks you for money on the spot just walk away.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:52] - Be really cognizant of what’s in the background of your photos.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:37] - You want to see what apps on your phone have access to.  They may have access to your microphone, video, or contacts. If they don’t need it then turn it off.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[28:12] - Fear, uncertainty, doubt, and urgency really get people in trouble.  Stop and take a breath before you react. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:26] - You have to take time right now to nurture yourself.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:08] - It is important to talk to our kids about what’s going on in the world right now.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:01] - Just be aware of what you're posting and what you’re doing and trying to be as paranoid as your be without being crazy paranoid. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <h3>Links and Resources:</h3> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web 			<title>Remote Worker Cybersecurity Risks with Dr. Eric Cole</title>
			<itunes:title>Remote Worker Cybersecurity Risks with Dr. Eric Cole</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 08 Apr 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[171fd809-bf05-41c7-9700-e26745827a4f]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/7]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">With over ten million cyber-attacks reported daily, we have to be equipped with the knowledge, information, and software to protect ourselves and our families. With the outbreak of the Coronavirus, there was a sudden shift of employees working at home and this has become even more of a problem. Since time wasn’t available for most businesses to create a well-thought-out plan, that opens the door for even more cyberattacks. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In this episode, Dr. Eric Cole and I talk about specific ways to make cyberspace a safe place to live and work. We talk about how to lock down your wireless access point, specific ways you need to update your computer, and most importantly how can you prevent these attacks. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">World-Renowned Cybersecurity Expert with more than 30 years of network security experience, Dr. Eric Cole is a distinguished cybersecurity expert and keynote speaker who helps organizations curtail the risk of cyber threats. Many of the foundational principles of this course and training in cybersecurity were developed by Dr. Cole. He has worked with a variety of clients ranging from Fortune 50 companies to top international banks, to the CIA, for which he was a professional hacker.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">While he started his career on the offense, he is now fully dedicated to understanding the adversary so he can provide cost-effective solutions that actually work. As a pioneer in the area of cybersecurity, he has been inducted into the Infosec hall of Fame, awarded the Cyber Wingman Award from the US Air Force, received multiple accommodations from the CIA and was part of the commission on cybersecurity for President Obama. He has been the featured speaker at many security events and also has been interviewed by several chief media outlets such as CNN, CBS News, FOX News and 60 Minutes.</span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:41] - Most businesses when they are making decisions usually look at the benefits and security risks. With everything happening so quickly right now it is just survival mode. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:15] - It is dangerous to get people up in running without a security plan because people assume that their home network is secure and protected, but often it is not. Most people were never meant to run their business off their home network. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:39] - The first step is to lock down your wireless access point. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:27] - If you are going to be clicking on links or opening email attachments about Corna or anything emotional use an Android, iPhone, or IPad. Don’t use Windows for doing that web surfing and email right now. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:03] - If you are running a business you need to pay for the commercial file storage. Free isn’t free. The free accounts are a higher risk to your business. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:24] - Search for directions to update your specific router and you will find easy to follow directions for your exact router. In less than 10 minutes your now in a much better position and much safer than you were ten minutes prior. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:13] - When it comes to cybersecurity you are going to pay the pipe. You either pay now or pay later. Do you want to spend 10 minutes now patching, locking down and updating your router or do you want to wait for 2-3 months when your data and identity are stolen and then you have to spend 300 hours trying to clean and fix everything?</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:24] - Make sure your password to log-in to your wi-fi is different than your administrative password. In the last 3-4 weeks, there has been an increase in cybercrime. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:10] - What people don’t realize is that free is not free. They are using your data. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:01] - If the service is really free and the company is staying in business there have to be some exposure points they are not telling people about.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:01] - No matter what somebody says or does never give away that second factor in your two-factor identification. Eric highly suggests account monitoring over two-factor identification. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:44] - Prevention is ideal, detection is a must. Set up account notifications so if someone is logging into your account or even attempting to log in you will get a text notification.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:24] - If you catch fraudulent bank activity within 24 hours it is usually reversible. Turn on your notifications so if something weird is going on with your account you will be notified immediately and can take action. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:33] - If you get a call from your bank saying there is a problem with your account, tell them you are going to hang up and call them back. If they start making excuses you should know there is a problem. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:00] - If you get an email that has an emotional response, urgency, and something feels a little off or unusual pick up the phone and verify it. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:44] - When working at home paranoia is your friend. Trust no one, admit nothing and make counter-accusations. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:21] - Make sure all software, operating systems and anything you are running is up to date. Check your support pieces like Adobe and Java. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:49] - When using Zoom or online teleconferencing programs set the additional passcode every time you do a conference meeting. You should also review everyone on the call. 			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>With over ten million cyber-attacks reported daily, we have to be equipped with the knowledge, information, and software to protect ourselves and our families. With the outbreak of the Coronavirus, there was a sudden shift of employees working at home and this has become even more of a problem. Since time wasn’t available for most businesses to create a well-thought-out plan, that opens the door for even more cyberattacks. </p> <p>In this episode, Dr. Eric Cole and I talk about specific ways to make cyberspace a safe place to live and work. We talk about how to lock down your wireless access point, specific ways you need to update your computer, and most importantly how can you prevent these attacks. </p> <p>World-Renowned Cybersecurity Expert with more than 30 years of network security experience, Dr. Eric Cole is a distinguished cybersecurity expert and keynote speaker who helps organizations curtail the risk of cyber threats. Many of the foundational principles of this course and training in cybersecurity were developed by Dr. Cole. He has worked with a variety of clients ranging from Fortune 50 companies to top international banks, to the CIA, for which he was a professional hacker.</p> <p>While he started his career on the offense, he is now fully dedicated to understanding the adversary so he can provide cost-effective solutions that actually work. As a pioneer in the area of cybersecurity, he has been inducted into the Infosec hall of Fame, awarded the Cyber Wingman Award from the US Air Force, received multiple accommodations from the CIA and was part of the commission on cybersecurity for President Obama. He has been the featured speaker at many security events and also has been interviewed by several chief media outlets such as CNN, CBS News, FOX News and 60 Minutes.</p> <p>Show Notes:</p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[01:41] - Most businesses when they are making decisions usually look at the benefits and security risks. With everything happening so quickly right now it is just survival mode. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:15] - It is dangerous to get people up in running without a security plan because people assume that their home network is secure and protected, but often it is not. Most people were never meant to run their business off their home network. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[02:39] - The first step is to lock down your wireless access point. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[04:27] - If you are going to be clicking on links or opening email attachments about Corna or anything emotional use an Android, iPhone, or IPad. Don’t use Windows for doing that web surfing and email right now. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[05:03] - If you are running a business you need to pay for the commercial file storage. Free isn’t free. The free accounts are a higher risk to your business. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[06:24] - Search for directions to update your specific router and you will find easy to follow directions for your exact router. In less than 10 minutes your now in a much better position and much safer than you were ten minutes prior. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[07:13] - When it comes to cybersecurity you are going to pay the pipe. You either pay now or pay later. Do you want to spend 10 minutes now patching, locking down and updating your router or do you want to wait for 2-3 months when your data and identity are stolen and then you have to spend 300 hours trying to clean and fix everything?</li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[09:24] - Make sure your password to log-in to your wi-fi is different than your administrative password. In the last 3-4 weeks, there has been an increase in cybercrime. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[11:10] - What people don’t realize is that free is not free. They are using your data. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[14:01] - If the service is really free and the company is staying in business there have to be some exposure points they are not telling people about.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:01] - No matter what somebody says or does never give away that second factor in your two-factor identification. Eric highly suggests account monitoring over two-factor identification. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[16:44] - Prevention is ideal, detection is a must. Set up account notifications so if someone is logging into your account or even attempting to log in you will get a text notification.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:24] - If you catch fraudulent bank activity within 24 hours it is usually reversible. Turn on your notifications so if something weird is going on with your account you will be notified immediately and can take action. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:33] - If you get a call from your bank saying there is a problem with your account, tell them you are going to hang up and call them back. If they start making excuses you should know there is a problem. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:00] - If you get an email that has an emotional response, urgency, and something feels a little off or unusual pick up the phone and verify it. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[21:44] - When working at home paranoia is your friend. Trust no one, admit nothing and make counter-accusations. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:21] - Make sure all software, operating systems and anything you are running is up to date. Check your support pieces like Adobe and Java. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:49] - When using Zoom or online teleconferencing programs set the additional passcode every time you do a conference meeting. You should also review everyone on the call. If there is an attendee you do not know you can knock them out of the call.  </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:17] - When taking a picture of your workspace, be conscious of what people can see on your screen and in the background. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[26:16] - Assume that your video camera is on and always dress appropriately for online videos. </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</a> and leave a nice review. </p> <p>Links and Resources:</p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Podcast Web Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast">Facebook Page</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">whatismyipaddress.com</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast">Easy Prey on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"> Easy Prey on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/">Easy Prey on Pinterest</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/DrEricCole/">Dr. Eric Cole on Facebook</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/drericcole">Dr. Eric Cole on Twitter</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCwg_j4TF1dnP9OZFXzYussA"> Dr. Eric Cole on YouTube</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/ericcole1/">Dr. Eric Cole on LinkedIn </a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/drericcole/">Dr. Eric Cole on Instagram</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.secure-anchor.com/cyberguide">Free CyberGuide</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://securityhaven.com/">Security Haven</a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://securityhaven.com/">Online Danger</a></li> </ul>]]></content:encoded>
