			<title>Hoaxes with Alex Kasprak</title>
			<itunes:title>Hoaxes with Alex Kasprak</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 01 Apr 2020 10:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[2b9359d1-5c98-4cf4-b4ce-3241fb607322]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/hoaxes-with-alex-kasprak/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In this day and age, we are experiencing knowledge overload. There is information everywhere on the internet and social media. Add in the changes and hoaxes we are seeing pop up with the Coronavirus and it is harder than ever to decipher the truth. How do we research and check out this overload of information? In this episode, Alex and I talk about many strategies you can use to be more aware and make the best decisions for yourself and your family. </span></p> <p><a href="https://www.snopes.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes.com</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">is a great resource for fact-checking information you receive.</span> <a href= "https://www.snopes.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes.com</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">does the research, cites its sources, and encourages you to do your own research. Alex shares the history of</span> <a href="https://www.snopes.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes.com</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and how the mission and company have grown into the information giant it is today. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alex Kasprak is a science writer and investigative journalist at Snopes. Before joining Snopes, he wrote about science at NASA’s Jet Propulsion Laboratory and at BuzzFeed. His work has been featured in The Atlantic, Motherboard, New Scientist, and other venues. These days, his work generally centers around scientific misinformation and long-term investigative projects. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Alex’s scientific background is in geological sciences. He has a master’s degree from Brown University, where his work focused on reconstructing environmental changes during a major mass extinction event by extracting molecular clues trapped in 200 million-year-old rocks. This research was published in the journal Geology in April 2015.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In addition, Alex has a master's degree in science writing from Johns Hopkins University. An adapted version of his Hopkins thesis essay was published online at The Atlantic under the title “The Desert Rock That Feeds the World” in November 2016.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When misinformation obscures the truth and readers don’t know what to trust,</span> <a href= "https://www.snopes.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes.com</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">’s fact-checking and original, investigative reporting lights the way to evidence-based and contextualized analysis. We always document our sources so readers are empowered to do independent research and make up their own minds.</span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:25] - Snopes has been around since 1994. It started as part of the Usenet Group dedicated to urban legends. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[01:39] - David Mikkelson and his wife Barbara spun it off into Snopes.com.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:04] - Now Snopes deals with social media misinformation, political stuff, and also investigative work. The mission and the size of the staff have grown over time. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:46] - Social media allows information to travel much faster than it used to through emails and other things. The tactics are always changing how misinformation gets around. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:40] - The most popular and most shared hoax on Snopes is the claim that posting something on your Facebook wall will legally prevent Facebook from using your material.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:39] - The underlying theme to most any conspiracy based hoax is that the government doesn’t want us to know this and is hiding it from us. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[08:52] - They often claim that the people debunking the myths are in cahoots with the people that are propagating the truth.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:22] - Hoaxes are designed to trick someone and are generally viral. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[09:53] - If a story feels too perfect for your personal or political viewpoints it is probably because someone is directly targeting you with that message. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:25] - The first thing to ask is does this seem too good to be true. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:20] - You can double-check most visual hoaxes by doing a reverse image search. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:49] - Different hoaxes target different demographics. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:53] - In general studies have suggested that older Americans are much more susceptible to online fake news than younger generations. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:46] - Political misinformation is typically targeted at making the other side look bad or your side look good. It doesn’t have a strong demographic component. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:46] - The motives for hoaxes can range anywhere from trying to be funny to financial motives. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:41] - Financial motives are the most common motivator for intentional misinformation. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:21] - Genuine innocent spreader heard something from somebody they thought was reliable and they shared it. It was wrong, but it went viral. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:08] - One outlandish hoax about the Coronavirus is the notion that holding your breath for 10 seconds can diagnose it. This is the most ridiculous scientific claim Alex has heard. It defies logic that that would be a scientific test. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:02] - Be careful of self-check and cure claims surrounding the Coronavirus. Another claim that sipping water every 15 minutes can cure the Coronavirus. Hydration is important, but you can not wash the virus down into your digestive tract to be destroyed. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:41] - When there are medical claims we have to be really careful not to follow the advice of people that are not physicians, doctors or people that don’t know our existing medical conditions and situations. Don’t take random advice. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:01] - Make sure to only read reputable sources like trusted news sources and governmental agencies. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[29:23] - In times of uncertainty we have to just take a step back, not share much, and accept the uncertainty and realize that if someone is reporting something with certainty at that time they are probably misinformed. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:01] With COVID-19 we are living in that uncertainty and doubt right now. Take a deep breath and don’t react out of haste. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:48] In crisis situations it is best to just not share information. Even a good intention to share information that comes without a named source doesn’t need to be shared and can often make the situation worse. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[31:20] Snopes.com is a credible news organization that you can check for information. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[32:44] Snopes suggests you take the argument they have presented and check it out for yourself. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p><strong>Links and Resources:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "http://www.alexkasprak.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alex’s Website</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/akasprak"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alex on Facebook</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/in/alex-kasprak-64457058/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alex on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/alexkasprak"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alex on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.snopes.com/author/alex/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Alex on Snopes</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/user/CaptainDisillusion"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Captain Disillusion on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.snopes.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/snopes"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Snopes on Facebook</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= It doesn’t have a strong demographic component. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[17:46] - The motives for hoaxes can range anywhere from trying to be funny to financial motives. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[18:41] - Financial motives are the most common motivator for intentional misinformation. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[19:21] - Genuine innocent spreader heard something from somebody they thought was reliable and they shared it. It was wrong, but it went viral. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[22:08] - One outlandish hoax about the Coronavirus is the notion that holding your breath for 10 seconds can diagnose it. This is the most ridiculous scientific claim Alex has heard. It defies logic that that would be a scientific test. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[23:02] - Be careful of self-check and cure claims surrounding the Coronavirus. Another claim that sipping water every 15 minutes can cure the Coronavirus. Hydration is important, but you can not wash the virus down into your digestive tract to be destroyed. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[25:41] - When there are medical claims we have to be really careful not to follow the advice of people that are not physicians, doctors or people that don’t know our existing medical conditions and situations. Don’t take random advice. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[27:01] - Make sure to only read reputable sources like trusted news sources and governmental agencies. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[29:23] - In times of uncertainty we have to just take a step back, not share much, and accept the uncertainty and realize that if someone is reporting something with certainty at that time they are probably misinformed. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[30:01] With COVID-19 we are living in that uncertainty and doubt right now. Take a deep breath and don’t react out of haste. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[30:48] In crisis situations it is best to just not share information. Even a good intention to share information that comes without a named source doesn’t need to be shared and can often make the situation worse. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[31:20] Snopes.com is a credible news organization that you can check for information. </li> <li style="font-weight: 400;">[32:44] Snopes suggests you take the argument they have presented and check it out for yourself. </li> </ul> <p>Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. 			<title>Coronavirus Scam Vigilance with Frank Figliuzzi</title>
			<itunes:title>Coronavirus Scam Vigilance with Frank Figliuzzi</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Thu, 26 Mar 2020 16:54:37 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[88208249-3dbc-441e-8920-775e46243a20]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/cv]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">With the worldwide virus pandemic, we are seeing things on Facebook, Twitter and in our email multiple times a day already. We are focused on remaining vigilant so we don’t contract the virus, but we also need to become vigilant so that we don’t become victims of the various cons, schemes, and scams that are already starting to surface. </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">During uncertain times we often see scams on a personal level, business level, and national geopolitical level.  It is important to be informed so that we can be protected in all areas.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Frank Figliuzzi is the former Assistant Director for Counterintelligence at the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Figliuzzi was previously the Special Agent in Charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Cleveland Division which includes all of northern Ohio, and the major cities of Cleveland, Toledo, Youngstown, Akron, and Canton. Following his FBI service, Figliuzzi joined General Electric and served for five years as Assistant Chief Security Officer for investigations, insider threat, workplace violence prevention, and special event security for GE's 300,000 employees in 180 countries. Figliuzzi is currently a frequent National Security Contributor for NBC and MSNBC News.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">A national pandemic is a target-rich opportunity for cons, schemes, and scams.  We have to make ourselves harder targets for the bad guys. It is really important that we don’t do things out of panic without researching, talking to people and seeking the right advice from the right people.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">What do we need to be looking for in an uncertain time to avoid being a victim of a scam or scheme?  Listen in as Frank and I discuss warning signs to look for and trusted resources you can turn in this very uncertain time.  </span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:55] - We are all so squirrely focused on remaining vigilant so we don’t contract the virus, but I’m here with a slightly different message which is that we have got to become vigilant so that we don’t become victims during the virus of various cons, schemes, and scams that are already starting to surface. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:15] - When you see something that doesn’t look or sound right go ahead and research it, find out if it’s wrong, and if it is wrong politely post your research.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[02:52] - Frank puts these scams in three different buckets.  There are scams for coronavirus on the personal level, business level, and national and geopolitical level.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:01] - It is really important that we don’t do things out of panic without researching, talking to people and seeking the right advice from the right people.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:48] - We have got to look out for each other on this. If you have elderly family or neighbors we have to pay extra attention to them. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:36] - If it is too good to be true, it’s not true. Trust your gut! Run it by 2 or 3 other people that you trust.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:53] - When it comes to charities, Frank’s advice is to stick with the well-established charities that you already donate to. </span> <a href= "https://www.charitynavigator.org/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Charity Navigator</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">will do the vetting for you.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[8:13] - If anybody is asking for your money or your personal identifiers right up front the alarm bells should go off.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[9:58] - Many businesses are not equipped from a cybersecurity perspective to deal with work from home.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:34] - We are going to see a huge increase in accounts payable fraud. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:51] - Get your IT people together and pay now for the increased security or you’re going to pay later.  Maybe some sensitive functions should not be functioning at home.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:00] - Testing is a great thing to do before you launch into massive work from home. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[13:28] - If looking for work from home options watch out for the too good to be true.  Always check out the opportunities and do your research. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[15:16] - Test first before you start producing products remotely and make sure that it can’t be interfered with.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:03] - With the government stimulus package coming out we will likely see emails pop up asking for your social security, date of birth, and address which is identity fraud.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[18:31] - Don’t fall for people reaching out to you by phone, e-mail, and snail-mail.  Go to a government site for the information.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:26] - The government will not call you.  You can verify through their websites and the official numbers.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[19:38] - Share this information about possible scams with your grandparents, parents, and adult young children to protect them.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:56] - We are in a polarized society.  So far it has been political polarization. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:22] - The fear is that we will move from political polarization to polarized responses to a pandemic and that can be very dangerous. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[22:15] - There is also a foreign influence to try and polarize us.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:14] - Do not be afraid to block and report anything that comes across your screen that looks like it is dangerous propaganda.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:43] - When there is something really scary that we don’t understand, it is a lot easier to blame something that we can identify than to recognize there is nothing we can do about the situation and we just have to wait.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:15] - Humans want simple solutions to the scariest, most complicated problems.  We want to embrace the hopeful and simple.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:14] When you click on something that offers you that simple explanation or solution you are probably making a mistake.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[25:21] This is one of those situations where you have emotions, urgency, panic, health and fear on a worldwide scale all rolled up together.  It is the ultimate opportunity for scam artists.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:07] Three trusted websites are</span> <a href="https://www.cdc.gov/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Centers for Disease Control</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">,</span> <a href= "https://www.who.int/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">World Health Organization</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, and</span> <a href="https://www.jhu.edu/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">John Hopkins University</span></a><span style= "font-weight: 400;">.  You should also consult the Department of Health from your state and county.</span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p><strong>Links and Resources:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast 			<title>Short Term Rental Scams with J. Massey</title>

			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[e5a4d357-ea33-46a5-8287-676163378d59]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/short-term-rental-scams-with-j-massey]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many of us love traveling, but safety and security are usually a concern in the back of our minds especially if we are traveling with our family.  So how do we stay safe and secure when we are traveling? J. teaches us what red flags to look for when reserving and staying with Airbnb. With a few extra steps any problem can often be prevented and in turn, keep you safer and more secure.  If you have thought about operating your own Airbnb tune in to find out what you need to be on the lookout for, how to be a responsive host and tools that J. offers to help you succeed.  </span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Massey is a full-time Real Estate Investor, Entrepreneur, Popular Podcast Host, Author, Speaker, Coach & All-Around Problem Solver. Cashflow Diary is a short-term rental hospitality training company. We show people how to build their own short-term rental business (without needing to buy or own any property) so they can thrive financially. Heralded as the most advanced short-term rental training in the industry, Cashflow Diary enjoys creating content and communities that are solely focused on developing individuals into powerful business owners. Founded by J. Massey, Cashflow Diary exists to create short-term rental entrepreneurs. No matter your passion, he believes that running a hospitality business will change people’s lives…</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Prior to entering the sharing economy, J. taught real estate strategies based on his years of experience. He owned hundreds of units, raised tens of millions of dollars, and even owned cell phone towers. He was all but “retired” at the age of 38 when one of his students asked what he knew about short-term rentals – the answer at the time was, “not very much.” He started looking into the model and was astounded at the opportunities it presented. J. now runs a 34 unit short-term rental business, and they create more profit faster than any other strategy he has seen before. That means that you too will now have a business that creates more profits to invest into whatever is most important to you—your family, your business, your future, and your community.</span></p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The bottom line is that because short-term rental businesses provide a financial safety net, you can take more risks, develop advanced business skills, and do more of what you’re passionate about.</span></p> <p><strong>Show Notes:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[00:35] - Chris shares an</span> <a href= "https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/43k7z3/nationwide-fake-host-scam-on-airbnb"> <span style="font-weight: 400;">article</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">from Allie Conti about her Airbnb problems and struggles. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[03:06] - As Allie digs into this particular host and their listings she finds out that this listing is actually being rented out by multiple people.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:18] - Common scams the renter is at risk of with Airbnb.</span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[04:38] - If you don’t know what you don’t know you wouldn’t know that you have an opportunity to discover this ahead of time.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[05:05] - The number one concern of people is safety and security.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[06:59] - Message the host right after the check out time the day you plan to arrive so they have a chance to respond to your inquiry.  Tell them when you are planning to arrive and ask if everything will be ready for your arrival. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[07:37] - If you don’t get a response then you would call and involve Airbnb directly. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[10:00] - Usually if you contact the renter by 12:30 PM they will know if something needs to be replaced or if they need longer for a maintenance issue.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:09] - Hosts that are less communicative and responsive to their listings get pushed down in the search results.  Those who are more responsive are more likely to have their search results near the top.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[11:39] - Keep your conversations inside the Airbnb platform. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[14:20] - If the host needs to move you ask for a link to the listing.  It needs to be on the Airbnb platform that you made your original reservation on.  Then you can verify it with Airbnb.   </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[16:44] - Most plumbing issues can not be resolved in one day.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[17:39] - Every listing can have a unique cancellation policy.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[20:20] - On the operators’ side there is a predictable pattern to those who have less than honest intentions.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[21:33] - If the property is substantially different when you arrive, you have to document the differences with pictures and videos and contact Airbnb. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:08] - If you know your arrival time is late all these preventive measures are extremely important before the cutoff time which is usually around 10 PM. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[23:43] - Read the listings. Don’t just look at the photos.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[24:21] - If you are suspicious of a place take a screenshot of any of the photos and do a Google image search.  It will tell you if the image is used frequently.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[26:57] - The biggest abuse for operators is with pet situations, but often they could suggest a better location for you and your pet.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[27:56] - Hosts need to know how many people are actually staying on the property for safety and security purposes. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[30:48] - Hosts know what bed bugs look like.  Renters will try to submit blurry photos of insects.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[33:39] - It is very common to say I couldn’t get in or I never stayed at a property.  Then the operator has to prove you stayed there with electronic door locks, key codes and other expert features.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[34:14] - If hosts know how to do proper screening checks on the front end most everything is preventable.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:02] - If you calculate the dollar per night per square foot of your hotel room, you will see how much you are paying for how little you are getting in exchange. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[37:31] When you choose to stay at a hotel you are choosing to eat out which is an additional cost. </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[38:04] With Airbnb properties you often have a full kitchen or at least a kitchenette.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[39:27] The demand for a different experience is high.  </span></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">[40:11]  J. has a</span> <a href= "https://cashflowdiary.outgrow.us/how-to-retire-on-airbnb-2"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> tool</span></a> <span style="font-weight: 400;">on his website to figure out how many units you need to have to retire. </span></li> </ul> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thanks for joining us on Easy Prey. Be sure to</span> <a href= "https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/easy-prey/id1488678905"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> subscribe to our podcast on iTunes</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and leave a nice review. </span></p> <p><strong>Links and Resources:</strong></p> <ul> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Podcast Web Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/EasyPreyPodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Facebook Page</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">whatismyipaddress.com</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.instagram.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Instagram</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://twitter.com/easypreypodcast"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Twitter</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.linkedin.com/company/easy-prey-podcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on LinkedIn</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCCgy_xKrjiXghSgGFEAFdTQ"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Easy Prey on YouTube</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.pinterest.com/easypreypodcast/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey on Pinterest</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://cashflowdiary.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cashflow Diary Website</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://cashflowdiary.com/listen/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">Cashflow Diary Podcast</span></a></li> <li style="font-weight: 400;"><a href= "https://www.facebook.com/CashflowDiary/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">J. 			<title>Business Email Compromise (BEC) Scams with Steve Weisman</title>
			<itunes:title>BEC Scams with Steve Weisman</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 18 Mar 2020 15:01:42 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[e41002b5-e736-4925-9383-55082c9135d0]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/bec-scams-with-steve-weisman/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have you ever been the victim of an email scam? Business Email Compromise is a type of scam where scammers focus on businesses that conduct wire transfers and work with suppliers abroad. There are many things businesses and consumers can be on the lookout for to avoid falling into these email traps.  Learn how to protect your information and money from these cyber attacks with Steve’s practical advice.  </span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Steve Weisman is a nationally recognized expert in scams, identity theft and cybersecurity as well as a lawyer, college professor and prolific author. In his informative speeches, articles, and books Steve makes difficult subjects such as cybersecurity, scams and identity theft not only understandable but enjoyable with the humor he brings to these complex issues.</span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Steve Weisman is a lawyer, admitted to practice before the United States Supreme Court. He is a college professor at Bentley University where he teaches “White Collar Crime.” He was awarded the Gregory H. Adamian Award, Bentley University’s highest award for teaching excellence.</span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">He is the author of more than ten books including</span> <em><a href= "https://scamicide.com/books/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Truth About Avoiding Scams</span></a></em><span style= "font-weight: 400;"> named by Smart Money Magazine as one of the ten best money books of the year. He has been awarded a Certificate of Merit for excellence in legal journalism by the American Bar Association. He has been a columnist for USA Today, Bankrate.com, the American Institute of Economic Research and the Saturday Evening Post. He has appeared throughout the media as an expert on scams, identity theft and cybersecurity including appearances on ABC, NBC, CNN, CBS CNBC, MSNBC, NECN NewsMax and Fox.  He also has been featured on the Dr. Phil Show. He has been quoted throughout the print media including the New York Times, the Washington Post, the Wall Street Journal, Barrons, Money Magazine and Forbes. He is a sought after public speaker with numerous appearances throughout the country.</span></p>]]></description>

			<title>Introduction</title>
			<itunes:title>Easy Prey Introduction</itunes:title>
			<pubDate>Wed, 18 Mar 2020 08:42:22 +0000</pubDate>
			<guid isPermaLink="false"><![CDATA[84ecbb9c-8120-4314-800c-17cec769dff7]]></guid>
			<link><![CDATA[https://www.easyprey.com/introduction/]]></link>
			<description><![CDATA[<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have you or your family been victims of identity theft, phishing, romance scams, or any other scams?  The true stories and actionable advice you will hear on this podcast can help save you money, headaches, and more.  </span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Chris Parker is the founder of</span> <a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">WhatIsMyIPAddress.com</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">and host of the</span> <a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Easy Prey podcast</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, which attracts over 6 million monthly visits. His website provides information on IP addresses, as well as easy-to-read information on how to stay safe online.</span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Chris realized that people need help recognizing the dangers and red flags before they step into a trap, not after they’ve been tricked and taken advantage of. The Easy Prey Podcast is the perfect way to reach a broad audience with stories and valuable information in today’s imperfect and sometimes dangerous world.</span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I want to provide a little background behind the launch of the podcast.  I launched</span> <a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/"><span style= "font-weight: 400;">WhatIsMyIPAddress.com</span></a> <span style= "font-weight: 400;">the Dark Ages of the Internet back in 2000.  Over the years it has grown from my social to a technical issue to a hobby to a side hustle.  In 2014 when I lost my day job it became my full-time work. As the site started to grow, more and more people who are the victims of scams reached out to me for help.  There were the victims of romance scams, identity theft, phishing, lottery scams, and the list goes on. To some the losses were minimal and to others it was their life savings and beyond.  Regardless of the loss, my heart goes out to them. When looking back at the interactions there were plenty of warning signs that were either overlooked or outright ignored.  </span></p> <p> </p> <p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many of those losses could have been prevented if they had only known what to be on the watch for. Over the years, I have had the pleasure of meeting and learning from experts in various industries and what to bring their knowledge and expertise to you.  You will hear true stories and actionable advice that will help you, your friends and your family from becoming Easy Prey.  </span></p>]]></description>
			<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p>Have you or your family been victims of identity theft, phishing, romance scams, or any other scams?  The true stories and actionable advice you will hear on this podcast can help save you money, headaches, and more.  </p> <p> </p> <p>Chris Parker is the founder of <a href="https://whatismyipaddress.com/">WhatIsMyIPAddress.com</a> and host of the <a href= "https://www.easyprey.com/">Easy Prey podcast</a>, which attracts over 6 million monthly visits. His website provides information on IP addresses, as well as easy-to-read information on how to stay safe online.</p> <p> </p> <p>Chris realized that people need help recognizing the dangers and red flags before they step into a trap, not after they’ve been tricked and taken advantage of. The Easy Prey Podcast is the perfect way to reach a broad audience with stories and valuable information in today’s imperfect and sometimes dangerous world.</p> <p> </p> <p>I want to provide a little background behind the launch of the podcast.  I launched <a href= "https://whatismyipaddress.com/">WhatIsMyIPAddress.com</a> the Dark Ages of the Internet back in 2000.  Over the years it has grown from my social to a technical issue to a hobby to a side hustle.  In 2014 when I lost my day job it became my full-time work. As the site started to grow, more and more people who are the victims of scams reached out to me for help.  There were the victims of romance scams, identity theft, phishing, lottery scams, and the list goes on. To some the losses were minimal and to others it was their life savings and beyond.  Regardless of the loss, my heart goes out to them. When looking back at the interactions there were plenty of warning signs that were either overlooked or outright ignored.  </p> <p> </p> <p>Many of those losses could have been prevented if they had only known what to be on the watch for. Over the years, I have had the pleasure of meeting and learning from experts in various industries and what to bring their knowledge and expertise to you.  You will hear true stories and actionable advice that will help you, your friends and your family from becoming Easy Prey.  </p>]]></content:encoded>
